member.name: T:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.SecondDegreePolynomial
member.summary:
The SecondDegreePolynomial object defines parameters for the Second Degree Conformal Polynomial and Second Degree Standard Polynomial datum transformation models. These models define a Second Degree Conformal or Second Degree General Polynomial transformation between projection coordinates of systems on two different datums.
A Second Degree Conformal Polynomial is achieved by supplying an array of six polynomial coefficients. A Second Degree General Polynomial is achieved by supplying an array of 12 polynomial coefficients.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.SecondDegreePolynomial.Coefficients
member.summary:
The Coefficients property defines the array of polynomial coefficients used by the SecondDegreePolynomial object. A Second Degree Conformal Polynomial is achieved by supplying an array of six polynomial coefficients. A Second Degree (General) Polynomial is achieved by supplying an array of 12 polynomial coefficients.
When specifying the six coefficients for a Second Degree Conformal Polynomial, the order of the array should be as follows: a0,a1,a2,b0,b1,b2
When specifying the 12 coefficients for a Second Degree (General) Polynomial, the order of the array should be as follows:
a0,a1,a2,a3,a4,a5,b0,b1,b2,b3,b4,b5

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.SecondDegreePolynomial.ForwardInputSpaceXofOrig
member.summary: The ForwardInputSpaceXofOrig property specifies the X origin of the forward input datum for the SecondDegreePolynomial object. This value is expressed in terms of the model forward input unit.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.SecondDegreePolynomial.ForwardInputSpaceYofOrig
member.summary: The ForwardInputSpaceYofOrig property specifies the Y origin of the forward input datum for the SecondDegreePolynomial object. This value is expressed in terms of the model forward input unit.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.SecondDegreePolynomial.ModelForwardInputUnitID
member.summary:
The ModelForwardInputUnitID property specifies the forward input unit for the SecondDegreePolynomial object. Values are UnitConstants.
When parameters for a particular Second Degree Polynomial datum transformation are published, they define a transformation between projection coordinates which are in a particular unit. The ModelForwardInputUnitID specifies the units for the projection coordinates of the input system.
When the datum transformation model is set to the Second Degree Polynomial model, the TransformPoint and TransformPoints methods require the input and output point types to be cspENU, cspENO, cspENG projection coordinates in meters.
During TransformPoint(s), these points will be converted from meters to this input unit before the 2nd Degree polynomial is applied.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.SecondDegreePolynomial.ModelForwardOutputUnitID
member.summary:
The ModelForwardOutputUnitID property specifies the forward output unit for the SecondDegreePolynomial object. Values are UnitConstants.
When parameters for a particular Second Degree Polynomial datum transformation are published, they define a transformation between projection coordinates which are in a particular units. The ModelForwardOutputUnitID specifies the units for the projection coordinates of the output system. When the datum transformation model is set to the Second Degree Polynomial model, the TransformPoint and TransformPoints methods require the input and output point types to be cspENU, cspENO, cspENG (projection coordinates) in meters.
During TransformPoint(s), these points are converted from meters to the input unit (specified by the ModelForwardOutputUnitID) before the 2nd Degree polynomial is applied, then converted from this output unit back to meters.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.SecondDegreePolynomial.XNormalizationFactor
member.summary: The XNormalizationFactor property specifies the scaling in X for the SecondDegreePolynomial object.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.SecondDegreePolynomial.YNormalizationFactor
member.summary: The YNormalizationFactor property specifies the scaling in Y for the SecondDegreePolynomial object.

member.summary: GTTextPointGeometry represents a textual label with a position and rotation.

member.name: T:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPointGeometry
member.summary: GTPointGeometry represents a single point.
member.remarks:
The point is stored as a GTPoint object in the Origin property. The coordinates for the origin can be returned or modified through the X, Y, and Z properties of the GTPoint object.
A GTPoint is distinct from the GTPointGeometry in that the GTPoint object is an X, Y, Z position in space that describes higher geometry objects. This point can be a member of the GTPoints collection. As a members of the collection, GTPoint objects describe multiple positions in a GTPolylineGeometry object or a GTPolylgonGeometry object.
The GTPointGeometry object is a type of geometry object as are GTLineGeometry, GTPolylineGeometry, and GTPolylgonGeometry objects. This GTPointGeometry object can be a member of the GTGeometryCollection object.

member.name: T:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTGeometry

Intergraph GTechnology Geometry object.
This is the base class for all geometry types.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTGeometry.CreateGeometry(GTech._DGMGeometry)
member.summary: CreateGeometry is used to create the appropriate .NET class for an existing COM geometry object. This method is mostly used in G/Technology code to assist in the "translation" of the COM world to the .NET world.
member.remarks: For internal use only.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTGeometry.ExtractGeometry(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPoint,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPoint,System.Boolean)
member.summary: The ExtractGeometry function creates a new geometry object by extracting parts of an existing geometry between two specified points. This function will enable a user to create a new geometry object by extracting parts of an existing geometry between two specified points. This function is intended to be used in commands to digitize using existing geometry.
member.remarks:
Uses positional tolerance.
The start and end points must be on the input geometry. A tolerance is used to determine whether the end and start points are on the geometry. If the distance is greater than the tolerance, an exception is thrown. It is intended that this function be used in conjunction with GTSnapService to ensure that the start and end points are on the input geometry.
The start and end points must be distinct.
member.param: The point from which extraction begins. This point must lie on the input geometry.
The point where extraction ends. This point must lie on the input geometry.

Used to indicate if the points extracted from the start point to the end point should be returned in a descending order in the point list. If this parameter is true, the resulting geometry will be digitized in the reverse order of the original geometry.

member.summary: The GetKeypointType function returns the keypoint type, such as gtkptEndPoint, of a specific keypoint defined by this geometry object.
member.param: The keypoint index, which must be between 0 and 1 less than the number of keypoints defined by the geometry. The KeypointCount property returns the number of keypoints.
member.returns: The type of keypoint.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTGeometry.GetKeypointPosition(System.Int32)
member.summary: The GetKeypointPosition function returns the position as a GTPoint object of a specific keypoint defined by this geometry.
member.param: The keypoint index, which must be between 0 and 1 less than the number of keypoints defined by the geometry. The KeypointCount property returns the number of keypoints.
member.returns: The coordinates of the keypoint.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTGeometry.BreakLinear(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPoint)
member.summary: The BreakLinear method creates two geometry objects by breaking an existing linear geometry object at a specified break point. This function is intended to be used in commands to allow the breaking of existing linework during digitizing so that clean linework, such as nodes at intersections, can be maintained.
member.remarks:
Uses PositionalTolerance.
The break point must be on the input geometry. A tolerance is used to determine whether the point is on the geometry. If the distance is greater than the tolerance, an exception is thrown. It is intended that this function be used in conjunction with SmartSketch to ensure that the break point is snapped to the input geometry.
This method returns an array of one or two geometries. If the break point is on the start point of the input geometry, then one geometry is returned, consisting of the entire input geometry. Likewise, if the break point is on the end point of the input geometry, then one geometry is returned, consisting of the entire input geometry.
member.param: The point where the break is to occur. This point must lie on the input geometry.
member.returns: An array of geometries.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTGeometry.BreakPolygon(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTGeometry)
member.summary: The BreakPolygon method creates two polygon geometry objects by breaking an existing polygon geometry object using a specified linear geometry. This function is intended to be used in commands to allow the splitting of simple polygonal areas with a linear geometry -- for example, the splitting of parcel features.
member.remarks:
Uses positional tolerance.
The break points must be on the input geometry. A tolerance is used to determine whether the points are on the geometry. If the distance is greater than the tolerance, an exception is thrown. It is intended that this function be used in conjunction with SnapService to ensure that the break points are snapped to the input geometry.
member.param: The geometry that splits the polygon geometry. The types of linear geometries allowed are line, polyline, and composite polyline. The start point in the linear geometry is assumed to be the first break point and the end point of the linear geometry is assumed to be the second break point. The endpoints of the linear geometry must lie on the polygon geometry.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTGeometry.TrimTo(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTGeometryCollection,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPoint)
member.summary:
The TrimTo method trims the input polyline to one of the crossing_geometries based on the input_point. The polyline is trimmed on the side that has its endpoint closest to the input_point.
The point to which to trim is defined by one of the geometries in the CrossingGeometry collection. The portion of the polyline to trim is defined by a point created by the geometry crossing the closest to the endpoint to trim.
If the input geometry is trimmed, this method returns an array of two geometries. The first element of the array is the input geometry minus the trimmed portion. The second element is the portion of the input geometry that was trimmed. If no trimming is performed, this method returns null.
member.remarks: If the input_point falls on the input geometry between two crossing geometries, nothing will be trimmed and the function will return False.
member.param: Collection of geometries possibly crossing the Input Geometry. Must be a GeometryCollection containing at least one item.
Point defining which side of the InputGeomety to trim.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTGeometry.ExtendTo(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTGeometryCollection,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPoint)
member.summary: The ExtendTo function extends the input polyline to one of the target geometries. The extension is oriented at the angle of the segment from which the extension is added. If an extension is made, this function returns an array of two elements. The first element is the extended geometry, while the second element is the extension that was added (a two-point polyline).
member.remarks:
The geometry must be a polyline.
The target_geometries must be a GTGeometryCollection containing at least one item.
member.param: GTPoint defining which side of the InputGeomety to extend.
Geometry collection to which to possibly extend.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTGeometry.CreateOffsetGeometries(System.Double)
member.summary: Creates parallel geometries to the right and left of the input geometry that are offset by a given distance. Right and left are defined by the direction of the points of the input geometry.
member.remarks:
If offset geometries can be created, then an array of 2 elements is returned. The left geometry is the first element (index 0) and the right geometry is the second element (index 1). If no offset geometries can be created, the function returns null.
The input geometry must be a polyline, composite polyline, polygon, or composite polygon.
The returned geometries may not be the same type of geometry as the input geometry. It is possible that the input of a simple polyline could produce a composite polyline output, or that the input of a composite polyline could produce a simple polyline output. The same is true for polygons.
If the input geometry is complex enough (has self-intersections, near self-intersections, or multiple sharp angles), then the output can be a GeometryCollection.
member.param: Distance from the input geometry at which to create the new geometry.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTGeometry.CopyGeometryParallel(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPoint,System.Double)
member.summary: Creates parallel geometry to the right or the left of the input geometry, given an offset distance. The input point defines the side to which to copy parallel. If no offset geometry can be created, the function returns null.
member.remarks: The InputGeometry must be either a polygon, composite polygon, polyline, composite polyline, or an arc.
member.param: Point defining which side of the geometry to create the parallel geometry.
Distance from the input geometry at which to create the new geometry.

member.summary: Returns the last point of the geometry. Typically, this would be the last point that is drawn when the geometry is displayed. It is generally also equivalent to the last keypoint. member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPointGeometry.Origin
member.summary: The Origin property returns the origin point or sets a point of reference that is used to determine the normal vector. This origin point is used to determine alignment, rotation, height and width, normal vectors, and so forth.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTTextPointGeometry.Alignment
member.summary: Returns or sets the alignment of the geometry's position with its bounding box. The 9 possible values correspond to the 4 corners of the bounding box, the 4 centers of each edge of the bounding box, and the center of the box. The Alignment determines where the text appears relative to the Origin (the position) of the geometry.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTTextPointGeometry.Format
member.summary:
Returns an indicator of the format of the text.
A property value of gtfmtRichText indicates that the text is in Rich Text format. The property value gtfmtUnGTFormatted indicates plain unformatted text.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTTextPointGeometry.Normal
member.summary: Returns or sets the vector that represents normal to the plane in which the textpoint geometry lies.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTTextPointGeometry.RichText
member.summary: Returns or sets the rich text stored with the GTTextPointGeometry object. This text must be in rich text format.
member.remarks: Text set by the RichText property is stored only if the Format property is set for rich text(gmfRichText).

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTTextPointGeometry.Rotation
member.summary: Returns or sets the rotation in degrees of the text geometry.
member.remarks: This rotation angle is measured counterclockwise from the origin point. The new rotation angle is not stored until the applicable record is updated with the new geometry.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTTextPointGeometry.Text

member.name: T:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTMatrix
member.summary:
GTMatrix represents a 4x4 three-dimensional matrix. GTMatrix is often used to hold a coordinate transformation matrix. The elements of a transformation matrix have the following meanings:
Element 0,0X-coordinate portion of scaling/rotation of X
Element 0,1X-coordinate portion of scaling/rotation of Y
Element 0,2X-coordinate portion of scaling/rotation of Z
Element 0,3Translation of X-coordinate.
Element 1,0Y-coordinate portion of scaling/rotation of X
Element 1,1Y-coordinate portion of scaling/rotation of Y
Element 1,2Y-coordinate portion of scaling/rotation of Z
Element 1,3Translation of Y-coordinate.
Element 2,0Z-coordinate portion of scaling/rotation of X
Element 2,1Z-coordinate portion of scaling/rotation of Y
Element 2,2Z-coordinate portion of scaling/rotation of Z
Element 2,3Translation of Z-coordinate.
Element 3,0Should be 0.0
Element 3,1Should be 0.0
Element 3,2Should be 0.0
Element 3,3Should be 1.0
All other elements should be equal to the corresponding elements of the identity matrix.

member.summary: Creates an identity matrix.

member.summary: Returns the product of the two given matrices. .

A GTMatrix object.

member.name: T:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTGeometryCollection
member.summary: The GTGeometryCollection object is a collection of geometry objects. These geometry objects are created apart from the GTGeometryCollection object and then added to it. They can also be removed from the collection.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTGeometryCollection.#ctor
member.summary: Creates a new empty collection.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTGeometryCollection.GetComponentKeypointIndexOffset(System.Int32)
member.summary: The GetComponentKeypointIndexOffset function returns the offset from which keypoint indexes begin for a specific component in the given geometry object.
member.remarks:
A geometry object which can have component geometries, such as a GeometryCollection object, contains all of the keypoints defined by its components. It is sometimes necessary to find out what the index of a keypoint defined by a certain component is in the scope of the parent geometry.
Example:
A certain GeometryCollection object, P, contains two components C1 and C2. C1 (a PolylineGeometry) has 5 keypoints, and C2 (an ArcGeometry) has 3 keypoints. Therefore, P has a total of 8 keypoints. To find the index of C2’s second keypoint within the scope of P, you can use GetComponentKeypointIndexOffset. The keypoint index offset for C2 in this case would be 5 because C1 has 5 keypoints. So C2’s second keypoint has an index of 7 ( 2 + 5) with respect to the list of keypoints in P.
member.param: The index of the component. Must be between 0 and Count-1.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTGeometryCollection.GetParent(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTGeometry)
member.summary: The GetParent method takes a descendent geometry of this geometry and returns the immediate parent of the descendent.
member.param: Some descendent of the root geometry object.
member.remarks: The return value may be this geometry, if it is the immediate parent of the given . If the given is not really a descendant of this geometry, an exception is raised.

member.summary: Creates a new empty composite polyline.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTCompositePolylineGeometry.ReplaceVertexByFillet(System.Int32,System.Double)
member.summary: Replaces the vertex specified by the key point index argument on the linear or area geometry by a fillet with the specified radius.
member.remarks:
For CompositePolyline geometries, keypoint_index must specify an interior vertex.
For CompositePolygon geometries, keypoint_index may specify any vertex.
The vertex is replaced by a fillet only if there is a line segment between (keypoint_index - 1) and keypoint_index vertices and there is a line segment between keypoint_index and (keypoint_index + 1) vertices.
The vertex is replaced by a fillet only if the line segments adjacent to the specified vertex are modified. The fillet is not inserted if one or both of the adjacent line segments would be completely eliminated.
Valid case
There is a smooth transition between the fillet arc and the line segments adjacent to the vertex to replace. The vertex will be replaced.
Invalid case
The radius is too large. A complete line segment would be eliminated and there would not be a smooth transition between the fillet arc and the adjacent line segment. The vertex will not be replaced.
Boundary geometry is not valid as the Geometry parameter. If a vertex of a boundary geometry has to be replaced by a fillet, custom code has to retrieve the boundary exterior or a hole where the vertex replacement should take place and pass this subgeometry the Geometry parameter.
If KeyPointIndex specifies an interior vertex of a polyline item, the polyline item is broken into two new polyline items and the fillet arc is inserted between them.
If KeyPointIndex specifies a boundary vertex between two polyline items, the fillet arc is inserted between them. The last vertex of the before item is adjusted to become connected to the start point of the fillet arc. The first vertex of the after item is adjusted to become connected to the end point of the fillet arc.
If KeyPointIndex specifies the first vertex of the composite polygon geometry, the fillet arc is inserted as the first item and the last vertex is adjusted appropriately so that the shape remains closed. The start point of the fillet arc thus becomes the first keypoint of the composite polygon.
If KeyPointIndex specifies the last vertex of the composite polygon geometry, the fillet arc is inserted as the last item, and the first vertex is adjusted appropriately so that the shape remains closed. The end point of the fillet arc thus becomes the last keypoint of the composite polygon.
Example
Input Geometry is a composite polygon consisting of one polyline item.
KeyPointIndex = 1
The fillet arc is the first item of the composite polygon. The polyline is the second item. The last point of the polyline has been adjusted so that it is identical with the start point of the arc.
KeyPointIndex = 5
The polyline is the first item of the composite polygon. Fillet arc is the second item. The first item of the polyline is adjusted so that it is identical with the start point of the fillet arc.
Positional tolerance must be greater than zero for all calculations to complete successfully.
member.param: The key point index of the vertex to be replaced.
The radius of the fillet arc.

member.name: T:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.LinearModelResidual
member.summary:
The LinearModelResidual object contains the residual statistics for its owning Observation when a linear model was used to calculate the least squares transformation.
The LinearModelResidual object is available only when the owning LeastSquares object is defined to have a linear model type (LeastSquares.IsLinear returns True) and the LeastSquares.CalculateTransformation method has been called.
With linear models, the mathematical assumption is made that system 1 observations are fixed. In the process of calculating the transformation, adjustment to observations can be performed only on system 2 coordinates. Thus, residuals are measured with respect to system 2 observations.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.LinearModelResidual.Norm
member.summary: The Norm property returns the residual norm, computed from the residuals in X, Y, and, if the model is three-dimensional, Z. Residuals for linear models are computed as the differences between the coordinates of the original observation in system 2 and the transformed observation from system 1.
member.remarks: This property cannot be accessed when the LeastSquares object has been put into a state that necessitates recalculation of the transformation.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.LinearModelResidual.StandardizedNorm
member.summary: Returns the norm of the standardized residuals.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.LinearModelResidual.StandardizedX
member.summary: The StandardizedX property returns the standardized X coordinate residual. Standardized residuals are defined as regular residuals divided by the standard deviation of those residuals. These regular residuals are computed as the differences between the coordinates of the original observation in system 2 and the transformed observation from system 1.
member.remarks: This property cannot be accessed when the LeastSquares object has been put into a state that necessitates recalculation of the transformation.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.LinearModelResidual.StandardizedY
member.summary: The StandardizedY property returns the standardized Y coordinate residual. Standardized residuals are defined as regular residuals divided by the standard deviation of those residuals. These regular residuals are computed as the differences between the coordinates of the original observation in system 2 and the transformed observation from system 1.
member.remarks: This property cannot be accessed when the LeastSquares object has been put into a state that necessitates recalculation of the transformation.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.LinearModelResidual.StandardizedZ
member.summary: The StandardizedZ property returns the standardized Z coordinate residual. Standardized residuals are defined as regular residuals divided by the standard deviation of those residuals. These regular residuals are computed as the differences between the coordinates of the original observation in system 2 and the transformed observation from system 1.
member.remarks: This property cannot be accessed when the LeastSquares object has been put into a state that necessitates recalculation of the transformation. A standardized Z coordinate residual is defined only for three-dimensional transformation models. For two-dimensional models, this property returns zero.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.LinearModelResidual.X
member.summary: The X property returns the X coordinate residual. Residuals for linear models are computed as the differences between the coordinates of the original observation in system 2 and the transformed observation from system 1.
member.remarks: This property cannot be accessed when the LeastSquares object has been put into a state that necessitates recalculation of the transformation.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.LinearModelResidual.Y
member.summary: The Y property returns the Y coordinate residual. Residuals for linear models are computed as the differences between the coordinates of the original observation in system 2 and the transformed observation from system 1.
member.remarks: This property cannot be accessed when the LeastSquares object has been put into a state that necessitates recalculation of the transformation.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.LinearModelResidual.Z
member.summary: The Z property returns the Z coordinate residual. Residuals for linear models are computed as the differences between the coordinates of the original observation in system 2 and the transformed observation from system 1. This Z coordinate residual is defined only for three-dimensional models. For two-dimensional models, this property is undefined.
member.remarks: This property cannot be accessed when the LeastSquares object has been put into a state that necessitates recalculation of the transformation.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTCUService.Selection(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Method to interactively execute CU Selection.
member.param: Specifies if the CUs being added are primary or ancillary CUs. For primary CUs to be displayed, the Primary parameter for this method should be passed as True or -1. For ancillary CUs, this parameter should be passed as False or 0.
member.remarks:
Default values 1, string.Empty and string.Empty are used for Occurrence, Keyword and Value.
If multiple features are defined inside the GTKeyObjects collection, then the CU Selection dialog box will be displayed once for each feature being processed. In this case, the feature name and feature ID will be displayed on the dialog box as it is displayed to the user.
This method returns a status that indicates whether the user dismissed the CU Selection dialog box by clicking OK or by clicking Cancel. A value of 1 means the user clicked OK; a value of 2 means the user clicked Cancel.
If the dialog box is displayed multiple times because the GTKeyObjects collection contains more than one GTKeyObject, the user can click OK to dismiss some of the dialog instances and Cancel to dismiss others. In this case, the status returned will be the OK or Cancel status of the last dialog box shown.
The number of Keywords and the number of Values supplied must match. If they do not, an error message will be displayed and the CU Selection dialog box will not be displayed.
If the Keywords and Values parameters are passed, then the CUs displayed on the dialog box for the features specified in the GTKeyObjects collection will be pre-filtered.
Keywords and values will be validated. Any invalid keywords or invalid values will result in an error message being raised, and the CU Selection dialog box will not be displayed.
The following SQL statements can be used to find specific keywords for a given feature (facility):
STORMS
SELECT * FROM TWMFACKEYWORDTYPE WHERE CD_FACILITY = [Facility Name];
LOGICA
SELECT * FROM CU_CATEGORY_ATTRIBUTE where CU_CATEGORY_CODE = [Facility Name];
The following SQL statements can be used to find specific values possible for keywords:
STORMS
SELECT * FROM TWMKEYWORD WHERE TP_KEYWORD = [Keyword];
LOGICA
SELECT * FROM CU_ATTRIBUTE_VALUE WHERE CU_ATTRIBUTE_CODE = [Keyword] AND CU_CATEGORY_CODE = [Facility];
When filtering ancillary CUs, the Keywords parameter may also contain one first level filter for each distinct feature type. No value item should be supplied in the Values parameter for first level filters. Thus, the Keywords array will contain more items than the Values array.
The following queries can be used to find first level filters for a given Feature (Facility)
STORMS
SELECT * FROM TWMFACILITYXREF WHERE CD_FACILITY = [Facility Name];
LOGICA
SELECT * FROM G3E_LOGICACUXREF WHERE G3E_FEATURENAME = [Facility Name];
If first level filters are included, they can be anywhere in the Keywords array. As they are identified, they will be removed from the Keywords array, leaving just keywords. Once all of the first level keywords have been removed, the remaining keywords and values will be paired together based on the position of each in the arrays. So the value at array location 1 will be paired with the keyword at array location 1. If the keywords and values are not paired correctly, then the values will be considered as invalid and an error message will be displayed. If the number of remaining keywords does not match the number of values, then an error message will be displayed.
The CUs selected will be checked for Macro expansion.
If the CU component being populated is defined as a repeating component, then the user will be prompted for the quantity of this CU to be added. New CU records will be created, based on the quantity specified.
For STORMS processing, if an application dependency exists for this CU, then the Application Dependency dialog will be displayed to the user for population of these values.
If the CU identifier being added is a primary CU, then static attributes will be processed.
If the CU component being populated is a non-repeating component, and a CU is already defined for the feature, then this method will overwrite the existing CU information and processing will be similar to the Replace Method. No new CU record will be created in this case.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTCUService.Selection(System.Boolean,System.Int16)
member.summary: Method to interactively execute CU Selection.
member.param: Specifies if the CUs being added are primary or ancillary CUs. For primary CUs to be displayed, the Primary parameter for this method should be passed as True or -1. For ancillary CUs, this parameter should be passed as False or 0.

Shows application dependencies, if any, associated with this CU instance. Like the Keywords parameter, this parameter allows CUs to be pre-filtered on the dialog box. Calling the Selection method without an Occurrence value or with an Occurrence value of -1 will display the CU Selection dialog box so that CUs can be selected interactively. Application dependencies will be displayed only if an Occurrence other than -1 is specified and the CU is an ancillary CU. You will not be able to reselect the ancillary CU value through the GUI. If an Occurrence other than -1 is specified and the CU is a primary CU, the CU Selection dialog box will be displayed first and then the application dependency dialog will appear if the database is configured for application dependencies. If the feature is defined to have application dependencies for this CU type (primary or ancillary), but no application dependencies exist for this CU occurrence, then a message will be displayed stating that this CU does not have any application dependencies. This preserves the current implementation of the CU Selection dialog box when invoked from Feature Explorer.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTCUService.Add(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Method to Add a Primary or Ancillary CU.
member.param: IDs of one or more CUs being added. If a CU being added is a primary CU, then static attributes will be processed. Multiple CUs can be passed as a comma-delimited string of CUs, or they can be passed as a variant array of strings.

Specifies if the CUs being added are primary or ancillary CUs. If the Primary parameter is True, the CUs will be mapped onto the features inside the GTKeyObjects collection using the CU facility name and feature numbers on each GTKeyObject. If a match is not found, an error will be raised to the calling routine. If the Primary parameter is False, the CUs will be mapped onto the first feature inside the GTKeyObjects collection. If the Primary parameter is True, the CUs can be applied to multiple GTKeyObjects, based on the facility-to-feature mappings. So the CUs will be applied to the features they are defined for. If the Primary parameter is False, the CUs will only be applied to the first GTKeyObject. This is because ancillary CUs do not carry specific facility-to-feature mappings like primary CUs.
member.remarks:
The CUs will be added to the features defined in the GTKeyObjects collection.
This method can display the following dialog boxes:
Select CU Quantity
Application Dependency Properties
For STORMS processing, if an application dependency exists for this CU, then the Application Dependency Properties dialog box will be displayed to the user for population of these values.
Each CU will be checked for macro expansion.
If the CU component being populated is defined as a repeating component, the user will be prompted for the quantity of this CU to be added. New CU records will be created based on the quantity specified.
If the CU component being populated is a non-repeating component, and a CU is already defined for the feature, this method will overwrite the existing CU information and processing will be similar to the Replace Method. No new CU record will be created in this case.
If the CU component being populated is a non-repeating component, and multiple CU values are specified in the CUIdentifiers parameter, then the last CU in the parameter is the one that gets assigned to the feature.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTCUService.Delete(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Method to delete an existing CU.
member.param: ID of the CU being deleted. If the CUIdentifier being deleted is a primary CU, then static attributes will be processed. The CUIdentifiers parameter can contain one or more CU values.
Specifies if the CUs being added are primary or ancillary CUs.
member.remarks:
Default value 1 is used for Occurrence.
Calling this method will delete the CU attribute from the feature. This method also cleans up application dependencies for STORMS and other CU-related components from Logica that are tied to the CU being deleted.
If the CU component to be cleaned up is optional, the instances will be deleted. If the CU component to be cleaned up is required and this is not the last instance of this component, then the instance will be deleted. If this is the last instance of a required CU component, the instance will not be deleted. Instead, the CU attributes for the CU identifier, macro CU, usage, and quantity will be nulled out.
If the CU being deleted is a primary CU, the static attributes associated with this CU will be left as is.
If Delete is called and more than one GTKeyObject has been specified, an error will be raised.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTCUService.Delete(System.String,System.Boolean,System.Int16)
member.summary: Method to delete an existing CU.
member.remarks:
Calling this method will delete the CU attribute from the feature. This method also cleans up application dependencies for STORMS and other CU-related components from Logica that are tied to the CU being deleted.
If the CU component to be cleaned up is optional, the instances will be deleted. If the CU component to be cleaned up is required and this is not the last instance of this component, then the instance will be deleted. If this is the last instance of a required CU component, the instance will not be deleted. Instead, the CU attributes for the CU identifier, macro CU, usage, and quantity will be nulled out.
If the CU being deleted is a primary CU, the static attributes associated with this CU will be left as is.
If Delete is called and more than one GTKeyObject has been specified, an error will be raised.
member.param: ID of the CU being deleted. If the CUIdentifier being deleted is a primary CU, then static attributes will be processed. The CUIdentifiers parameter can contain one or more CU values.
Specifies if the CUs being added are primary or ancillary CUs.

If the CU being deleted is an ancillary macro CU and an Occurrence value is specified, then only the specified instance of the macro CU will be cleaned up. If the CU being deleted is an ancillary macro CU and no Occurrence value is specified, then all the CUs associated with this macro will be cleaned up. If the CU being deleted is a primary macro CU, then all the CUs and related components associated with this macro will be cleaned up. The Occurrence parameter will be ignored. This means that one individual occurrence or instance of a primary macro CU cannot be deleted. For non-macro CUs, if the Occurrence parameter is specified, then only this occurrence (G3E_CID) of this CU will be cleaned up; otherwise all CUs that match the CUIdentifier parameter will be cleaned up.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTCUService.Replace(System.String,System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Method to replace an existing CU with another CU value.
member.param: ID of the CU being replaced. If the CU component being replaced is defined as a repeating component, then the user will be prompted for the quantity of this CU to be added. If the ExistingCUIdentifier is a macro CU, the macro will be cleaned up according to the rules laid out in the Delete method for macro cleanup.
ID of the CU replacing the existing one. The NewCUIdentifier will be checked for macro expansion.
Specifies if the CUs being added are primary or ancillary CUs.
member.remarks:
Default value 1 is used for Occurrence.
This method can display the following dialog boxes:
Select CU Quantity
Application Dependency Properties
For STORMS processing, if an application dependency exists for this CU, then the Application Dependency Properties dialog box will be displayed for population of these values.
If Replace is called and more than one GTKeyObject has been specified, an error will be raised.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTCUService.Replace(System.String,System.String,System.Boolean,System.Int16)
member.summary: Method to replace an existing CU with another CU value.
member.param: ID of the CU being replaced. If the CU component being replaced is defined as a repeating component, then the user will be prompted for the quantity of this CU to be added. If the ExistingCUIdentifier is a macro CU, the macro will be cleaned up according to the rules laid out in the Delete method for macro cleanup.
ID of the CU replacing the existing one. The NewCUIdentifier will be checked for macro expansion.
Specifies if the CUs being added are primary or ancillary CUs.
The specific occurrence within the primary or ancillary CU component to be replaced by the NewCUIdentifier.
member.remarks:
This method can display the following dialog boxes:
Select CU Quantity
Application Dependency Properties
For STORMS processing, if an application dependency exists for this CU, then theApplication Dependency Properties dialog box will be displayed for population of these values.
If Replace is called and more than one GTKeyObject has been specified, an error will be raised.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTCUService.Validate
member.summary: Method to validate CU and static attribute values.
member.remarks:
This method validates the feature within the GTKeyObjects collection to make certain that all the static attributes for the primary CUs are consistent. If they are not, an ADO recordset listing the feature's G3E_FID and CUIdentifier values that are inconsistent will be returned.
The current static attribute values and the expected values (based upon the CUIdentifier) will also be returned inside this recordset.
The format of the recordset is as follows:
FEATURE_NAME — Username of the feature.
G3E_FID — Feature instance.
COMPONENT_NAME — Username of the CU component record.
G3E_CID — CU component instance.
CU_IDENTIFIER — The CU value.
STATIC_ATTRIBUTE_NAME — Username of the static attribute field.
CURRENT_ATTRIBUTE_VALUE — The value stored in the static attribute.
EXPECTED_ATTRIBUTE_VALUE — The value expected for the static attribute.
If Validate is called and more than one GTKeyObject has been specified, an error will be raised.

Select CU Quantity
Application Dependency Properties
For STORMS processing, if an application dependency exists for this CU, then theApplication Dependency Properties dialog box will be displayed for population of these values.
If Replace is called and more than one GTKeyObject has been specified, an error will be raised.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTCUService.DataContext
member.summary: Property to set the GTDataContext object.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTCUService.KeyObjects
member.summary: Property to set the KeyObjects collection.
member.remarks:
Selection and Add are the only methods that can process multiple GTKeyObjects, specifically to support the industryware Staking Sheet command. Otherwise, only the first GTKeyObject inside the collection will be processed.
Example
If a switch gear or other placement configuration with multiple features is being processed, then the GTKeyObject for each feature would be included inside the GTKeyObjects collection.
Calling the Selection or Add methods with multiple CUs would cause a mapping to occur between the CUs' facility definitions from the work management tables and the G3E_FEATURE.G3E_NAME for the features defined inside the GTKeyObject.
If multiple instances of one feature type were defined inside the GTKeyObjects collection, then the CU value mapped to this feature would be applied to each instance of the feature type (GTKeyObject).
Macro CUs cannot contain CUs for multiple feature definitions. The macro will be expanded and processed only against the feature that maps to the facility defined for the macro CU itself.

member.name: T:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTBoundaryGeometry
member.summary: GTBoundaryGeometry represents a polygon with excluded interior regions.
member.remarks:
Typically, the exterior geometry is a polygon geometry, although it may be a closed polyline geometry, that defines the boundary geometry extents. It is created separately from the GTBoundaryGeometry Object and is then assigned to the GTBoundaryGeometry.Exterior property.
Interior regions are geometry objects that are completely contained within the area of the exterior geometry and must not overlap each other. The collection of interior regions is a GTGeometryCollection object that is automatically created when the GTBoundaryGeometry is created. It is stored in the GTBoundaryGeometry.Holes property.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTBoundaryGeometry.#ctor
member.summary: Constructs a new empty boundary geometry.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTBoundaryGeometry.GetComponentKeypointIndexOffset(System.Int32)
member.summary: The GetComponentKeypointIndexOffset function returns the offset from which keypoint indexes begin for a specific component in the given geometry object.
member.remarks:
A geometry object which can have component geometries, such as a GeometryCollection object, contains all of the keypoints defined by its components. It is sometimes necessary to find out what the index of a keypoint defined by a certain component is in the scope of the parent geometry.
Example:
A certain GeometryCollection object, P, contains two components C1 and C2. C1 (a PolylineGeometry) has 5 keypoints, and C2 (an ArcGeometry) has 3 keypoints. Therefore, P has a total of 8 keypoints. To find the index of C2’s second keypoint within the scope of P, you can use GetComponentKeypointIndexOffset. The keypoint index offset for C2 in this case would be 5 because C1 has 5 keypoints. So C2’s second keypoint has an index of 7 ( 2 + 5) with respect to the list of keypoints in P.
member.param: The index of the component. Must be between 0 and Count-1.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTBoundaryGeometry.Exterior
member.summary: Returns or sets the geometry forming the exterior of the boundary. This is typically a polygon geometry.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTBoundaryGeometry.Holes
member.summary: Returns the geometry collection representing the holes (excluded regions) of the boundary. Note that modifying this collection will modify the holes of the boundary.

member.name: T:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.TransLinks
member.summary:
The TransLinks object is an ordered collection of Link objects representing the transformation path.
Link objects are created by the Links.Add method. An AltCoordSystemPath object creates and deletes Link objects and manages their persistence through its Links collection. An AltCoordSystemPath object manages its transformation path using its TransLinks collection. Link objects appended to an AltCoordSystemPath’s TransLinks collection must belong to its Links collection.

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.TransLinks.Append(Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.Link,System.Boolean,Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSTransDirectionConstants)
member.summary:
The Append method adds an existing Link object to the TransLinks collection, which represents an ordered transformation chain.
The Append method may also strengthen the transformation chain when adding the link to the chain. An example of strengthening would be to add a datum transformation between two coordinate systems on different datums.
member.remarks:
The TransLinks transformation chain exists to transform coordinates between the reference spaces of the coordinate system which is a member of the CoordSystemsMgr object (CoordSystemsMgr.CoordSystem) and the reference spaces of an alternate coordinate system or reference space which is defined within the AltCoordSystemPath which owns the TransLinks collection, where that AltCoordSystemPath exists within an AltCoordSystemPaths collection owned by the same CoordSystemsMgr. Therefore, the CoordSystemsMgr.CoordSystem is required to be the first link in the transformation chain. The TransLinks object automatically fulfills this requirement; thus the first call to TransLinks.Append actually results in the given link becoming the second link in the chain (assuming no strengthening occurs). Link objects accumulate sequentially in the forward direction.
The Link object is validated against the Link object that immediately precedes it in the collection (for the first link appended by a user, this implies it is validated against the CoordSystemsMgr.CoordSystem link). This is to ensure that there is at least one match between the output point types of the preceding link and the input point types of the link being added. If valid, the Append method adds the link.
The Link object being appended to the TransLinks collection must itself already be a member of a Links collection, where both the Links and TransLinks collections in question are members of the same AltCoordSystemPath object.
member.param: The Link object to append
Boolean flag dictating whether links should be added (if possible) between the old last link and this new last link to "strengthen" the chain. A True value means to strengthen.

Transformation direction in which the TM is to determine its ability to strengthen the chain transformation. This parameter is required if the Stengthen parameter is True. Currently the only strengthening performed by the Append method is the addition of a datum transformation link between two coordinate system links. Because all such datum transformations currently available are bidirectional and transformation between two coordinate systems is also bidirectional, the Append method currently ignores this parameter. You should specify cstdForward for this parameter.

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.TransLinks.RemoveAll
member.summary: The RemoveAll method removes all links in the TransLinks collection.
member.remarks:
The RemoveAll method removes only the links from the TransLinks collection. The Link objects are not deleted and still exist in the Links collection.
Once all links are removed, the links in the chain can no longer be accessed from the chain. If the code needs to reuse links in the chain in rebuilding this or other chains, references to these links must be made elsewhere before RemoveAll is called.

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.TransLinks.GetEnumerator
member.summary: Enumerates the Links in the transformation chain, in the order they were added.
member.returns: Collection type-safe enumerator

member.summary: Returns an enumerator for the collection.

member.summary: Returns the Link object specified by the index within the TransLinks collection.
member.param: The index in the collection of the object to return
member.returns: Link object

member.name: T:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.SingleParameterConstraint
member.summary:
The SingleParameterConstraint object allows the constraint of one of the transformation parameters so that the parameter must have a specified value.
Note: The Automation model does not allow constraints which involve more than one parameter, such as "Parameter 1 must equal twice Parameter 4".
The TransformationParameterIndex property of a SingleParameterConstraint must be greater than or equal to zero and less than the LeastSquares.NumberTransformationParameters property.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.SingleParameterConstraint.TransformationParameterIndex
member.summary:
The TransformationParameterIndex property defines which parameter of the least squares transformation is being constrained by the SingleParameterConstraint object.
The parameter is specified by a zero-based index into the array returned by the LeastSquares.TransformationParameters property. Thus, the value of this index must be greater than or equal to zero and less than the LeastSquares.NumberTransformationParameters
member.remarks:
If the model type is unknown, this property may be set to any value greater than or equal to zero. However, the transformation parameter index is validated at the time the LeastSquares.CalculateTransformation method is called. The model type must be defined then so the number of transformation parameters can be known.
Changing the value of the TransformationParameterIndex property while the LeastSquares.ConstraintsUsage property is True causes the LeastSquares object to mark itself as needing to recalculate the transformation. When the LeastSquares object is in this need-to-calculate state, users cannot obtain statistics, such as residual data, or transform points until the situation has been rectified -- in this case by calling the LeastSquares.CalculateTransformation method.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.SingleParameterConstraint.Value
member.summary: The Value property defines the value to which the particular least squares transformation parameter (as identified by the TransformationParameterIndex property) is being constrained.
member.remarks: Changing the value of this property while the LeastSquares.ConstraintsUsage property is True causes the LeastSquares object to mark itself as needing to recalculate the transformation. When the LeastSquares object is in this need-to-calculate state, users cannot obtain statistics, such as residual data, or transform points until the situation has been rectified -- in this case by calling the LeastSquares.CalculateTransformation method.

member.name: T:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.RefSpaceMgr
member.summary:
The RefSpaceMgr object defines a set of reference spaces based on a common geodetic datum and a set of algorithms for transforming coordinate points among the members of that local set of reference spaces.
The reference spaces defined are as follows:
Spheroid (geographic reference space)
Geocenter (geocentric reference space)
Projection plane (projected reference space)
Scaled paper reference space

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.RefSpaceMgr.GetMeridianConvergence(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: The GetMeridianConvergence method returns the meridian convergence of the projection reference space at a specified geographic point. This meridian convergence is the angle from the positive Y projection space axis to geographic North.
member.param: The longitude in radians of the specified point.
The latitude in radians of the specified point.
The height in meters of the specified point. In an application limited to 2-D this value may be set to zero.
member.returns: The meridian convergence angle in radians.

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.RefSpaceMgr.IsTransformationValid(Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSPointConstants,System.Int32,Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSPointConstants,System.Int32)
member.summary: Validates whether a proposed transformation can be performed by the object. If so, this method returns true.
member.param: Point type from the CSPointConstants enumeration for the points to transform
Ignored, but must be the value 1.
Point type from the CSPoint constants enumeration for the transformed points
Ignored, but must be the value 1.
member.returns: Boolean True or False

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.RefSpaceMgr.TransformPoint(Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSPointConstants,System.Int32,Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSPointConstants,System.Int32,System.Double@,System.Double@,System.Double@)
member.summary:
Transforms a single point between different reference spaces.
The TransformPoint method accepts a single point (specified as X, Y, and Z coordinate values) to transform, accepts the input and output point types, and accepts input and output reference space identifiers as input. The method returns the X, Y, and Z coordinate values of the transformed point, using the same parameters as used for the input coordinate values.
member.param: Point type from the CSPointConstants enumeration for the points to transform
Must be the value 1.
Point type from the CSPoint constants enumeration for the transformed points
Must be the value 1.
On Input, the X coordinate value of the point to be transformed. On output, the transformed X coordinate value.
On Input, the Y coordinate value of the point to be transformed. On output, the transformed Y coordinate value.

On Input, the Z coordinate value of the point to be transformed. On output, the transformed Z coordinate value. The X, Y, and Z parameters serve as both input and output (the transformation is done in place).

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.RefSpaceMgr.TransformPoints(Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSPointConstants,System.Int32,Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSPointConstants,System.Int32,System.Double[])
member.summary:
Transforms coordinates between different reference spaces.
The TransformPoints method accepts an array of points to transform, accepts the input and output point types, and accepts input and output reference space identifiers as input. The method returns the transformed coordinates, using the same array of points as used for input.
member.param: Point type from the CSPoint constants enumeration for the points to transform.
Must be the value 1.
Point type from the CSPointConstants enumeration for the transformed points.
Must be the value 1.
A single-dimensional array containing the points to transform. Each point is stored as a set of 3 consecutive elements representing X, Y, and Z coordinates respectively.

member.name: T:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPoints
member.summary:
GTPoints represents an ordered collection of GTPoint objects.
Note: A GTPoints collection may indirectly reference another object, such as a GTPolylineGeometry. Modifying the collection can modify that referenced object. The documentation of methods and properties that return GTPoints indicates whether the returned object may exhibit this behavior.
However, when you get a point (of type GTPoint) from this collection, that object is a copy of the point in the collection. To modify the coordinates of a point in a GTPoints collection, you must retrieve the point from the collection, modify it, then set that point in the collection (using the indexer property, for example).

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPoints.#ctor
member.summary: Constructs an empty GTPoints collection.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPoints.Add(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPoint)
member.summary: Adds the given point at the end of the collection.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPoints.Clear
member.summary: Removes all points from the collection.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPoints.Contains(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPoint)
member.summary: Returns true if the collection contains a point that is equal to the given point. Note that this method requires exact equality of the points (not approximate equality using a positional tolerance).
member.remarks: This method is likely to be slow if the collection has very many points.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPoints.CopyTo(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPoint[],System.Int32)
member.summary: Copies the contents of the collection to the given array, starting at the given array index.
member.param: Array to receive the collection elements.
Starting index for the copy.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPoints.Remove(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPoint)
member.summary: Removes the given point from the collection, if it is present. Relies on equality to determine if the given item is in the collection.
member.remarks: This method is likely to be slow if the collection has very many points.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPoints.GetEnumerator
member.summary: Enumerates the points in the collection. Note that the returned points are a copy of the items in the collection. Modifying one of the objects returned by this enumerator does NOT modify the collection.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPoints.System#Collections#IEnumerable#GetEnumerator
member.summary: Enumerates the points in the collection. Note that the returned points are a copy of the items in the collection. Modifying one of the objects returned by this enumerator does NOT modify the collection.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPoints.IndexOf(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPoint)
member.summary: Returns the index of the given point. Relies on equality to determine if the given point is in the collection.
member.remarks: This method is likely to be slow if the collection has very many points.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPoints.Insert(System.Int32,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPoint)
member.summary: Inserts the given point into the collection at the indicated position.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPoints.RemoveAt(System.Int32)
member.summary: Removes the item at the specified index in the collection.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPoints.Count
member.summary: Returns the number of elements in the collection.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPoints.IsReadOnly
member.summary: GTPoints collections are always read-write, so IsReadOnly always returns false.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPoints.Item(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns or sets an item in the collection. The get accessor returns a copy of the point, so modifying the returned value has no effect on the collection itself.

member.name: T:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTCompositePolygonGeometry
member.summary: GTCompositePolygonGeometry represents a closed polygon formed by a linear combination of polylines and arcs. Conceptually, GTCompositePolygonGeometry is just a collection of geometries, except that the geometry elements are required to touch end-to-end and the last point of the last element must be coincident with the first point of the first element.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTCompositePolygonGeometry.#ctor
member.summary: Creates a new empty composite Polygon.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTCompositePolygonGeometry.Contains(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPoint)
member.summary: The Contains function determines whether a point is inside this polygon. The polygon is stroked to create a simple polygon.
member.remarks: Returns gtiptOutside if the point is outside the polygon, gtiptOnPolygon if on the polygon, and gtiptInside if it is in the polygon.
member.param: GTPoint used to determined whether it is inside or outside of the polygon.

member.name: T:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTReplaceVertexByFilletConstants
member.summary:
The GTReplaceVertexByFilletConstants enumeration is used with the GTCompositePolylineGeometry.ReplaceVertexByFillet function.
The following values can be used by the caller to determine whether the replacement succeeded or find out why the replacement did not take place.

member.name: F:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTReplaceVertexByFilletConstants.gtrvfSuccess
member.summary: The vertex has been successfully replaced by the fillet arc.

member.name: F:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTReplaceVertexByFilletConstants.gtrvfInvalidRadius
member.summary: Radius must be greater than 0.

member.name: F:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTReplaceVertexByFilletConstants.gtrvfInvalidGeometryType
member.summary: The input geometry must be either composite polygon or composite polyline.

member.name: F:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTReplaceVertexByFilletConstants.gtrvfCannotReplaceFirstVertex
member.summary: The first vertex of composite polyline cannot be replaced by a fillet.

member.name: F:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTReplaceVertexByFilletConstants.gtrvfCannotReplaceLastVertex
member.summary: The last vertex of composite polyline cannot be replaced by a fillet.

member.name: F:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTReplaceVertexByFilletConstants.gtrvfInvalidKeyPointIndex
member.summary: Invalid key point index (must be greater than 0 and less or equal than key point count).

member.name: F:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTReplaceVertexByFilletConstants.gtrvfCannotManipulateArcItem

member.name: T:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.AltCoordSystemPaths
member.summary: The AltCoordSystemPaths object is a collection of AltCoordSystemPath objects.

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.AltCoordSystemPaths.Add(System.String)
member.summary: Creates and adds a new AltCoordSystemPath object to the AltCoordSystemPaths collection object.
member.param: The name of the AltCoordSystemPath object to create. This name must be 255 characters or less and can include embedded spaces. This name must uniquely identify the object in the collection.
member.returns: The created AltCoordSystemPath object

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.AltCoordSystemPaths.Delete(System.String)
member.summary: Deletes the named AltCoordSystemPath object from the AltCoordSystemPaths collection.
member.param: The name of the object to delete. This name must be 255 characters or less and can include embedded spaces.

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.AltCoordSystemPaths.System#Collections#IEnumerable#GetEnumerator
member.summary: Returns an enumerator for the collection.

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.AltCoordSystemPaths.GetEnumerator
member.summary: Returns a type-safe enumerator for the collection.
member.returns: Collection type-safe enumerator

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.AltCoordSystemPaths.Count
member.summary: Returns the number of objects in the collection.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.AltCoordSystemPaths.Item(System.String)
member.summary: Returns the named object from the collection.
member.remarks: When searching for the AltCoordSystemPath with the given name, the AltCoordSystemPaths.Item property performs a name comparison which is case-insensitive. Thus, for example, if an AltCoordSystemPath named "TestPath" exists, then an attempt to get the AltCoordSystemPath named "Testpath" will result in the retrieval of the AltCoordSystemPath named "TestPath." Case-insensitive uniqueness must be used because other objects such as ServerTransService and CSSTransformPipe use GUID strings as AltCoordSystemPath names, and case is indeterminate for such GUID strings.
member.param: The name of the object to return
member.returns: Collection named object

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTMath.CircleIntersectCircle(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPoint,System.Double,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPoint,System.Double)
member.summary: Computes the intersection of two circles defined by center point and radius. If the circles do not intersect, an empty array is returned. If the two circles overlap, an array with a single element is returned with a Type property of gtsptOverlap. Otherwise, one or two elements are returned with Type property gtsptOnSegment.
member.param: Center of the first circle
Radius of the first circle
Center of the second circle
Radius of the second circle

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTMath.PositionalTolerance
member.summary:
Gets or sets the positional tolerance used in comparing coordinate-related quantities. . .
Use this function with care; modifying this value could adversely affect the operation of your application. If you need a specific tolerance value only for a given operation, save the old tolerance, modify it, perform your operation, then restore the original tolerance value. The default value of this property is based on the coordinate system, and is generally the appropriate value to use when comparing geographic coordinates.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTMath.SquaredPositionalTolerance
member.summary: Returns the square of the PositionalTolerance value. In many cases, such as when comparing distances, it is more convenient to compare the square of the value (e.g., the squared distance) to the squared tolerance, in order to avoid a square-root operation. This property provides the squared tolerance directly. .

member.name: T:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.AltCoordSystemPath
member.summary:
The AltCoordSystemPath object contains a chain of transformations to an alternate CoordSystem object. The object provides a transformation pathway between the base CoordSystem of the CoordSystemsMgr object that contains it and another (alternate) coordinate system.
An AltCoordSystemPath object
Creates and deletes Link objects and manages their persistence through its Links collection.
Manages its transformation path using its TransLinks collection.
Link objects appended to an AltCoordSystemPath’s TransLinks collection must belong to its Links collection.

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.AltCoordSystemPath.IsTransformationValid(Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSPointConstants,System.Int32,Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSPointConstants,System.Int32)
member.summary: Validates whether a proposed transformation can be performed by the object. If so, this method returns true.
member.param: Point type from the CSPointConstants enumeration for the points to transform.
Use the value 1 to identify reference spaces within the coordinate system of the CoordSystemsMgr and the value 2 to indentify reference spaces within the alternate coordinate system.
Point type from the CSPointConstants enumeration for the transformed points.
Use the value 1 to identify reference spaces within the coordinate system of the CoordSystemsMgr and the value 2 to indentify reference spaces within the alternate coordinate system.
member.returns: Boolean True or False

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.AltCoordSystemPath.RecomputeInternalPaths
member.summary: Updates the path array.
member.remarks: The internal path array within the AltCoordSystemPath object governs point transformations across the transformation chain represented by the TransLinks collection. Therefore, when one of the transformation link objects is changed in any way that affects its transformation capabilities (a change to projection algorithm parameters within a coordinate system link, for example) the AltCoordSystemPath object’s internal path array should be updated using the RecomputeInternalPaths method.

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.AltCoordSystemPath.TransformPoint(Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSPointConstants,System.Int32,Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSPointConstants,System.Int32,System.Double@,System.Double@,System.Double@)
member.summary:
Transforms a single point between different reference spaces.
The TransformPoint method accepts a single point (specified as X, Y, and Z coordinate values) to transform, accepts the input and output point types, and accepts input and output reference space identifiers as input. The method returns the X, Y, and Z coordinate values of the transformed point, using the same parameters as used for the input coordinate values.
member.param: Point type from the CSPointConstants enumeration for the points to transform.
Use the value 1 to identify reference spaces within the coordinate system of the CoordSystemsMgr and the value 2 to indentify reference spaces within the alternate coordinate system.
Point type from the CSPointConstants enumeration for the transformed points.
Use the value 1 to identify reference spaces within the coordinate system of the CoordSystemsMgr and the value 2 to indentify reference spaces within the alternate coordinate system.
On Input, the X coordinate value of the point to be transformed. On output, the transformed X coordinate value.
On Input, the Y coordinate value of the point to be transformed. On output, the transformed Y coordinate value.

On Input, the Z coordinate value of the point to be transformed. On output, the transformed Z coordinate value. The X, Y, and Z parameters serve as both input and output (the transformation is done in place).

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.AltCoordSystemPath.TransformPoints(Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSPointConstants,System.Int32,Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSPointConstants,System.Int32,System.Double[])
member.summary:
Transforms coordinates between different reference spaces.
The TransformPoints method accepts an array of points to transform, accepts the input and output point types, and accepts input and output reference space identifiers as input. The method returns the transformed coordinates, using the same array of points as used for input.
member.param: Point type from the CSPoint constants enumeration for the points to transform.
Use the value 1 to identify reference spaces within the coordinate system of the CoordSystemsMgr and the value 2 to indentify reference spaces within the alternate coordinate system.
Point type from the CSPointConstants enumeration for the transformed points.
Use the value 1 to identify reference spaces within the coordinate system of the CoordSystemsMgr and the value 2 to indentify reference spaces within the alternate coordinate system.
A single-dimensional array containing the points to transform. Each point is stored as a set of 3 consecutive elements representing X, Y, and Z coordinates respectively.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.AltCoordSystemPath.Links
member.summary: Returns the Links collection object for the AltCoordSystemPath object. This property extends the methods and properties of the Links collection object to the AltCoordSystemPath object.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.AltCoordSystemPath.TransLinks
member.summary: Returns the TransLinks object for the AltCoordSystemPath object. These represent the transformation path from this alternate coordinate system to/from the primary coordinate system.
