member.name: T:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.Observations
member.summary:
The Observations object contains the set of pairs of coordinate points used by the owning LeastSquares object to calculate or validate its transformation.
Properties for the Observations object are read-only.

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.Observations.Add
member.summary: The Add method creates a new Observation object, adds it to the Observations collection, and returns it to the caller. This new Observation is essentially empty, having no name or description, and its coordinate values for both System 1 and System 2 are all set to zero.
member.remarks: Adding a new Observation object to the Observations collection causes the owning LeastSquares object to mark itself as needing to recalculate the transformation. When the LeastSquares object is in this need-to-calculate state, users cannot obtain statistics, such as residual data, or transform points until the situation has been rectified by (in this case) filling out the properties of the new Observation and calling the LeastSquares.CalculateTransformation method.

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.Observations.Delete(System.Int32)
member.summary: The Delete method removes a specified Observation object from the collection and obliterates its internal data storage.
member.remarks:
Numeric indices in the Observations collection begin with the value 0.
An attempt to delete with an invalid (out-of-range) index produces an error.
Deleting an Observation from the Observations collection causes the owning LeastSquares object to mark itself as needing to recalculate the transformation if the Observation in question had the value cslsoControlPoint for its Type property. When the LeastSquares object is in this need-to-calculate state, users cannot obtain statistics (such as residual data) or transform points until the situation has been rectified by (in this case) calling the LeastSquares.CalculateTransformation method.
Although it is possible to hold a reference on an Observation object after its deletion, any attempt to usefully access the deleted object results in an error. At that point, release of the reference is the only allowable operation.
member.param: The integer index number for the Observation object to delete.

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.Observations.Delete(System.String)
member.summary: The Delete method removes a specified Observation object from the collection and obliterates its internal data storage.
member.remarks:
If more than one Observation in the collection have been given the same name, the first such Observation found in the collection is the one which is deleted.
Deleting an Observation from the Observations collection causes the owning LeastSquares object to mark itself as needing to recalculate the transformation if the Observation in question had the value cslsoControlPoint for its Type property. When the LeastSquares object is in this need-to-calculate state, users cannot obtain statistics (such as residual data) or transform points until the situation has been rectified by (in this case) calling the LeastSquares.CalculateTransformation method.
Although it is possible to hold a reference on an Observation object after its deletion, any attempt to usefully access the deleted object results in an error. At that point, release of the reference is the only allowable operation.
member.param: The name string for the Observation object to delete.

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.Observations.DeleteAll
member.summary: The DeleteAll method removes all objects from the collection and obliterates any internal data storage formerly used by those objects.
member.remarks:
Deleting all Observation objects from the Observations collection causes the owning LeastSquares object to mark itself as needing to recalculate the transformation. When the LeastSquares object is in this need-to-calculate state, users cannot obtain statistics (such as residual data) or transform points until the situation has been rectified. In the case of deleting all Observation objects, a new, valid set of Observations must be populated and the LeastSquares.CalculateTransformation method must then be called.
Although it is possible to hold a reference on an Observation object after its deletion, any attempt to usefully access the deleted object results in an error. At that point, release of the reference is the only allowable operation.
Calling DeleteAll on a collection which already has a Count of zero produces no error and does nothing.

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.Observations.GetEnumerator
member.summary: Returns a type-safe enumerator for the collection.
member.returns: Collection type-safe enumerator

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.Observations.System#Collections#IEnumerable#GetEnumerator
member.summary: Returns an enumerator for the collection.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.Observations.CheckPointCount
member.summary: The CheckPointCount property returns the count of Observation objects in the collection which are check points.
member.remarks:
An Observation object is a check point if its Type property has the value cslsoCheckPoint.
Check points are not used by the owning LeastSquares object to calculate the transformation. They exist in order to validate the transformation using their statistics, such as residuals.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.Observations.ControlPointCount
member.summary: The ControlPointCount property returns the count of Observation objects in the collection which are control points.
member.remarks:
An Observation object is a control point if its Type property has the value cslsoControlPoint.
Control points are used by the owning LeastSquares object to calculate the transformation.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.Observations.Count
member.summary: Count returns the number of Observation objects in the collection.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.Observations.Item(System.Int32)
member.summary: The Item method returns the Observation object specified by the index within the Observations collection.
member.remarks:
Numeric indexes in the Observations collection begin with the value 0.
Indexing the collection with an invalid index produces an IndexOutOfRangeException.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.Observations.Item(System.String)
member.summary: The Item method returns the Observation object specified by the index within the Observations collection.
member.remarks:
If more than one Observation in the collection have been given the same name, the first such Observation found in the collection is the one which is returned.
Indexing the collection with a non-existent name produces an IndexOutOfRangeException.

member.name: T:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.MultipleRegression
member.summary:
The MultipleRegression object defines parameters for the Multiple Regression datum transformation model. The Multiple Regression model is used to convert data between a local datum and the WGS84 geodetic datum. This model can also be used to convert data (approximately) between a local datum and the North American 1983 geodetic datum.
This object contains a snapshot of the names of all the projection algorithms supported at the time of its creation.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.MultipleRegression.ModelTypeStr
member.summary:
The ModelTypeStr property sets the multiple regression model used by the MultipleRegression object by specifying a character string from a standard list of model character string names. This multiple regression model defines a set of predefined coefficients in a polynomial transformation between geodetic coordinates on a given local datum and geodetic coordinates on WGS84 datum. This property also returns the character string for the currently assigned multiple regression model.
If the ModelTypeStr property is used to set the multiple regression model, the string assigned to this property must be an alphanumeric character string that matches one of those within the MultRegressionModelTypeStrings collection.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.MultipleRegression.ModelTypeVal
member.summary: The ModelTypeVal property sets the multiple regression model used by the MultipleRegression object by assigning a predefined model constant to the property. This multiple regression model defines a set of predefined coefficients in a polynomial transformation between geodetic coordinates on a given local datum and geodetic coordinates on WGS84 datum. This property also returns the constant value for the currently assigned multiple regression model.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.MultipleRegression.MultRegressionModelTypeStrings
member.summary: The MultRegressionModelTypeStrings property returns a string collection that enumerates the list of available multiple regression model names.

member.name: T:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPoint
member.summary:
Intergraph G/Technology GTPoint Object.
Usage note: In the older COM-based API for G/Technology, some methods and properties that returned a GTPoint could return an object that implicitly referenced another object, such as a geometry object. Modifying the coordinates of that GTPoint object would therefore implicitly modify the referenced geometry.
This GTPoint class never behaves in that fashion. Whenever a GTPoint object is retrieved from another object, the returned GTPoint is always a copy of the information from the source object.

member.summary: Creates a point with the given coordinates.

member.summary: A GTPoint equals another GTPoint if they contain the same coordinates.
member.returns: Boolean

member.summary:
A GTPoint equals another GTPoint if they contain the same coordinates.
, which compares points based on a positional tolerance. The == and != operators, as well as the Equals method, compare the coordinate values for exact equality.
member.returns: Boolean

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPoint.ProjectTo(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTSegment)
member.summary: The ProjectTo function projects this point on to a given line segment.
member.remarks: The return is the perpendicular projection of the point onto the segment. If the projection is not on the segment, and the segment's IsExtended property is false, then the point returned is the nearest end point (with Type property equal to GTSegmentPointType.gtsptOnEndpoint). If the projection is not on the segment, and the segment's IsExtended property is true, then the point returned is the perpendicular projection of the point onto the extended segment (with Type property equal to GTSegmentPointType.gtsptOnExtendedSegment). If the projected point is on the segment, the Type property of the return value will be GTSegmentPointType.gtsptOnSegment.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPoint.IsContainedBy(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPoints)
member.summary: The IsContainedBy function determines whether a point is inside a polygon.
member.remarks: Returns gtiptOutside if the point is outside the polygon, gtiptOnPolygon if on the polygon, and gtiptInside if it is in the polygon.
member.param: The vertices of the polygon to be tested.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPoint.IsOn(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTSegment)
member.summary: Determines if a point is on the segment. If the segment's IsExtended property is true, this function raises an exception.
member.returns: Boolean

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPoint.ProjectAtAngle(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTSegment,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPoint,System.Double)
member.summary: Returns a projected point by deriving the lines that pass through the anchor point at the specified angle increment from the original line segment and then projecting the reference point onto the closest derived line.
member.remarks:
Uses positional tolerance.
The angle increment must be greater than 0 and less than or equal to 180 degrees.
The extendability of the input segment is ignored.
member.param: The point through which the reference lines pass.
The angle in degrees between the reference lines and the input segment.
The original line segment.

member.name: T:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.ProjSpace
member.summary:
The ProjSpace object specifies and retrieves the projection algorithm used to define the projection reference space within the RefSpaceMgr object. This object also allows modification of the projection algorithm parameter settings.
The ProjSpace properties either set or return the active projection algorithm or set or return parameter values for the active projection algorithm. The projection algorithm is specified with the ProjAlgorithmVal or ProjAlgorithmStr property. Most of the remaining properties set or return algorithm parameter values.
The applicable properties vary for each projection algorithm. If a parameter is applicable to a projection algorithm, its corresponding properties (usually a numeric value and a string property) are preloaded to preset values when the projection algorithm is set. The values can be returned through the applicable properties.
Setting a property varies depending on the active projection algorithm as follows:
The property accepts any value that is valid for the data type.
The property accepts a value within limits (such as setting the azimuth angle between 90 and -90 degrees).
The property changes or is changed by changes to other property values (such as the scale reduction factor changing the latitude of origin).
The property does not accept changes and, thus, retains its preset value.
If a property is valid and accepts changes, the modified values remain until a new projection algorithm is assigned or the current projection algorithm is reassigned.
If the property is invalid, an error is returned when the property is referenced.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.ProjSpace.AzimuthAng
member.summary:
The AzimuthAng property uses a double precision value in radians to set or get the azimuth angle projection parameter. The value is always measured positive clockwise from north.
The AzimuthAng property applies to certain oblique projection algorithms where it defines the azimuth of the central line of the projection and to the Local Space Rectangular (LSR) projection where it defines the azimuth of the projection's X-axis. Referencing or attempting to set this property for non-applicable projection algorithms results in an error. For the Laborde, Oblique Mercator, and preset Switzerland LV projection algorithms the azimuth is defined at the map center. For the Rectified Skew Orthomorphic projection algorithm the azimuth is defined at the skew origin. For the Local Space Rectangular projection algorithm the azimuth is defined at the projection origin.
member.remarks:
Depending on the currently assigned projection algorithm, changing the AzimuthAng property value may change additional property values.
For the Local Space Rectangular and Oblique Mercator projection algorithms the AzimuthAng property is read-write when the value of the AzimuthDefinitionMode property is csadmDirect and is read-only when the value of the AzimuthDefinitionMode property is csadmByTwoPoints.
For both Switzerland LV projection algorithms the AzimuthAng property is preset to the radian equivalent of 90 degrees and is read-only.
For each of the two State Plane Coordinate System projections this property is available in the single case of the Alaska 1 zone, where the underlying projection algorithm is Oblique Mercator, the azimuth is defined at the map center, and the property is read-only.
The ProjAlgorithmVal or ProjAlgorithmStr property automatically sets the AzimuthAng property to a predefined value when the algorithm is set to a value for which azimuth angle is a valid parameter. Therefore, resetting either of these properties after changing the AzimuthAng property value resets the property to its predefined value.
Note: Some projection algorithms may not accept a change in the property value (the value is preset). In this case, the property ignores the newly assigned value and retains the preset value.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.ProjSpace.AzimuthDefinitionMode
member.summary:
The AzimuthDefinitionMode property uses a constant value to set or get the azimuth definition mode projection parameter. The parameter specifies how the azimuth of the central line is defined for oblique projection algorithms or how the azimuth of the X-axis is defined for the Local Space Rectangular projection algorithm.
The AzimuthDefinitionMode property is applicable to only those projection algorithms for which the AzimuthAng property is applicable. Referencing or attempting to set this property for non-applicable projection algorithms results in an error.
member.remarks:
Depending on the currently assigned projection algorithm, changing the AzimuthDefinitionMode property value may change additional property values.
For the Local Space Rectangular and Oblique Mercator projection algorithms the AzimuthDefinitionMode property is read-write and the valid values are csadmDirect and csadmByTwoPoints.
For the Laborde, Rectified Skew Orthomorphic, and Switzerland LV projection algorithms the AzimuthDefinitionMode property is preset to csadmDirect and is read-only.
For each of the two State Plane Coordinate System projections this property is available in the single case of the Alaska 1 zone, where the underlying projection algorithm is Oblique Mercator, the azimuth definition mode is csadmDirect, and the property is read-only
The ProjAlgorithmVal or ProjAlgorithmStr property automatically sets the AzimuthDefinitionMode property to a predefined default value when the algorithm is set to a value for which azimuth definition mode is a valid parameter. Therefore, resetting either of these projection algorithm properties after changing the AzimuthDefinitionMode property value resets the AzimuthDefinitionMode property to its predefined default value.
Note: Some projection algorithms may not accept a change in the property value (the value is preset). In this case, the property ignores the newly assigned value and retains the preset value.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.ProjSpace.FalseX
member.summary:
The FalseX property uses a double precision value in meters to set or get the false X projection parameter.
The false X projection parameter specifies the X coordinate value that is assigned to the origin of the projection, with the following exceptions:
For the Oblique Mercator and Rectified Skew Orthomorphic projection algorithms, the false X value applies to the skew origin.
For each of the two State Plane Coordinate System projections in the single case of the Alaska 1 zone, the false X value applies to the skew origin.
Note: Some projection algorithms may not accept a change in the property value (the value is preset). In this case, the property ignores the newly assigned value and retains the preset value.
member.remarks:
The ProjAlgorithmVal or ProjAlgorithmStr property automatically sets the FalseX property to a predefined value. Therefore, resetting either of these properties after changing the FalseX property value resets the property to its predefined value.
The zoned projections set the FalseX property to a value specific to the chosen zone:
Gauss-Kruger
State Plane Coordinate Systems
Universal Polar Stereographic
Universal Transverse Mercator
The following projections also preset the FalseX property:
Bipolar Oblique Conic Conformal
British National Grid
Krovak
New Zealand Map Grid
Switzerland LV
For these zoned and preset projections, the FalseX property is read-only.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.ProjSpace.FalseY
member.summary:
The FalseY property uses a double precision value in meters to set or get the false Y projection parameter.
The false Y projection parameter specifies the Y coordinate value that is assigned to the origin of the projection, with the following exceptions:
For the Oblique Mercator and Rectified Skew Orthomorphic projection algorithms, the false Y value applies to the skew origin.
For each of the two State Plane Coordinate System projections in the single case of the Alaska 1 zone, the false Y value applies to the skew origin.
Note: Some projection algorithms may not accept a change in the property value (the value is preset). In this case, the property ignores the newly assigned value and retains the preset value.
member.remarks:
The ProjAlgorithmVal or ProjAlgorithmStr property automatically sets the FalseY property to a predefined value. Therefore, resetting either of these properties after changing the FalseY property value resets the property to its predefined value.
The zoned projections set the FalseY property to a value specific to the chosen zone:
Gauss-Kruger
State Plane Coordinate Systems
Universal Polar Stereographic
Universal Transverse Mercator
The following projections also preset the FalseY property:
Bipolar Oblique Conic Conformal
British National Grid
Krovak
New Zealand Map Grid
Switzerland LV
For these zoned and preset projections, the FalseY property is read-only.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.ProjSpace.GeomHeightOrigin
member.summary: The GeomHeightOrigin property uses a Double value to set or return the geometric height of origin projection parameter value. This property is always in meters with positive values increasing towards up. It is the height above the ellipsoid of the geographic origin of the projection.
member.remarks:
The GeomHeightOrigin property can be set or referenced only if the currently assigned projection algorithm is Local Space Rectangular (the only projection algorithm for which it is a valid parameter). Referencing or attempting to set the property for non-applicable projection algorithms results in an error.
The ProjAlgorithmVal or ProjAlgorithmStr property automatically sets the GeomHeightOrigin property to a predefined default value , providing that the GeomHeightOrigin property is valid for the algorithm. Therefore, resetting either of these projection algorithm properties after changing the GeomHeightOrigin property value resets the GeomHeightOrigin property to its predefined value.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.ProjSpace.GeomHeightPoint1
member.summary: The GeomHeightPoint1 property uses a Double value to set or return the geometric height of point 1 projection parameter value. This property is always in meters with positive values increasing towards up. It is the geometric height of the first of two points used to define the orientation of the X-axis of the Local Space Rectangular (LSR) projection.
member.remarks:
The GeomHeightPoint1 property can be set or referenced only if the currently assigned projection algorithm is Local Space Rectangular and the azimuth definition mode is csadmByTwoPoints. Referencing or attempting to set the property for non-applicable configurations results in an error.
Changing the GeomHeightPoint1 property value may change additional property values, such as the AzimuthAng property.
The ProjAlgorithmVal or ProjAlgorithmStr property automatically sets the GeomHeightPoint1 property to a predefined default value , providing that the GeomHeightPoint1 property is valid for the algorithm. Therefore, resetting either of these projection algorithm properties after changing the GeomHeightPoint1 property value resets the GeomHeightPoint1 property to its predefined value.
For the Local Space Rectangular projection algorithm changing the azimuth definition mode from csadmDirect to csadmByTwoPoints causes the GeomHeightPoint1 property to be set to the value of the geometric height of origin parameter

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.ProjSpace.GeomHeightPoint2
member.summary: The GeomHeightPoint2 property uses a Double value to set or return the geometric height of point 2 projection parameter value. This property is always in meters with positive values increasing towards up. It is the geometric height of the first of two points used to define the orientation of the X-axis of the Local Space Rectangular (LSR) projection.
member.remarks:
The GeomHeightPoint2 property can be set or referenced only if the currently assigned projection algorithm is Local Space Rectangular and the azimuth definition mode is csadmByTwoPoints. Referencing or attempting to set the property for non-applicable configurations results in an error.
Changing the GeomHeightPoint2 property value may change additional property values, such as the AzimuthAng property.
The ProjAlgorithmVal or ProjAlgorithmStr property automatically sets the GeomHeightPoint2 property to a predefined default value , providing that the GeomHeightPoint2 property is valid for the algorithm. Therefore, resetting either of these projection algorithm properties after changing the GeomHeightPoint2 property value resets the GeomHeightPoint2 property to its predefined value.
For the Local Space Rectangular projection algorithm changing the azimuth definition mode from csadmDirect to csadmByTwoPoints causes the GeomHeightPoint2 property to be set to the value of the geometric height of origin parameter

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.ProjSpace.HemisphereStr
member.summary:
The HemisphereStr property sets the hemisphere used by the projection algorithm to a northern or southern hemisphere. This property uses a character string from a standard list of character string names. The HemisphereStr property also returns the character string for the hemisphere of the currently assigned projection algorithm.
Note: Some projection algorithms may not accept a change in the property value. In this case, the property ignores the newly assigned value and retains the preset value.
member.remarks:
The HemisphereStr property returns a value only if the hemisphere parameter is a valid parameter of the currently assigned projection algorithm. Referencing this property for non-applicable projection algorithms results in an error.
The HemisphereStr property can be set only if the hemisphere parameter is a valid parameter of the currently assigned projection algorithm. Otherwise, the property retains its predefined value and the property returns an error. This property accepts only one of the preset character strings, "Northern" or "Southern".
Changing the HemisphereStr property value automatically changes the HemisphereVal property value. Depending on the currently assigned projection algorithm, changing the HemisphereStr property value may change additional property values.
The ProjAlgorithmVal or ProjAlgorithmStr property automatically sets the HemisphereStr property to a predefined value providing that it is valid for the algorithm. Therefore, resetting either of these properties after changing the HemisphereStr property value resets the property to its predefined value.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.ProjSpace.HemisphereVal
member.summary:
The HemisphereVal property sets the hemisphere projection parameter. This property also returns the Long value corresponding to the currently assigned hemisphere constant.
Note: Some projection algorithms may not accept a change in the property value. In this case, the property ignores the newly assigned value and retains the preset value.
member.remarks:
The HemisphereVal property returns a value only if the hemisphere parameter is a valid parameter of the currently assigned projection algorithm. Referencing this property for non-applicable projection algorithms results in an error.
The HemisphereVal property can be set only if the hemisphere parameter is a valid parameter of the currently assigned projection algorithm. Attempting to set the property for non-applicable projection algorithms results in an error.
If the HemisphereVal property is used to set the hemisphere, a constant is assigned to the property.
The ProjAlgorithmVal or ProjAlgorithmStr property automatically sets the HemisphereVal property to a predefined value, providing that it is valid for the algorithm. Therefore, resetting either of these properties after changing the HemisphereVal property value resets the property to its predefined value.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.ProjSpace.LatOfOrig
member.summary:
The LatOfOrig property uses a Double value to set or return the latitude of origin projection parameter value. This property is always in radians with positive values increasing towards north.
For most projection algorithms this parameter is the latitude of the geographic origin of the projection. These are the exceptions:
For the Oblique Mercator and Rectified Skew Orthomorphic projections this parameter refers to the latitude of the map center. For each of the two State Plane Coordinate System projections in the single case of the Alaska 1 zone this parameter refers to the latitude of the map center. Note: Some projection algorithms may not accept a change in the property value. In this case, the property ignores the newly assigned value and retains the preset value. Valid values accepted by the LatOfOrig property are always in radians and must fall within the range -pi/2 to pi/2 radians. Values outside of this range produce an error. In this case, the property retains its last valid value. Some projection algorithms may restrict the range of acceptable values more than others.
member.remarks:
The LatOfOrig property can only be set or referenced if the latitude of origin parameter is a valid parameter of the currently assigned projection algorithm. Referencing or attempting to set the property for non-applicable projection algorithms results in an error.
Depending on the currently assigned projection algorithm, changing the LatOfOrig property value may change additional property values.
The ProjAlgorithmVal or ProjAlgorithmStrings property automatically sets the LatOfOrig property to a predefined default value , providing that the LatOfOrig property is valid for the algorithm. Therefore, resetting either of these projection algorithm properties after changing the LatOfOrig property value resets the LatOfOrig property to its predefined value.
The following projections preset the LatOfOrig property and do not allow it to be modified directly. For all of these cases the property is read-only.
Bipolar Oblique Conic Conformal
British National Grid
Krovak
New Zealand Map Grid
Switzerland LV
Gauss-Kruger
State Plane Coordinate Systems
Universal Polar Stereographic
Universal Transverse Mercator

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.ProjSpace.LatOfTrueScale
member.summary:
The LatOfTrueScale property uses a Double value to set or return the latitude of true scale projection parameter. This property is always in radians with positive values increasing towards north.
The latitude of true scale parameter is applicable when the projection algorithm is defined as one of the following:
Mercator North Polar Stereographic South Polar Stereographic Universal Polar Stereographic
Note: Some projection algorithms may not accept a change in the property value. In this case, the property ignores the newly assigned value and retains the preset value. Values accepted by the LatOfTrueScale property fall within a preset range. Values outside of this range produce an error. In this case, the property retains its last valid value. The preset range varies depending on the projection algorithm.
Example
The North Polar Stereographic projection algorithm accepts only values within the range of 0 to pi/2 radians. Conversely, the South Polar Stereographic projection algorithm only accepts values within the range of 0 to -pi/2 radians.
member.remarks:
The LatOfTrueScale property can be set or referenced only if the latitude of true scale parameter is a valid parameter of the currently assigned projection algorithm. Referencing or attempting to set the property for non-applicable projection algorithms results in an error.
Depending on the currently assigned projection algorithm, changing the LatOfOrig property value may change additional property values. Often a change in the latitude of true scale will produce a change in the scale reduction factor and vice versa.
The ProjAlgorithmVal or ProjAlgorithmStr property automatically sets the LatOfTrueScale property to a predefined value, providing that it is valid for the algorithm. Therefore, resetting either of these properties after changing the LatOfTrueScale property value resets the property to its predefined value.
The Universal Polar Stereographic projection presets the LatOfTrueScale property, based upon the chosen hemisphere. For this projection, the property is read-only.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.ProjSpace.LatPoint1
member.summary: The LatPoint1 property uses a Double value to set or return the latitude of point 1 projection parameter value. This property is always in radians with positive values increasing towards north.
member.remarks:
The LatPoint1 property can be set or referenced only if the latitude of point 1 parameter is a valid parameter of the currently assigned projection algorithm. Referencing or attempting to set the property for non-applicable projection algorithms results in an error. The latitude of point 1 parameter is applicable when the projection algorithm is defined as Local Space Rectangular (LSR) or Oblique Mercator and the azimuth definition mode is csadmByTwoPoints. For these cases, the LatPoint1 property is read-write. The property is also applicable as read-only when the projection algorithm is defined as Bipolar Oblique Conic Conformal.
For the Local Space Rectangular projection, this parameter is the latitude of the first of two points used to define the orientation of the X-axis.
For the Oblique Mercator projection, this parameter is the latitude of the first of two points used to define the oblique central line.
For the Bipolar Oblique Conic Conformal projection, this parameter is the latitude of pole A, the southwest pole.
Note: Some projection algorithms may not accept a change in the property value. In this case, the property ignores the newly assigned value and retains the preset value. Depending on the currently assigned projection algorithm, changing the LatPoint1 property value may change additional property values, such as the AzimuthAng property.
The ProjAlgorithmVal or ProjAlgorithmStr property automatically sets the LatPoint1 property to a predefined default value , providing that the LatPoint1 property is valid for the algorithm. Therefore, resetting either of these projection algorithm properties after changing the LatPoint1 property value resets the LatPoint1 property to its predefined value.
The Bipolar Oblique Conic Conformal projection presets the LatPoint1 property. For this projection the property is read-only.
For the Local Space Rectangular projection algorithm, changing the azimuth definition mode from csadmDirect to csadmByTwoPoints causes the LatPoint1 property to be set to the latitude of a point on the LSR tangent plane one hundred kilometers away from the origin along the X-axis.
For the Oblique Mercator projection algorithm, changing the azimuth definition mode from csadmDirect to csadmByTwoPoints causes the LatPoint1 property to be set to the latitude of a point one hundred kilometers away from the map center point along the oblique central line in the direction indicated by the defining azimuth.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.ProjSpace.LatPoint2

member.remarks:
The LatPoint2 property can be set or referenced only if the latitude of point 2 parameter is a valid parameter of the currently assigned projection algorithm. Referencing or attempting to set the property for non-applicable projection algorithms results in an error. The latitude of point 2 parameter is applicable when the projection algorithm is defined as Local Space Rectangular (LSR) or Oblique Mercator and the azimuth definition mode is csadmByTwoPoints. For these cases, the LatPoint2 property is read-write. The property is also applicable as read-only when the projection algorithm is defined as Bipolar Oblique Conic Conformal.
For the Local Space Rectangular projection, this parameter is the latitude of the first of two points used to define the orientation of the X-axis.
For the Oblique Mercator projection, this parameter is the latitude of the first of two points used to define the oblique central line.
For the Bipolar Oblique Conic Conformal projection, this parameter is the latitude of pole A, the southwest pole.
Note: Some projection algorithms may not accept a change in the property value. In this case, the property ignores the newly assigned value and retains the preset value. Depending on the currently assigned projection algorithm, changing the LatPoint2 property value may change additional property values, such as the AzimuthAng property.
The ProjAlgorithmVal or ProjAlgorithmStr property automatically sets the LatPoint2 property to a predefined default value , providing that the LatPoint2 property is valid for the algorithm. Therefore, resetting either of these projection algorithm properties after changing the LatPoint2 property value resets the LatPoint2 property to its predefined value.
The Bipolar Oblique Conic Conformal projection presets the LatPoint2 property. For this projection the property is read-only.
For the Local Space Rectangular projection algorithm, changing the azimuth definition mode from csadmDirect to csadmByTwoPoints causes the LatPoint2 property to be set to the latitude of a point on the LSR tangent plane one hundred kilometers away from the origin along the X-axis.
For the Oblique Mercator projection algorithm, changing the azimuth definition mode from csadmDirect to csadmByTwoPoints causes the LatPoint2 property to be set to the latitude of a point one hundred kilometers away from the map center point along the oblique central line in the direction indicated by the defining azimuth.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.ProjSpace.LonOfOrig
member.summary:
The LonOfOrig property uses a Double value to set or return the longitude of origin projection parameter value. This property is always in radians with positive values increasing towards east.
The LonOfOrig property can be set or referenced only if the longitude of origin parameter is a valid parameter of the currently assigned projection algorithm. Referencing or attempting to set the property for non-applicable projection algorithms results in an error.
For most projection algorithms this parameter is the longitude of the geographic origin of the projection. These are the exceptions:
For the Oblique Mercator and Rectified Skew Orthomorphic projections this parameter refers to the longitude of the map center. For each of the two State Plane Coordinate System projections in the single case of the Alaska 1 zone this parameter refers to the longitude of the map center. Note: Some projection algorithms may not accept a change in the property value. In this case, the property ignores the newly assigned value and retains the preset value. Valid values accepted by the LonOfOrig property are always in radians and must fall within the range of 2pi to -2pi radians. Values outside of this range produce an error. In this case, the property retains its last valid value.
The LonOfOrig property normalizes values set between pi and 2pi and betweeen -pi and -2pi to fall within the -pi to pi radian intervals and stores the normalized value.
member.remarks:
The ProjAlgorithmVal or ProjAlgorithmStrings property automatically sets the LonOfOrig property to a predefined default value , providing that the LonOfOrig property is valid for the algorithm. Therefore, resetting either of these projection algorithm properties after changing the LonOfOrig property value resets the LonOfOrig property to its predefined value.
The following projections preset the LonOfOrig property and do not allow it to be modified directly. For all of these cases the property is read-only.
Bipolar Oblique Conic Conformal
British National Grid
Krovak
New Zealand Map Grid
Switzerland LV
Gauss-Kruger
State Plane Coordinate Systems
Universal Polar Stereographic
Universal Transverse Mercator
For the Oblique Mercator projection algorithm, the LonOfOrig property is read-write when the azimuth definition mode is csadmDirect and read-only when the azimuth definition mode is csadmByTwoPoints.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.ProjSpace.LonPoint1
member.summary: The LonPoint1 property uses a Double value to set or return the latitude of point 1 projection parameter value. This property is always in radians with positive values increasing towards east.
member.remarks:
The LonPoint1 property can be set or referenced only if the longitude of point 1 parameter is a valid parameter of the currently assigned projection algorithm. Referencing or attempting to set the property for non-applicable projection algorithms results in an error. The longitude of point 1 parameter is applicable when the projection algorithm is defined as Local Space Rectangular (LSR) or Oblique Mercator and the azimuth definition mode is csadmByTwoPoints. For these cases, the LonPoint1 property is read-write. The property is also applicable as read-only when the projection algorithm is defined as Bipolar Oblique Conic Conformal.
For the Local Space Rectangular projection, this parameter is the longitude of the first of two points used to define the orientation of the X-axis.
For the Oblique Mercator projection, this parameter is the longitude of the first of two points used to define the oblique central line.
For the Bipolar Oblique Conic Conformal projection, this parameter is the longitude of pole A, the southwest pole.
Note: Some projection algorithms may not accept a change in the property value. In this case, the property ignores the newly assigned value and retains the preset value. Valid values accepted by the LonPoint1 property are always in radians and must fall within the range of 2pi to -2pi radians. Values outside of this range produce an error. In this case, the property retains its last valid value.
With one exception, the LonPoint1 property normalizes values set between pi and 2pi and between -pi and -2pi to fall within the -pi to pi radian interval and stores the normalized value. The exception is that no such normalization occurs for the Oblique Mercator projection when the two points used to define the oblique central line span across the 180 degree (pi or -pi) meridian.
Depending on the currently assigned projection algorithm, changing the LonPoint1 property value may change additional property values, such as the AzimuthAng property.
The ProjAlgorithmVal or ProjAlgorithmStr property automatically sets the LonPoint1 property to a predefined default value, providing that the LonPoint1 property is valid for the algorithm. Therefore, resetting either of these projection algorithm properties after changing the LonPoint1 property value resets the LonPoint1 property to its predefined value.
The Bipolar Oblique Conic Conformal projection presets the LonPoint1 property. For this projection the property is read-only.
For the Local Space Rectangular and Oblique Mercator projection algorithms, changing the azimuth definition mode from csadmDirect to csadmByTwoPoints causes the LonPoint1 property to be set to the value of the longitude of origin parameter. This is the longitude of the map center point for Oblique Mercator.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.ProjSpace.ProjAlgorithmStr
member.summary:
The ProjAlgorithmStr property sets the projection algorithm used by the RefSpaceMgr object by specifying a character string from a standard list of projection algorithm string names. The RefSpaceMgr object uses the projection algorithm to transform coordinates between the geographic and projected reference spaces. This property also returns the character string for the currently assigned projection algorithm.
If the ProjAlgorithmStr property is used to set the projection algorithm, the string assigned to this property must be an alphanumeric character string that matches an internal designation. The ProjSpace.ProjAlgorithmStrings returns a collection includes the names of each predefined projection algorithm available for the projection space. This collection's indexer can return the character string for any item in the projection algorithm strings collection.
The ProjAlgorithmStr property and the ProjAlgorithmStrings collection currently do not support internationalization.
Note: The ellipsoid defined in the GeogSpace object along with various projection parameters definied in the ProjSpace are used to transform coordinates between the geographic and projected reference spaces.
member.remarks:
Projection parameter values, such as the latitude of true scale, are assigned predefined values depending on the specified projection algorithm. The parameter values are available through corresponding properties. For example, the first standard parallel is available through the StandPar1 property.
Each projection algorithm uses some but not all the parameters associated with properties for the ProjSpace object. Therefore, a property may be applicable for some projection algorithms but not available for others.
Setting The ProjAlgorithmVal or ProjAlgorithmStr property to a new algorithm or resetting it to the same algorithm automatically resets all properties valid for the specified projection algorithm to their preset values.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.ProjSpace.ProjAlgorithmStrings
member.summary:
The ProjAlgorithmStrings property returns a collection of strings for each predefined projection algorithm available for the projection space.
Note that the returned collection of strings is a copy of the underlying collection. Modifying this collection does not modify the set of available projection algorithms.
member.remarks:
Projection parameter values, such as the latitude of true scale, are assigned predefined values depending on the specified projection algorithm. The parameter values are available through corresponding properties. For example, the first standard parallel is available through the StandPar1 property.
Each projection algorithm uses some but not all the parameters associated with properties for the ProjSpace object. Therefore, a property may be applicable for some projection algorithms but not available for others.
Setting The ProjAlgorithmVal or ProjAlgorithmStr property to a new algorithm or resetting it to the same algorithm automatically resets all properties valid for the specified projection algorithm to their preset values.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.ProjSpace.ProjAlgorithmVal
member.summary:
The ProjAlgorithmVal property sets the projection algorithm used by the RefSpaceMgr object by assigning a predefined projection algorithm constant (defined as a Long) to the property. This property also returns the Long value for the currently assigned projection algorithm constant.
Note: The ellipsoid defined in the GeogSpace object along with various projection parameters definied in the ProjSpace are used to transform coordinates between the geographic and projected reference spaces.
member.remarks:
Projection parameter values such as the latitude of true scale are assigned predefined values depending on the specified projection algorithm. The parameter values are available through corresponding properties. For example, the first standard parallel is available through the StandPar1 property.
Each projection algorithm uses some but not all the parameters associated with properties for the ProjSpace object. Therefore, a property may be applicable for some projection algorithms but not available for others.
Setting the ProjAlgorithmVal or ProjAlgorithmStr property to a new algorithm or resetting it to the same algorithm automatically resets all properties valid for the specified projection algorithm to their preset values.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.ProjSpace.ScaleReductFactStr
member.summary:
The ScaleReductFactStr property uses a formatted numeric string to set or return the scale reduction factor projection parameter. This property is a unitless, positive, non-zero numeric string.
Note: Some projection algorithms may not accept a change in the property value. In this case, the property ignores the newly assigned value and retains the preset value.
member.remarks:
The format of the scale reduction factor string is a unitless decimal value such as 0.99998.
The ScaleReductFactStr property can be set or referenced only if the scale reduction factor parameter is a valid parameter of the currently assigned projection algorithm. Referencing or attempting to set this property for non-applicable projection algorithms results in an error.
Changing the ScaleReductFactStr property value automatically changes the ScaleReductFactVal property value. Depending on the currently assigned projection algorithm, changing the ScaleReductFactStr property value might change additional property values. For algorithms that support the latitude of true scale paramter, a change in scale reduction factor typically produces a change in the latitude of true scale and vice versa.
The ProjAlgorithmVal or ProjAlgorithmStr property automatically sets the ScaleReductFactStr property to a predefined value, providing that it is valid for the algorithm. Therefore, resetting either of these properties after changing the ScaleReductFactStr property value resets the property to its predefined value.
The following projections preset the ScaleReductFactStr property and do not allow it to be modified directly. For all of these cases the property is read-only.
Bipolar Oblique Conic Conformal
British National Grid
Krovak
New Zealand Map Grid
Switzerland LV
Gauss-Kruger
State Plane Coordinate Systems
Universal Polar Stereographic
Universal Transverse Mercator

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.ProjSpace.ScaleReductFactVal
member.summary:
The ScaleReductFactVal property uses a Double value to set or return the scale reduction factor projection parameter. This property is a unitless, positive, non-zero value.
Note: Some projection algorithms may not accept a change in the property value. In this case, the property ignores the newly assigned value and retains the preset value.
member.remarks:

Therefore, resetting either of these properties after changing the ScaleReductFactVal property value resets the property to its predefined value.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.ProjSpace.StandPar1
member.summary:
The StandPar1 property uses a Double value, in radians where positive values increase towards north, to set the first standard parallel projection parameter value. This property also returns the first standard parallel for the current projection algorithm.
Note: Some projection algorithms may not accept a change in the property value. In this case, the property ignores the newly assigned value and retains the preset value. Valid values accepted by the StandPar1 property are always in radians and must fall within the range of -pi/2 to pi/2 radians. Values outside of this range produce an error. In this case, the property retains its last valid value. Some projection algorithms may restrict the range of acceptable values more than others.
member.remarks:
The StandPar1 property can be set or referenced only if the first standard parallel parameter is a valid parameter of the currently assigned projection algorithm. Referencing or attempting to set this property for non-applicable projection algorithms results in an error.
The first standard parallel parameter is applicable when the projection algorithm is defined as one of the following. For these cases the StandPar1 property is read-write.
Albers Equal Area
Cylindrical Equirectangular
Equidistant Conic
Lambert Conformal Conic
The parameter is also applicable as read-only when the projection algorithm is defined as Bipolar Oblique Conic Conformal or when the projection algorithm is defined as either of the State Plane Coordinate Systems and the zone is one of those that uses the Lambert Conformal Conic projection.
For the Bipolar Oblique Conic Conformal projection, the StandPar1 property is the first official standard transformed parallel. For the Cylindrical Equirectangular projection it is the single standard parallel.
The ProjAlgorithmVal or ProjAlgorithmStr property automatically sets the StandPar1 property to a predefined value , providing that it is valid for the algorithm. Therefore, resetting either of these properties after changing the StandPar1 property value resets the property to its predefined value.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.ProjSpace.StandPar2
member.summary:
The StandPar2 property uses a Double value, in radians where positive values increase towards north, to set the second standard parallel projection parameter value. This property also returns the second standard parallel for the current projection algorithm.
Note: Some projection algorithms may not accept a change in the property value. In this case, the property ignores the newly assigned value and retains the preset value. Valid values accepted by the StandPar2 property are always in radians and must fall within the range of -pi/2 to pi/2 radians. Values outside of this range produce an error. In this case, the property retains its last valid value. Some projection algorithms may restrict the range of acceptable values more than others.
member.remarks:
The StandPar2 property can be set or referenced only if the second standard parallel parameter is a valid parameter of the currently assigned projection algorithm. Referencing or attempting to set this property for non-applicable projection algorithms results in an error.
The second standard parallel parameter is applicable when the projection algorithm is defined as one of the following. For these cases the StandPar2 property is read-write.
Albers Equal Area
Cylindrical Equirectangular
Equidistant Conic
Lambert Conformal Conic
The parameter is also applicable as read-only when the projection algorithm is defined as Bipolar Oblique Conic Conformal or when the projection algorithm is defined as either of the State Plane Coordinate Systems and the zone is one of those that uses the Lambert Conformal Conic projection.
For the Bipolar Oblique Conic Conformal projection, the StandPar2 property is the second official standard transformed parallel.
The ProjAlgorithmVal or ProjAlgorithmStr property automatically sets the StandPar2 property to a predefined value , providing that it is valid for the algorithm. Therefore, resetting either of these properties after changing the StandPar2 property value resets the property to its predefined value.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.ProjSpace.ZoneStr
member.summary:
The ZoneStr property sets the zone projection parameter using a formatted string. This property also returns the character string for the zone of the currently assigned projection algorithm.
Note: Some projection algorithms may not accept a change in the property value. In this case, the property ignores the newly assigned value and retains the preset value.
member.remarks:
The ZoneStr property can be set or referenced only if the zone parameter is a valid parameter of the currently assigned projection algorithm. Referencing or attempting to set this property for non-applicable projection algorithms results in an error. The zone parameter is applicable when the projection algorithm is defined as one of the following:
Gauss-Kruger
State Plane Coordinate System 1927
State Plane Coordinate System 1983
Universal Transverse Mercator
Almost all projection algorithms for which the zone parameter is a valid parameter, accept non-decimal positive numeric strings. The exceptions are the State Plane 1927 and State Plane 1983 projection algorithms. These zone strings have non-numeric zone names such as "Alabama East".
Changing the ZoneStr property value automatically changes the ZoneVal property value. Depending on the currently assigned projection algorithm, changing the ZoneStr property value may change additional property values.
The ProjAlgorithmVal or ProjAlgorithmStr property automatically sets the ZoneVal property to a predefined value , providing that it is valid for the algorithm. Therefore, resetting either of these properties after changing the ZoneVal property value resets the property to its predefined value.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.ProjSpace.ZoneVal
member.summary:
The ZoneVal property sets or returns the zone projection parameter using a unitless Long value.
Note: Some projection algorithms may not accept a change in the property value. In this case, the property ignores the newly assigned value and retains the preset value.
member.remarks:
The ZoneVal property can be set or referenced only if the zone parameter is a valid parameter of the currently assigned projection algorithm. Referencing or attempting to set this property for non-applicable projection algorithms results in an error. The zone parameter is applicable when the projection algorithm is defined as one of the following:
Gauss-Kruger
State Plane Coordinate System 1927
State Plane Coordinate System 1983
Universal Transverse Mercator
Changing the ZoneVal property value automatically changes the ZoneStr property value. Depending on the currently assigned projection algorithm, changing the ZoneVal property value may change additional property values.
The ProjAlgorithmVal or ProjAlgorithmStr property automatically sets the ZoneVal property to a predefined value, providing that it is valid for the algorithm. Therefore, resetting either of these properties after changing the ZoneVal property value resets the property to its predefined value.
The valid range of zone numbers for Gauss-Kruger is 0 through 5.
The valid range for Universal Transverse Mercator is 1 through 60.
The valid values for the State Plane Coordinate Systems are well-known and published by the U.S. National Geodetic Survey.

member.summary: Method to set the print properties before printing a plot.
member.remarks:
The plot server retrieves the value of the PrinterName property before calling this method, and requests the set of supported paper sizes from that printer. If a paper size is specified in the plot request, that size will be stored in GTPrintProperties. Otherwise, the plot server determines the paper size supported by the printer that matches, within ISO-specified tolerances, the plot sheet size of the plot. That paper size will be stored in the GTPrintProperties object passed to PlotPrepared. If no paper size matches the plot sheet size, the printer's default paper size will be used.
The custom object can alter the values of any properties of the GTPrintProperties object, including the paper size; and those new values will be used in generating the plot. However, changing the paper size does not affect the plot-sheet size; it affects only the size of paper upon which the plot is printed. Custom plot objects may want to "best fit" the printer's paper sizes to the plot sheet, for example.
member.param: On input, this object contains the printer paper size specified in the plot request or determined by the plot server. The Orientation is set according to the dimensions of the plot sheet relative to the chosen paper size. The Copies property is set according to the plot request parameters.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTCustomPlot.Arguments
member.summary: Property to return/set the arguments specified by the remote plot request for the GTCustomPlot.
member.remarks: This property is set immediately after the IGTCustomPlot Interface is created and before any methods are called.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTCustomPlot.DataContext
member.summary: Property to return/set the GTDataContext object on the GTCustomPlot object.
member.remarks: This property grants the custom plot object access to the database and published metadata. This will be the GTDataContext for the connection that was specified when the plot was created. This GTDataContext could be used, for example, to access the styles used by redline elements in the GTNamedPlot object.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTCustomPlot.PlotWindow
member.summary: Property to return/set the GTPlotWindow for the plot to be produced.
member.remarks: From this object, the IGTCustomPlot Interface can retrieve the NamedPlot property to access the plot object. Access to the plot window also allows the IGTCustomPlot Interface to insert new maps or embedded objects. This property is set immediately after the IGTCustomPlot Interface is created and before any methods are called.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTCustomPlot.PrinterName
member.summary: Property to return/set the name of the output device specified in the plot request.
member.remarks:
This property is set immediately after the IGTCustomPlot Interface is created and before any methods are called.
If the custom plot object wants to alter the output destination, it should return that destination as the value of this property.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTFunctional.Validate(System.String[]@,System.String[]@)
member.summary: Method called when a feature is validated.
member.remarks:
There is a one-to-one correspondence between the error priorities in the ErrorPriorityArray and the error messages in the ErrorMessageArray.
You should include logic in the Validate method to ensure that post fails based on any business rules you are implementing with the Functional interface.
The software allows some validation errors to be accepted when posting the data. See the validation processing description for more details and specifically the discussion of the error filtering parameters to determine the proper value to specify for your workflow.
member.param: Returns the priority of any errors that were detected while validating. This array is expected to be string data. The format of the error priority should be consistent with the values used by the product software and other custom interfaces. By default, these take the form of P1, P2, P3, and P4.
Returns the actual error messages detected while validating.

member.name: T:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTPostBreakLinear
member.summary: The Intergraph G/Technology IGTPostBreakLinear Interface is leveraged by objects called from BreakLinearService, and is used primarily as a cleanup point during break.
member.remarks: At the point that Post Break Linear objects are called, the break has been completed, all components have been destined and graphically adjusted, and all relationships have been reassigned appropriately. This step follows the bulk of break work and precedes the establishing of relationships between a breaking feature and the two features resulting from the break. Since this step follows all break geometry work, it is a logical place to do any work that would require the actual updated geometries for purpose of attribution updates.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTPlacementTechnique.MouseClick(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTMapWindow,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPoint,System.Int32,System.Int32,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTDDCKeyObjects,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPlacementTechniqueEventMode)
member.summary: Method called when a MouseClick event is received on the input GTMapWindow.
member.remarks:
The IGTPlacementTechnique does not receive any mouse events while either construction aids or common adjustments are running.
The IGTPlacementTechnique does not receive any mouse events while either construction aids or common adjustments are running.
This method is called only for clicks made with the left mouse button. ShiftState may be any value except ALT. An ALT+left-button click is interpreted as a double click and will be sent to the MouseDblClick method instead.
The GTPlacementTechniqueEventMode's RelationshipProcessingEnabled property allows the IGTPlacementTechnique to disable relationship establishment at the location of the mouse click. This is needed when the mouse click locates an existing feature.
If the actual point used for geometry construction differs from the original UserPoint input parameter, then UserPoint should be updated to reflect that value. This is particularly important for processing relationships at the proper locations.
member.param: The window in which the mouse click occurred
The location of the mouse click on the screen, in world coordinates
Denotes which mouse button was depressed when the click occurred
Denotes if the SHIFT, ALT, or CTRL keys were also depressed. Some, all, or none of these keys may be depressed at the time the mouse click occurred.
A collection of existing components that are within tolerance (as specified by the SmartLocatePixelTolerance preference set value) to the location of the mouse click
Allows the IGTPlacementTechnique to communicate to the placement software how the MouseClick event was processed. This determines how the placement software will post process this event.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTPlacementTechnique.MouseDblClick(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTMapWindow,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPoint,System.Int32,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTDDCKeyObjects)
member.summary: Method called when a MouseDblClick event is received on the input GTMapWindow.
member.remarks:
Mouse double click events normally signal that the user has finished digitizing this component. In addition to left double clicks, this method will also be called for ALT+left-button clicks.
ShiftState may be any value. The IGTPlacementTechnique does not receive any mouse events while either construction aids or common adjustments are running.
If the actual point used for geometry construction differs from the original UserPoint input parameter, then UserPoint should be updated to reflect that value. This is particularly important for processing relationships at the proper locations.
member.param: The window in which the double click occurred
The location of the double click on the screen, in world coordinates
Denotes if the SHIFT, ALT, or CTRL keys were also depressed. Some, all, or none of these keys may be depressed at the time the double click occurred.
A collection of existing components that are within tolerance (as specified by the SmartLocatePixelTolerance preference set value) to the location of the double click

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTPlacementTechnique.MouseMove(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTMapWindow,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPoint,System.Int32,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTDDCKeyObjects,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPlacementTechniqueEventMode)
member.summary: Method called when a MouseMove event is received on the input GTMapWindow.
member.remarks:
The MouseMove method processes mouse moves that draw dynamically from the last point appended to the current mouse location. This method is called for all mouse moves.
ShiftState may be any value. The IGTPlacementTechnique does not receive any mouse events while either construction aids or common adjustments are running.
If the IGTPlacementTechnique is displaying its own status bar messages, it should check the contents of the status bar to avoid message flicker and refresh the message displayed there if different than expected. This lets the technique's messages be restored if the placement command has been interrupted by another command that also writes to the status bar.
The GTPlacementTechniqueEventMode's RelationshipProcessingEnabled property allows the IGTPlacementTechnique to disable relationship candidates from highlighting during mouse moves. This is useful if the IGTPlacementTechnique is also highlighting graphics on mouse move.
If the actual point used for geometry construction differs from the original UserPoint input parameter, then UserPoint should be updated to reflect that value. This is particularly important for processing relationships at the proper locations.
member.param: The window in which the mouse move occurred
The location of the mouse on the screen, in world coordinates
Denotes if the SHIFT, ALT, or CTRL keys were also depressed. Some, all, or none of these keys may be depressed at the time the mouse move occurred.

A collection of existing components that are within tolerance (as specified by the SmartLocatePixelTolerance preference set value) to the location of the mouse. This collection will be Null if a locate was not performed or if the contents of the collection have not changed from the last mouse move. If it is Null, the IGTPlacementTechnique should not make any changes to HighlightedObjects, such as Clear/Add/Remove. This is to avoid highlight flicker.
Allows the IGTPlacementTechnique to communicate to the placement software how the MouseMove event was processed. This determines how the placement software will post process this event.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTPlacementTechnique.KeyUp(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTMapWindow,System.Int32,System.Int32,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPlacementTechniqueEventMode)
member.summary: Method called when a KeyUp event is received on the input GTMapWindow.
member.remarks:
The KeyUp method processes keyup events such as F1, which normally brings up help, and BACKSPACE, which normally removes points from the geometry. This method is called for all keyup events except when ESC, SHIFT+ESC, or F3 are pressed, as these have special meaning to the placement and edit commands.
The GTPlacementTechniqueEventMode's RelationshipProcessingEnabled property allows the IGTPlacementTechnique to disable deletion of relationships on backspace events. This is useful if the IGTPlacementTechnique disabled relationship processing on mouse click. Disabling relationships on mouse click and key up events should be done in combination to keep relationship processing synchronized.
The IGTPlacementTechnique does not receive any mouse events while either construction aids or common adjustments are running.
member.param: The window in which the keyup occurred
The key that was pressed
Denotes if either the SHIFT, ALT, or CTRL key was also depressed. Some, all, or none of these keys may be depressed at the time the mouse move occurred.
Allows the IGTPlacementTechnique to communicate to the placement software how the KeyUp event was processed. This determines how the placement software will post process this event.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTPlacementTechnique.AbortPlacement
member.summary: Method called to terminate the placement technique when the user presses ESC, etc.
member.remarks:
The following actions will result in the AbortPlacement method being called on the IGTPlacementTechnique:
If the user hits ESC while a component is being digitized.
If the user hits SHIFT+ESC or F3 while a component is being digitized.
If the user selects a different feature or configuration to place while a component is being digitized.
If the user selects a different component to place while digitizing some other component.
If the user clicks the Cancel Edits button on Feature Explorer while a component is being digitized.
If the user clicks the Restart with Job Defaults on Feature Explorer while a component is being digitized.
If the user closes the last open map window while a component is being digitized.
The AbortPlacement method terminates the technique by aborting it and discarding all work it has done. If the IGTPlacementTechnique needs to cancel placement apart from actions listed above, then it should explicitly call GTPlacementTechniqueHelper.AbortPlacement. This cancels the placement of the component and continues as though the user has pressed SHIFT+ESC.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTPlacementTechnique.GraphicComponent
member.summary: Property to return/set the graphic component that is being placed. It is added to the GraphicComponents collection after digitization is complete.
member.remarks:
The GraphicComponent property contains information about the component currently being drawn, including metadata settings and dynamic display information.
This is true for feature placement as well as for feature edit scenarios. For the edit scenarios, all graphic components that exist for the selected feature at the time the edit was invoked will be included in this collection.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTPlacementTechnique.GraphicComponents
member.summary: Property to return/set the collection of graphic components already placed (or that already exist in an Edit case).
member.remarks: The GraphicComponents property contains key information about all the components that have already been digitized for the current feature or configuration instance, including metadata settings and dynamic display information.

member.name: T:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTMergeFeatures
member.summary: The Intergraph G/Technology IGTMergeFeatures Interface is used to customize the behavior of the Merge Features command.
member.remarks:
The IGTMergeFeatures Interface is called at four places in the processing of the Merge Feature command:
Before any user interaction, to indicate if two features are suitable to be merged.
To perform a custom merge of components.
After the geometries and attributes have been merged, to indicate if the merged features are acceptable.
To execute any post processing.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTMergeFeatures.Allow(System.String[]@)
member.summary: Method called to give the interface an opportunity to stop the merge if it determines, based on the not yet merged geometries and attributes, that the two features should not be merged.
member.remarks:
The ErrorMessageArray parameter is an array of strings. The method should allocate the array, populate it, and assign it to the ErrorMessageArray if any errors are found.
When this call is made, Feature1 and Feature2 contain the data of the features as they are stored in the database. The Allow method should catch as many errors as possible because it is called before any user interaction starts.
If any of the IGTMergeFeatures interfaces returns False from this method, the Merge Features command displays the error messages and terminates.
member.param: Returns the actual error messages that were detected by the interface.
member.returns: The Allow Method returns a Boolean value that indicates if the Merge Features command can continue.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTMergeFeatures.Approve(System.String[]@)
member.summary: Method called to give the interface an opportunity to stop the merge if it determines, based on the merged geometries and attributes, that the two features should not be merged.
member.remarks:
The ErrorMessageArray parameter is an array of strings. The method should allocate the array, populate it, and assign it to the ErrorMessageArray if any errors are found.
When this call is made, Feature1 already contains the data that the Merge Features command intends to write to the database. Only the relationship components and attributes are not yet updated.
The Approve method should catch the errors that are consequences of how the user decides to merge the geometries. If any of the IGTMergeFeatures interfaces returns False from this method, the Merge Features command displays the error messages, rolls back the transaction, and terminates.
member.param: Returns the actual error messages that were detected by the interface.
member.returns: The Approve Method returns a Boolean that indicates if the Merge Features command can continue.

members.member:
Method called to give the interface an opportunity to do post processing of component instances based on how other component instances were merged. It is not supposed to merge any components. /// The PostProcess method is called so that the interface can execute any post processing necessary.
This method should do post processing of component instances based on how other component instances have been merged. It should not merge any components. PostProcess may be used, for example, to rearrange the labels based on how the primary geometries have been merged.
If PostProcess manages to do all its processing, it should return True. If PostProcess fails to do all its processing, it should display an error message and return False. If False is returned, the Merge Features command rolls back the transaction and terminates. Such failure should be very rare. IGTMergeFeatures should catch data errors in Approve; so PostProcess should be called only with clean data.

member.remarks: The DataContext property grants the IGTMergeFeatures interface access to the database and to published metadata.
