member.name: T:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTRelationshipGeometry
member.summary: The Intergraph G/Technology IGTRelationshipGeometry Interface enforces stricter geometry rules for establishing or reestablishing the relationships and/or performing geometry manipulations to features related to a feature that is being edited.
member.remarks: Relationship Geometry interface objects are called from the Many-To-Many Ownership, Node-Edge Connectivity, Ownership, and Node-Ordered Connectivity relationships at various times during placement, edit, and validate workflows.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTRelationshipGeometry.AdjustGeometry(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTGeometry)
member.summary: Method called to perform geometry adjustments on the active or related features when the conditions influencing the relationship change.
member.remarks:
The method returns True if it considers all the current relationships to be valid. Otherwise, it returns False. This tells the relationship service to evaluate the existing relationships—drop if not valid and try to establish the new relationships.
The CNO and CID of the updated component instance of the active feature can be retrieved from the CNO and CID properties of the GTKeyObject of the ActiveFeature property. AdjustGeometry should be prepared to handle the case when the CNO and CID are 0 because the relationship software does not always receive these values from the calling commands.
member.param: The geometry of the component instance defined by CNO and CID properties of ActiveFeature before the change.
member.returns: Boolean

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTRelationshipGeometry.AfterDelete
member.summary: Method called after the relationship is deleted. It performs any post-processing on the active or previously related feature.
member.remarks:
For each call to the BeforeDelete method, there should be an immediate call to AfterDelete because no other method of this RGI can be called between BeforeDelete and AfterDelete for the same related feature. If a feature pair has multiple RGIs configured, all of the before methods are called and the delete is performed, and then all of the after methods are called.
The BeforeDelete method receives as an argument the GTKeyObject for the feature for which the relationship is being deleted. BeforeDelete should cache this reference if needed in AfterDelete.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTRelationshipGeometry.AfterEstablish
member.summary: Method called after the relationship is established. It performs any post-processing on the active or previously related feature.
member.remarks:
For each call to the BeforeEstablish method, there should be an immediate call to AfterEstablish because no other method of this RGI can be called between BeforeEstablish and AfterEstablish for the same related feature. If a feature pair has multiple RGIs configured, all of the before methods are called and the delete is performed, and then all of the after methods are called.
The BeforeEstablish method receives as an argument the GTKeyObject for the feature for which the relationship is being established. BeforeEstablish should cache this reference if needed in AfterEstablish.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTRelationshipGeometry.AfterUpdate
member.summary: Method called after the relationship is saved to the database.
member.remarks: This method is called as the last method within any command workflow that involves relationship processing. RGI should call Reestablish on the related features it has modified.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTRelationshipGeometry.BeforeDelete(Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.GTRelationshipGeometryDeleteActionConstants,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTKeyObject)
member.summary: Method called to indicate that the relationship to the RelatedFeature is about to be deleted.
member.remarks:
The CNO of the triggering component on the active feature and CID of the component instance for which relationship is deleted can be retrieved from the CNO and CID properties of the GTKeyObject of the ActiveFeature property.
This method should be prepared to handle the case when the CNO are CID are 0 because the relationship software does not always receive these values from the calling commands.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTRelationshipGeometry.BeforeEstablish(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTKeyObject,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Method called to indicate that a relationship to the EstablishToFeature is about to be established.
member.remarks:
After updating the relationship attributes or component for the EstablishToFeature parameter, a call to the AfterEstablish method is made.
If multiple RGIs are running within the context of the same relationship service, first BeforeEstablish is called on all RGIs, then the relationship is established, and then AfterEstablish is called on all RGIs.
The CNO of the triggering component on the active feature and CID of the component instance establishing the relationship can be retrieved from the CNO and CID properties of the GTKeyObject of the ActiveFeature property. BeforeEstablish should be prepared to handle the case when the CNO are CID are 0 because the relationship software does not always receive these values from the calling commands.
member.param: GTKeyObject of the feature to which the relationship is established.
True if a relationship is established as part of preparing for break, that is, a break is not yet in progress.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTRelationshipGeometry.BeforeUpdate
member.summary: Method called before the relationship is saved to the database.
member.remarks: This method is paired with AfterUpdate, which is called after all the relationship information has been written to the database.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTRelationshipGeometry.Initialize
member.summary: Method called to give the interface an opportunity to initialize itself. It is called before any other method is called.
member.remarks:
The Initialize method does one-time initialization of the object. All properties have to be set before calling this method.
RGI is associated with source FNO, source CNO, related FNO and related CNO in G3E_RELATIONSHIPGEOMETRY. RGI can always retrieve source FNO from ActiveFeature.FNO. It can always get related FNO and related CNO from its RelatedFNO and Related CNO properties. At the time when Initialize is called, ActiveFeature.CNO will be set to the source CNO.
Initialize should retrieve all metadata it needs for further processing. It should also check the context in which it is running.
Example
If an RGI expects to be called only from many-to-many ownership and it is called from Node-Edge Connectivity, it should display a message box stating that it is not supposed to be called from NEC and set a member variable such as m_bDoNothig indicating that calls to other methods should return immediately

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTRelationshipGeometry.Validate(System.String[]@,System.String[]@)
member.summary: Method called to validate the relationship.
member.remarks: Validate is called during post operations.
member.param: Returns the priority of any errors that were detected while validating
Returns the actual error messages detected while validating

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTRelationshipGeometry.AllowDelete(Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.GTRelationshipGeometryDeleteActionConstants,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTKeyObject)
member.summary: Method called to give the interface an opportunity to stop the relationship to RelatedFeature from being deleted. Return True (-1) to allow the delete or False (0) to prevent it.
member.returns: Boolean

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTRelationshipGeometry.FilterCandidates(System.Boolean,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTKeyObjects)
member.summary: Method called to give the interface an opportunity to remove all relationship candidates from the Candidates collection that do not comply with the interface's stricter criteria.
member.remarks:
The relationship software calls the FilterCandidates method when:
Scrutinizing existing relationships, such as after merge.
New relationship candidates have been retrieved using a method other than locating objects, as when a GTDDCKeyObjects collection with located objects is not available and therefore FilterLocatedCandidates cannot be called.
The RGI should remove from the Candidates collection all relationship candidates that do not comply with the stricter RGI's criteria. The Candidates collection may contain multiple FNOs. The FilterCandidates method must keep in the collection all those FNO/CNO combinations that are different from the RelatedFNO/RelatedCNO combination. Only those with the same FNO and CNO can be removed.
If existing relationships are scrutinized, the CNO and CID properties of the GTKeyObject of the ActiveFeature property are not set. So, this method must examine all possible combinations of triggering components to determine if the relationship is still valid.
If new relationship candidates are examined, the CNO and CID properties of the GTKeyObject of the ActiveFeature property will be set.
member.param: True if EstablishToFeature is a linear feature that the relationship service is considering breaking using the active feature.
GTKeyObjects collection with the relationship candidates

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTRelationshipGeometry.FilterLocatedCandidates(System.Boolean,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTDDCKeyObjects)
member.summary: Method called during mouse move or mouse click operations to give the interface an opportunity to remove all relationship candidates from the Candidates collection that do not comply with the interface's stricter criteria.
member.remarks:
The Candidates collection may contain multiple FNO/CNO combinations. The FilterCandidates method must keep in the collection all those FNO/CNO combinaitons that are different from the RelatedFNO/RelatedCNO combination. Only those with the same FNO and CNO can be removed.
The CNO of the triggering component on the active feature and CID of the component instance establishing the relationship can be retrieved from the CNO and CID properties of the GTKeyObject of the ActiveFeature property.
FilterLocatedCandidates should be prepared to handle the case when the CNO and CID are 0 because the relationship software does not always receive these values from the calling commands.
member.param: True if the relationship service is running in a workflow where it could possibly break using the active feature.
GTDDCKeyObjects with the located components of the relationship candidates

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTRelationshipGeometry.AllowMerge(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTKeyObject,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTKeyObjects,System.String[]@)
member.summary: Method called to give the interface an opportunity to stop the relationship to MergeCandidate from being merged. Return True (-1) to allow the merge or False (0) to prevent it.
member.remarks:
True is returned when the RGI allows the merge. False is returned if the RGI does not allow the merge. If it returns false, it also has to add at least one message to MessageArray.
The RGI can get the features to be merged through the ActiveFeature property and the MergeCandidate parameter. Features related to the ActiveFeature can be examined through the RelatedFeatures property. Features related to the MergeCandidate can be examined through the MergeCandidateRelatedFeatures parameter.
member.returns: Boolean

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTRelationshipGeometry.ApproveMerge(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTKeyObject,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTKeyObjects,System.String[]@)
member.summary: Method called to give the interface an opportunity to stop the relationship to MergeCandidate from being merged. Return True (-1) to approve the merge or False (0) to prevent it. ActiveFeature already contains changes to the geometries and attributes.
member.remarks:
True is returned when the RGI approves the merge. False is returned if the RGI does not approve the merge. If it returns False, it also has to add at least one message to MessageArray.
The RGI can get the features to be merged through the ActiveFeature property and the MergeCandidate parameter. Features related to the ActiveFeature can be examined through the RelatedFeatures property. Features related to the MegreCandidate can be examined through the MegreCandidateRelatedFeatures parameter.
member.returns: Boolean

member.name: T:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTImportFeature
member.summary: The Intergraph G/Technology IGTImportFeature Interface, along with the GTFeatureLoader service, is used by the Import Feature command to import features into G/Technology.
member.remarks: If you are implementing a new Import Feature interface without requiring the capability to establish a relationship or break a linear feature, use the DataContext and TransactionManager properties to create or edit features and to maintain the database transactions.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTImportFeature.Execute(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTFeatureLoaderService,ADODB.Recordset,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Method called in which features should be imported into the database.
member.remarks:
Note: An active connection with a job should already be defined when calling the Execute method.
The Execute method should do the following:
Open the file and validate its contents.
Create or upate and save each feature definition.
Raise an error to the command on any failure that should initiate a rollback of the transaction.
Return without error when data should be saved within the transaction.
Return the error string as part of the raised error.
Process its own metadata definition if applicable.
Perform any progress reporting it feels is necessary.
The Execute method should include the code to read the input data source file and to create new or update existing feature attribute information.
The Execute method should return a success or failure. Successful execution triggers the Attribute Grid Control to refresh itself to reflect the changes made during the execution of the Foreign Key Query. The success also replaces the value of the selected attribute with the new output value.
member.param: The Feature Loader object. The command will initialize the application pointer on the object.
The pointer can be null, but this is the ADO version metadata recordset to get the contents of G3E_FEATUREIMPORT_OPTABLE.G3E_OPTIMIZEDTABLE for the particular object.
The name of the file selected by the user.
The value may be null, but this is the contents of G3E_FEATUREIMPORT_OPTABLE.G3E_PARAMETER for the particular object.

member.remarks: The DataContext property lets you set up a GTDataContext object through which you can perform database operations and access published metadata.

member.summary: Property to return/set the GTTransactionManager object associated with this interface.
member.remarks: The TransactionManager property should be used in implementations where the transaction capabilities of Feature Loader Service are not used.

member.name: T:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTForeignKeyQuery
member.summary: The Intergraph G/Technology IGTForeignKeyQuery Interface provides a custom interface where users can replace the value of a selected attribute with a value based on queries against a foreign or domain table (or foreign system data) and add or edit attributes in other components based on the current or new value of selected attributes.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTForeignKeyQuery.Execute(System.Object)
member.summary: Method to process the foreign key request. Successful execution triggers the Attribute Grid control to reflect all changes made during execution. Success also replaces the value of the selected attribute with the new OutputValue.
member.remarks:
An active connection with job should already be defined before this method is called. The Execute method is responsible for the following:
Opening a custom dialog to find the foreign key reference
Using the current value of the selected attribute to perform various tasks.
Returning the output value that will be used to replace the value of the selected attribute.
Updating one or more attributes on any of the components of the current feature.
Adding or deleting rows to the components of the current feature.
Performing data or metadata queries if required.
Returning a success or failure.
The Execute method should contain the code for launching any custom dialog or making updates to one or more attributes on any of the components of the current feature.
The Execute method should return a success or failure. The success of the execution will trigger the Attribute Grid Control to refresh itself to reflect the changes made during the execution of the Foreign Key Query. The success will also replace the value of the selected attribute with the new output value.
member.param: The current value of the selected attribute.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTForeignKeyQuery.Arguments
member.summary: Property to return/set the metadata-defined arguments for this interface.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTForeignKeyQuery.DataContext
member.summary: Property to return/set the GTDataContext object associated with this interface.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTForeignKeyQuery.Feature
member.summary: Property to return/set the GTKeyObject of the feature. It is used to add/delete rows or edit attributes in any of the components of the current feature.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTForeignKeyQuery.FieldName
member.summary: Property to return/set the field name (G3E_ATTRIBUTE.G3E_FOREIGNKEYFIELD or G3E_ATTRIBUTE.G3E_DOMAINFIELD) in the foreign/domain table that is associated with the currently selected attribute.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTForeignKeyQuery.OutputValue
member.summary: Property to return the new value for the selected attribute. It is retrieved if Execute is successful.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTForeignKeyQuery.ReadOnly
member.summary: Property to return/set the flag that indicates the Attribute Grid mode when the interface is called. A value of True (-1) indicates Review mode; a value of False (0) indicates Edit mode. OutputValue is ignored in Review mode.
member.remarks: The attributes must be enabled or disabled on the customized dialog, if one exists, based on the value of this property. Also, in a ReadOnly mode, even though the output value is set, it will not be copied back to the selected attribute.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTForeignKeyQuery.TableName
member.summary: Property to return/set the Foreign or Domain table name associated with the currently selected attribute.
member.remarks:
The TableName property helps build the reference to the foreign or domain table. The foreign or domain table name is derived from the G3E_ATTRIBUTE.G3E_FOREIGNKEYTABLE or G3E_ATTRIBUTE.G3E_DOMAINTABLE field of the selected attribute.
The foreign table field G3E_ATTRIBUTE.G3E_FOREIGNKEYTABLE has priority over the domain table field G3E_ATTRIBUTE.G3E_DOMAINTABLE field of the selected attribute.
The value of this property is null if this interface is invoked through the tab attribute, that is, G3E_TABATTRIBUTE.G3E_FKQRINO is null for the selected attribute.

member.name: T:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTConstructionAid
member.summary: The Intergraph G/Technology IGTConstructionAid Interface is used to create a construction aid.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTConstructionAid.Abort
member.summary: Method called to abort the Construction Aid.
member.remarks: The construction aid should free all pointers and do general cleanup.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTConstructionAid.Initialize
member.summary: Method called after the Construction Aid is created and its initial property values have been set.
member.remarks: The construction aid should free all pointers and do general cleanup.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTConstructionAid.KeyUp(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTMapWindow,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Method called to pass KeyUp events to the Construction Aid.
member.remarks:
Key-up events, such as F1, normally result in help's being displayed or in points' being removed from the geometry.
This method is called for all key-up events except when ESC, SHIFT+ESC, or F3 is pressed, as these have special meaning to the placement and edit commands.
member.param: The window the in which the key up occurred.
The key that was pressed.
Denotes if the SHIFT, ALT, or CTRL keys were also depressed. Some, all, or none of these keys may be depressed at the time the mouse click occurred.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTConstructionAid.MouseClick(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTMapWindow,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPoint,System.Int32,System.Int32,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTDDCKeyObjects)
member.summary: Method called to pass MouseClick events to the Construction Aid.
member.remarks:
This method processes mouse click events, which typically results in points' being appended to the geometry or in locating existing features.
ShiftState may be any value except ALT. An ALT+left-button click is interpreted as a double click, which is not passed to the construction aid.
member.param: The window the in which the mouse click occurred.
The location of the mouse click on the screen, in world coordinates.
Denotes which mouse button was depressed when the click occurred.
Denotes if the SHIFT, ALT, or CTRL keys were also depressed. Some, all, or none of these keys may be depressed at the time the mouse click occurred.
The collection of existing components that are within tolerance (as specified by the SmartLocatePixelTolerance preference-set value) to the location of the mouse click.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTConstructionAid.MouseMove(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTMapWindow,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPoint,System.Int32,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTDDCKeyObjects)
member.summary: Method called to pass MouseMove events to the Construction Aid.
member.remarks: This method is called for all mouse moves, and typically results in dynamics' being drawn from the last point appended to the current mouse location. ShiftState may be any value.
member.param: The window the in which the mouse move occurred.
The location of the mouse pointer on the screen, in world coordinates.
Denotes if the SHIFT, ALT, or CTRL keys were also depressed. Some, all, or none of these keys may be depressed at the time the mouse move occurred.
This is a collection of existing components that are within tolerance (as specified by the SmartLocatePixelTolerance preference set value) to the location of the mouse pointer.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTConstructionAid.SetValue(Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.GTConstructionAidFieldNumberConstants,System.Object)
member.summary: Method called to pass values that have been entered into one of the keyin fields on the Construction Aids Control to the Construction Aid.
member.param: ID that tells the construction aid the type of value and from which key-in field it came.
Value that was entered into the field specified by FieldNumber.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTConstructionAid.DynamicsEnabled
member.summary: Property to tell ConstructionAid whether or not to draw the dynamics between the feature currently being digitized and the geometry that the CA has in dynamics.
member.remarks:
If this property is not set, it should default to True.
Example:This property is set to False by the RectanglebyTwoPointsIPT placement technique because there is no endpoint from which to draw dynamics.
When this property is enabled, you must decide whether or not it makes sense to draw a rubber banding line between the reference geometry and the geometry the construction aid is generating.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTConstructionAid.Geometry
member.summary: Property to return the resulting geometry from the Construction Aid.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTConstructionAid.LengthInDynamics
member.summary: Property to return the length of the geometry currently in dynamics. This includes the length of the geometry that would be returned if the construction aid were completed at this time plus the length of the segment needed to connect this geometry to the existing geometry.
member.remarks: This property may be implemented to always return zero, but this decision should be made based on whether or not the customer uses placement techniques that require this value, such as CableAndComponentIPT and ComponentLengthLabelIPT.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTConstructionAid.ReferenceGeometry
member.summary: Property to set geometry currently being digitized. Typically (but not always), the CA's result is appended to this geometry. Sometimes the CA may use it to determine its result. E.g., orthogonal uses it to determine what it should be orthogonal to.
member.remarks: This property must be set before calling the Initialize method.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTConstructionAid.ReferenceStyleID
member.summary: Property to set the style id of the geometry being digitized. This StyleID can be used with the GTGeometryEditService and GTGeometryCreationService for displaying geometry with an appropriate style.
member.remarks: This property must be set before calling the Initialize Method.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTConstructionAid.ValueMask
member.summary: Property to return a mask of the value IDs that the Construction Aid will recognize in SetValue.
member.remarks: This property uses GTConstructionAidFieldConstants to specify which key-in controls that the Construction Aids control should enable and what type of values each input field should accept.

member.name: T:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTCreateMarker
member.summary: The Intergraph G/Technology IGTCreateMarker Interface is used to place markers at specified marker location points.
member.remarks: In desktop environments, markers can be placed as temporary geometry, as a component of a feature, or as a new feature. In NET environments the markers can be placed as redlines. In either type of environment, the Create Marker function can be replaced with a custom implementation. For example, you can write the marker information into the database for historical reasons.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTCreateMarker.Create(ADODB.Recordset,System.String)
member.summary: Method to create markers at the specified coordinates.
member.remarks: The Create method should create the markers using whatever method for drawing geometries best meets the requirements for each specific implementation.
member.param: The recordset containing the coordinate locations at which to create the marker geometries.
Name of the query to use.

member.name: T:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTTemporaryGeometryPlacement

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTTemporaryGeometryPlacement.MouseMove(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTMapWindow,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPoint,System.Int32,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTDDCKeyObjects)
member.summary: Method to process a mouse move event received on the input GTMapWindow.

The location in world coordinates of the mouse on the screen. UserPoint is snapped when the user hovers the mouse over the same location on the map during the time Select Tool needs to highlight a component.
Denotes if the SHIFT, ALT, or CTRL keys were also pressed. Some, all, or none of these keys may be pressed at the time the mouse move occurred.

While the user moves the mouse, LocatedObjects is Nothing. Once the user hovers the mouse over the same location on the map during time Select Tool needs to highlight a geometry, LocatedObjects is populated with a collection of existing components, which are within tolerance (as specified by the SmartLocatePixelTolerance preference set value) to the location of the mouse.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTTemporaryGeometryPlacement.KeyUp(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTMapWindow,System.Int32@,System.Int32)
member.summary: Method to process a key-up event received on the input GTMapWindow.
member.remarks:
ESC key-up events are not passed to the interface. The calling software component processes those events and calls AbortPlacement on the interface.
The interface is responsible for handling Backspace key-up events. If the user backspaces into an arc in a composite polyline or composite polygon, remove the complete arc at once because leaving an unfinished arc in the GTGeometryCreationService does not automatically switch on the Arc construction aid.
member.param: The window in which the key up occurred.
The key that was pressed.
Denotes if the SHIFT, ALT, or CTRL keys were also pressed. Some, all, or none of these keys may be pressed at the time the key up occurred.

member.name: T:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTFeatureValidation
member.summary:
The Intergraph G/Technology IGTFeatureValidation Interface allows the writing of custom validation software to look for conditions that should prevent data from being saved to the database. Examples of these conditions include:
All required components have not been digitized.
All required attributes have not been populated.
The interface has full control over which conditions should be validated and what priority should be assigned to each validation failure. The interface returns a success or failure status, which determines whether the data can be saved, and the validation errors that are found.
The New Feature and Edit Feature commands have been modified to call this interface prior to saving edits. If the validation interface returns a failing status, both commands will prevent the edits from being saved to the database until the errors have been corrected. When validation fails, the commands will do the following:
Remain Active.
Display the validation errors using the Recordset Review Control.
Keep the transaction intact and running so that the user can correct the errors and try again to save the edits.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTFeatureValidation.Validate(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTKeyObjects,ADODB.Recordset)
member.summary: Method to validate the features in the Features collection and record any validation errors in the ValidationErrors recordset.
member.remarks:
If this function finds a validation error that should prevent the features from being saved, the function should return a value of False. If it finds no validation errors that should prevent the features from being saved, this function should return a value of True.
When called from New Feature or Edit Feature, the Features collection will not contain any features that were related to the input Features as part of the placement or edit operation. The validation interface can access related features by calling the GTRelationshipService.GetRelatedFeatures method for each RNO they are interested in. This method will return the features related to the active features as a result of the current placement or edit operation. However, it may also return related features that were edited in a previous transaction.
If validation errors are recorded in the ValidationErrors recordset, but the function returns a status of True (meaning the data can be saved to the database), the errors in the ValidationErrors recordset will be ignored and will not be displayed.
If there are no validation errors recorded in the ValidationErrors recordset, and the function returns a status of False (meaning the data should not be saved to the database), the command assumes that the validation interface displayed the errors to the user. The command will not attempt to display the validation errors, but it will prevent the save.
If the Validate function returns a failing status, you may want to alert the user that validation failed by some means, such as displaying a message box, beeping at the user, or putting a message in the status bar.
You may use the GTHelperService.RunReport or GTHelperService.DisplayHTML methods to display the validation errors in the Web browser. If the errors are displayed by the interface, no errors should be returned in the ValidationErrors recordset. This will prevent the placement or edit command from also displaying the errors.
The G3E_CNO and G3E_CID fields of the ValidationErrors recordset are not displayed if the placement or edit command displays the errors using the Recordset Review Control.
The Validate function can perform different types of validation depending on the value of the ProcessingMode. For example, more stringent validation may be done when the user is placing a feature as opposed to editing it.
The Validate function can perform different types of validation depending on the role granted to the user. The function can use the GTDataContext.IsRoleGranted function or send in a role through the ArgumentArray to determine the type of validation to perform.
The New Feature and Edit Feature commands call this interface prior to committing the data to the database. This means that triggers and Update functional interfaces have not been fired at the time that the interface is called. Therefore, the interface should not attempt to validate data that will be populated by triggers or Update functional interfaces.
The Validate function can determine whether an attribute has an Update functional interface defined for it by checking the G3E_ATTRIBUTEINFO_OPTABLE. If the G3E_FUNCTIONALTYPE field is set to 'Update, this attribute has an Update functional interfaced defined for it and should not be validated by the interface.
This interface can be called from a desktop or field application. Keep in mind that the external systems and reference tables available to the desktop application may not be available to the field application. These external systems and reference tables should not be accessed when used in a field application. The GTDataContext.Type property can be used to determine if a field application is in use. When the application is connected to a field database, the value of this property will be gtdccField (4).
If the custom validation interface encounters an unexpected problem and raises an error, the New Feature and Edit Feature commands will display the error message to the user and prevent the feature from being saved. This scenario is expected to occur mostly during the development of the interface.
member.param: The GTKeyObjects collection that is to be validated. When called from the Edit Feature command, the collection will contain a single GTKeyObject for the feature selected for edit. When called from the New Feature command, the collection will consist of one GTKeyObject if an individual feature was selected for placement or a GTKeyObject for each feature instance defined to be placed as part of the configuration if a placement configuration was selected.

The recordset of validation errors found and returned by this function. The recordset should be created by the caller and sent to this function. The Validate function can add a row to this recordset for each validation error it finds.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTFeatureValidation.Arguments
member.summary: Property to return/set the metadata-defined arguments for this interface.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTFeatureValidation.DataContext
member.summary: Property to return/set the GTDataContext object used by the Validate method of this interface. It is used to grant the interface access to the database and published metadata.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTFeatureValidation.ProcessingMode
member.summary: Property to return/set the mode that determines the context in which the IGTFeatureValidation interface is being called.
member.remarks:
If being called from the New Feature command, set this property to "Placement" when placing a feature, or to the G3E_PCNO of the placement configuration when placing a placement configuration. If being called from the Edit Feature command, set this property to "Edit."
The Validate method can use this property to perform different types of validation depending on the context in which it is called.

member.name: T:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTDisableEditTool
member.summary: The Intergraph G/Technology IGTDisableEditTool Interface allows the disabling of Edit Tool buttons based on any set criteria, such as user role or items selected.
member.remarks:
This disabling of Edit Tool buttons is in addition to the normal disabling of the Edit Tool command. Modification of the select set with custom software is allowed in limited cases.
Note: While this interface can disable buttons that have been enabled by the Edit Tool, it cannot enable buttons that have been disabled by the Edit Tool.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTDisableEditTool.Initialize
member.summary: Method to process select set and perform other initializations. The Initialize Method is called by the Edit Tool command after the Edit Tool does its own enable/disable logic of the buttons.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTDisableEditTool.ButtonEnabled(Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.GTEditToolButtonConstants)
member.summary: Method takes a button constant as input and returns True or False. If False then the associated button is disabled.
member.param: The button to disable or keep enabled.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTDisableEditTool.Arguments
member.summary: Property to return/set the metadata-defined arguments for this interface.

member.name: T:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.NonlinearModelResidual
member.summary:
The NonlinearModelResidual object contains the residual statistics for its owning Observation when a nonlinear model was used to calculate the least squares transformation.
The NoninearModelResidual object is available only when the owning LeastSquares object is defined to have a nonlinear model type (LeastSquares.IsLinear returns False) and the LeastSquares.CalculateTransformation method has been called.
With nonlinear models, the mathematical assumption is made that neither system 1 nor system 2 observations are fixed, and thus, in the process of calculating the transformation, adjustments to observations can be performed on both system 1 and system 2 coordinates. Thus, residuals may be measured with respect to these adjustments on both systems.
The residuals calculated for system 2 minus transformed system 1 coordinates have no statistical meaning for nonlinear models (they ignore system 1 adjustments). However, as these are commonly desired, they are provided by the NoninearModelResidual object.
Properties for the NonlinearModelResidual object are read-only.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.NonlinearModelResidual.Sys2MinusTransformedSys1Norm
member.summary: The Sys2MinusTransformedSys1Norm property returns the system 2 minus transformed system 1 residual norm, computed from the system 2 minus transformed system 1 X, Y, and Z (if the model is three-dimensional) residual data. As the name implies, these residuals are computed as the differences between the coordinates of the original observation in system 2 and the transformed observation from system 1.
member.remarks:
The residuals calculated for system 2 minus transformed system 1 coordinates have no statistical meaning for nonlinear models (they ignore system 1 adjustments). However, they are provided by the NonlinearModelResidual object.
This property cannot be accessed when the LeastSquares object has been put into a state that necessitates recalculation of the transformation.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.NonlinearModelResidual.Sys2MinusTransformedSys1X
member.summary: The Sys2MinusTransformedSys1X property returns the X coordinate residual computed as the difference between the X coordinate of the original observation in system 2 and the X coordinate of the transformed observation from system 1.
member.remarks:
The residuals calculated for system 2 minus transformed system 1 coordinates have no statistical meaning for nonlinear models (they ignore system 1 adjustments). However, they are provided by the NonlinearModelResidual object.
This property cannot be accessed when the LeastSquares object has been put into a state that necessitates recalculation of the transformation.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.NonlinearModelResidual.Sys2MinusTransformedSys1Y
member.summary: The Sys2MinusTransformedSys1Y property returns the Y coordinate residual computed as the difference between the Y coordinate of the original observation in system 2 and the Y coordinate of the transformed observation from system 1.
member.remarks:
The residuals calculated for system 2 minus transformed system 1 coordinates have no statistical meaning for nonlinear models (they ignore system 1 adjustments). However, they are provided by the NonlinearModelResidual object.
This property cannot be accessed when the LeastSquares object has been put into a state that necessitates recalculation of the transformation.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.NonlinearModelResidual.Sys2MinusTransformedSys1Z
member.summary: The Sys2MinusTransformedSys1Z property returns the Z coordinate residual computed as the difference between the Z coordinate of the original observation in system 2 and the Z coordinate of the transformed observation from system 1. This Z coordinate residual is defined only for three-dimensional models. For two-dimensional models, this property is undefined.
member.remarks:
The residuals calculated for system 2 minus transformed system 1 coordinates have no statistical meaning for nonlinear models (they ignore system 1 adjustments). However, they are provided by the NonlinearModelResidual object.
This property cannot be accessed when the LeastSquares object has been put into a state that necessitates recalculation of the transformation.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.NonlinearModelResidual.System1Norm
member.summary: The System1Norm property returns the system 1 residual norm, computed from the system 1 residuals in X, Y, and Z if the model is three-dimensional. The system 1 residuals for nonlinear models are computed as the differences between the coordinates of the original observation in system 1 and the observation from system 1 as adjusted by the calculation of the transformation.
member.remarks: This property cannot be accessed when the LeastSquares object has been put into a state that necessitates recalculation of the transformation.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.NonlinearModelResidual.System1StandardizedNorm
member.summary: The System1StandardizedNorm property returns the system 1 standardized residual norm, computed from the system 1 standardized residuals in X, Y, and Z if the model is three-dimensional. Standardized system 1 residuals are defined as regular system 1 residuals divided by the standard deviation of those residuals. These regular system 1 residuals are computed as the differences between the coordinates of the original observation in system 1 and the observation from system 1 as adjusted by the calculation of the transformation.
member.remarks: This property cannot be accessed when the LeastSquares object has been put into a state that necessitates recalculation of the transformation.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.NonlinearModelResidual.System1StandardizedX
member.summary: The System1StandardizedX property returns the system 1 standardized X coordinate residual. Standardized system 1 residuals are defined as regular system 1 residuals divided by the standard deviation of those residuals. These regular system 1 residuals are computed as the differences between the coordinates of the original observation in system 1 and the observation from system 1 as adjusted by the calculation of the transformation.
member.remarks: This property cannot be accessed when the LeastSquares object has been put into a state that necessitates recalculation of the transformation.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.NonlinearModelResidual.System1StandardizedY
member.summary: The System1StandardizedY property returns the system 1 standardized Y coordinate residual. Standardized system 1 residuals are defined as regular system 1 residuals divided by the standard deviation of those residuals. These regular system 1 residuals are computed as the differences between the coordinates of the original observation in system 1 and the observation from system 1 as adjusted by the calculation of the transformation.
member.remarks: This property cannot be accessed when the LeastSquares object has been put into a state that necessitates recalculation of the transformation.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.NonlinearModelResidual.System1StandardizedZ

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.NonlinearModelResidual.System2Y
member.summary: The System2Y property returns the system 2 Y coordinate residual. The system 2 residuals for nonlinear models are computed as the differences between the coordinates of the original observation in system 2 and the observation from system 2 as adjusted by the calculation of the transformation.
member.remarks: This property cannot be accessed when the LeastSquares object has been put into a state that necessitates recalculation of the transformation.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.NonlinearModelResidual.System2Z
member.summary: The System2Z property returns the system 2 Z coordinate residual. The system 2 residuals for nonlinear models are computed as the differences between the coordinates of the original observation in system 2 and the observation from system 2 as adjusted by the calculation of the transformation. This Z coordinate residual is defined only for three-dimensional models. For two-dimensional models, this property is undefined.
member.remarks: This property cannot be accessed when the LeastSquares object has been put into a state that necessitates recalculation of the transformation.

member.name: T:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.LeastSquares
member.summary:
The LeastSquares object uses least squares mathematics to perform control-point-based registration between two sets of coordinate points. This operation derives a transformation which may be used to transform points between the two reference spaces defined by the two sets of control points. This transformation may be considered to represent the best set of parameters for a given functional relationship between the two reference spaces.
The LeastSquares object also makes available certain statistics derived from the transformation which it produces. These may be used to evaluate the usefulness of the transformation.
The LeastSquares object persists the given control point pairs, as well as check point pairs, the transformation parameters, and appropriate statistics.
A LeastSquares object may be created as a stand-alone object or it may be created as a member of the Links collection within an AltCoordSystemPath object, using the Links.Add method and specifying the link type cstlLeastSquares. Typically, to persist a LeastSquares object, it should be created using the Links.Add approach, so that its persistence can be organized within the persistence of the other coordinate systems related objects.

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.LeastSquares.CalculateTransformation
member.summary:
Validates the current configuration and then applies least squares mathematics as specified to produce a transformation between system 1 and system 2, using the control-point type Observations. Statistics regarding the transformation are also calculated.
The transformation parameters and statistics are stored internally and may be obtained by various other object properties. The elements of the configuration which are validated include ModelType, Degree (for polynomial type models), Observations.ControlPointCount, WeightsUsage, and, if constraints are being used, the SingleParameterConstraints.Count, and the TransformationParameterIndex values of those constraints.
member.remarks:
The transformation cannot be calculated if the LeastSquares.ModelTypeVal property is set to the value cslsmUndefined (this is equivalent to the LeastSquares.ModelTypeStr property having the value “Undefined”).
The LeastSquares.Degree property must be greater than zero for the polynomial model types. The LeastSquares.ModelTypeVal values for these models are as follows:
cslsmLinear2Dim2ndDegPolynomial
cslsmLinear2DimNDegPolynomial
cslsmLinear2DimNDegConformalPolynomial
cslsm2DimNDegPolynomial, cslsm2DimNDegConformalPolynomial
cslsmLinear3DimNDegPolynomial
cslsm3DimNDegPolynomial
The minimum number of control points needed may be determined from the LeastSquares.NumberControlPointsNeeded property. Note that this property is dependent upon the ModelType and Degree (where appropriate) settings.
The LeastSquares.WeightsUsage property must not include weighting of system 1 (either the cslswSystem1Only or cslswSystem1AndSystem2 value) if the LeastSquares.IsLinear property (which is based upon ModelType) is True.
If the LeastSquares.ConstraintsUsage property is True, then the SingleParameterConstraints.Count must be less than the LeastSquares.NumberTransformationParameters property, and the TransformationParameterIndex property of each SingleParameterConstraint in the collection must be greater than or equal to zero and less than the LeastSquares.NumberTransformationParameters property.
When the CalculateTransformation method detects a rank-deficient solution, it raises a COMException whose ErrorCode property is 0x80070057 (hresult = E_INVALIDARG) and whose Message property is "The least squares solution is rank deficient. You may want to either add more control points or use different control points and recalculate the transformation."
This situation may usually be geometrically interpreted as control points which are so close as to appear identical in terms of the solution, points which are colinear and thus cannot influence the solution, and so forth. If it is possible in this situation, more control points, having different values from those currently used, should be obtained.

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.LeastSquares.CopyTo(Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.LeastSquares)
member.summary: Copies all of properties of one object to another. The object receiving the copied characteristics must exist before calling the CopyTo method.
member.param: The destination object receiving the copied characteristics

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.LeastSquares.IsTransformationValid(Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSPointConstants,System.Int32,Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSPointConstants,System.Int32)
member.summary: Validates whether a proposed transformation can be performed by the object. If the transformation is possible, this method returns a Boolean True value. If the transformation is not possible, this method returns a Boolean False value.
member.remarks:
The values of InputSpaceID and OutputSpaceID are typically the same values used to define the InputSpaceID and OutputSpaceID properties of the LeastSquares object. When a LeastSquares object is being used to transform between similar point types across different reference spaces (as might typically occur with raster or digitizer board registration, where one transforms from storage coordinates of the raster or digitizer board to storage coordinates of the application workspace), then the two space IDs are different.
When a LeastSquares object is being used to transform between different point types (as might occur if registration was being used to simulate projection mapping equations), then the two space IDs are identical.
member.param: Point type from the CSPointConstants enumeration for the points to transform.
A value designating the reference space of the input points.
Point type from the CSPoint constants enumeration for the transformed points.
A value designating the reference space of the output points.

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.LeastSquares.TransformPoint(Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSPointConstants,System.Int32,Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSPointConstants,System.Int32,System.Double@,System.Double@,System.Double@)
member.summary:
The TransformPoint method transforms a single point between different reference spaces according to the capabilities of the object and the method’s parameters.
The TransformPoint method accepts a single point (specified as X, Y, and Z coordinate values) to transform, accepts the input and output point types, and accepts input and output reference space identifiers as input. The method returns the X, Y, and Z coordinate values of the transformed point, using the same parameters as used for the input coordinate values.
member.remarks:
The values of InputSpaceID and OutputSpaceID are typically the same values used to define the InputSpaceID and OutputSpaceID properties of the LeastSquares object.
When a LeastSquares object is being used to transform between similar point types across different reference spaces (as might typically occur with raster or digitizer board registration, where one transforms from storage coordinates of the raster or digitizer board to storage coordinates of the application workspace), then the two space IDs are different.
When a LeastSquares object is being used to transform between different point types (as might occur if registration was being used to simulate projection mapping equations), then the two space IDs are identical.
member.param: Point type from the CSPointConstants enumeration for the points to transform
A value designating the reference space of the input points
Point type from the CSPoint constants enumeration for the transformed points
A value designating the reference space of the output points
On Input, the X coordinate value of the point to be transformed. On output, the transformed X coordinate value.
On Input, the Y coordinate value of the point to be transformed. On output, the transformed Y coordinate value.

On Input, the Z coordinate value of the point to be transformed. On output, the transformed Z coordinate value. The X, Y, and Z parameters serve as both input and output (the transformation is done in place).

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.LeastSquares.TransformPoints(Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSPointConstants,System.Int32,Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSPointConstants,System.Int32,System.Double[])
member.summary:
The TransformPoints method transforms coordinates between different reference spaces according to the capabilities of the object and the method’s parameters.
The TransformPoints method accepts an array of points to transform, accepts the input and output point types, and accepts input and output reference space identifiers as input. The method returns the transformed coordinates, using the same array of points as used for input.
member.remarks:
The values of InputSpaceID and OutputSpaceID are typically the same values used to define the InputSpaceID and OutputSpaceID properties of the LeastSquares object.
When a LeastSquares object is being used to transform between similar point types across different reference spaces (as might typically occur with raster or digitizer board registration, where one transforms from storage coordinates of the raster or digitizer board to storage coordinates of the application workspace), then the two space IDs are different.
When a LeastSquares object is being used to transform between different point types (as might occur if registration was being used to simulate projection mapping equations), then the two space IDs are identical.
member.param: Point type from the CSPoint constants enumeration for the points to transform.
A value designating the reference space of the input points.
Point type from the CSPointConstants enumeration for the transformed points.
A value designating the reference space of the output points.

On Input, an array of points to be transformed. On Output, the array of transformed points. Within this array, the coordinates are laid out as (X1, Y1, Z1, X2, Y2, Z2, ..., Xn, Yn, Zn) where n = Count. The buffer serves as both input and output. That is, the transformation is done in place.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.LeastSquares.AdjObservationCovarianceMatrix
member.summary: Returns a covariance matrix of the adjusted control point observations. This is a square matrix of dimension LeastSquares.ObservationMatrixSize by LeastSquares.ObservationMatrixSize. The matrix is returned as a one-dimensional array of doubles, where the matrix is laid out in row-major order.
member.remarks: This property cannot be accessed when the LeastSquares object has been put into a state that necessitates recalculation of the transformation.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.LeastSquares.ApplyResidualSmoothing
member.summary:
Controls whether or not the residual smoothing technique is applied during point transformations during calls to the TransformPoint and TransformPoints methods.
When used, residual smoothing is applied to a point after it has been transformed by the transformation derived by the CalculateTransformation method. The algorithm involves interpolation of the residual field. For a given point following transformation by the least squares derived transformation, an interpolated residual is then added to the point, in effect adjusting for the discrepancies between the original control points and the least squares adjusted control points. More descriptively, points close to least squares adjusted control points are pulled towards the corresponding original control points, with adjusted control points being transformed onto the corresponding original control points exactly.
member.remarks: When this property is set True, the LeastSquares.ResidualSmoothingExponent property must also be set.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.LeastSquares.ConstraintsUsage
member.summary: Controls whether the calculation of the transformation constrains the transformation solution using the contents of the SingleParameterConstraints collection.
member.remarks: Changing the value of this property when the contained SingleParameterConstraints collection is not empty causes the LeastSquares object to mark itself as needing to recalculate the transformation. When the LeastSquares object is in this need-to-calculate state, users cannot obtain statistics, such as residual data, or transform points until the situation has been rectified -- in this case by calling the LeastSquares.CalculateTransformation method.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.LeastSquares.Degree
member.summary: Defines the degree of the polynomial used when the model type has been set to one of the polynomial models.
member.remarks:
The Degree property may be set for any of the following models, as defined by enumerated type values:
cslsmLinear2DimNDegPolynomial
cslsmLinear2DimNDegConformalPolynomial
cslsm2DimNDegPolynomial
cslsm2DimNDegConformalPolynomial
cslsmLinear3DimNDegPolynomial
cslsm3DimNDegPolynomial
Additionally, for the cslsmLinear2Dim2ndDegPolynomial model, the property always returns the value 2, which is preset and cannot be reset or changed. Attempts to access the property when any other model type has been set produces an error.
The Degree property value must be greater than zero.
Changing the Degree property affects the NumberControlPointsNeeded property. Thus, increasing the value of the Degree property, for example, might cause a need for more control points so the transformation can be calculated with the new, higher Degree value.
Changing the value of the Degree property causes the LeastSquares object to mark itself as needing to recalculate the transformation. When the LeastSquares object is in this need-to-calculate state, users cannot obtain statistics, such as residual data or transform points, until the situation has been rectified by (in this case) calling the CalculateTransformation method.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.LeastSquares.DegreesOfFreedom
member.summary: Returns a statistic regarding the calculated transformation that is a measure of the redundancy of the transformation solution. For a transformation which is not rank-deficient, the DegreesOfFreedom may be defined as the dimension of the model (2 or 3) multiplied by the difference between the number of control points used and the minimum number of control points required by the model. For a rank-deficient transformation, the DegreesOfFreedom is modified by the amount of the deficiency.
member.remarks:
The dimension of the transformation model may be determined by the Is3d property. The minimum number of control points required is returned by the NumberControlPointsNeeded property. Rank deficiency is reported as an exception by the CalculateTransformation method, and may usually be geometrically interpreted as control points that are so close as to appear identical in terms of the solution, points which are colinear and thus cannot influence the solution, and so forth.
This property cannot be accessed when the LeastSquares object has been put into a state that necessitates recalculation of the transformation.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.LeastSquares.Description
member.summary: Defines a string that can be used to describe the LeastSquares transformation for informational purposes.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.LeastSquares.HomogeneousParameterMatrix
member.summary: Returns the transformation in the form of a 4 x 4 matrix. The matrix is returned as a one-dimensional array of 16 doubles, where the matrix is laid out in row-major order. For some models, the transformation can only be approximated in this 4 x 4 matrix.
member.remarks:
The HomogeneousParameterMatrix only approximates the transformation for the following models:
cslsmProjective
cslsmLinearProjective
cslsmLinear2Dim2ndDegPolynomial
If the Degree property is 2 or higher, the HomogeneousParameterMatrix only approximates the transformation for the following models:
cslsm2DimNDegConformalPolynomial
cslsm2DimNDegPolynomial
cslsm3-DimNDegPolynomial
cslsmLinear2DimNDegConformalPolynomial
cslsmLinear2DimNDegPolynomial
cslsmLinear3-DimNDegPolynomial
This property cannot be accessed when the LeastSquares object has been put into a state that necessitates recalculation of the transformation.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.LeastSquares.HomogeneousParamMatrixType
member.summary: Defines whether the HomogeneousParameterMatrix property is defined for a right-handed or left-handed system.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.LeastSquares.InputPointType
member.summary: Defines the point type of points on input when they are being transformed from the reference space of System 1 to the reference space of System 2.
member.remarks: The InputPointType, InputSpaceID, OutputPointType, and OutputSpaceID properties all must be defined before you can use the IsTransformationValid, TransformPoint, and TransformPoints methods.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.LeastSquares.InputSpaceID
member.summary: Defines the reference space identifier of points on input when they are being transformed from the reference space of System 1 to the reference space of System 2.
member.remarks:
The InputSpaceID property value must be greater than zero.
The InputPointType, InputSpaceID, OutputPointType, and OutputSpaceID properties all must be defined before you can use the IsTransformationValid, TransformPoint, and TransformPoints methods.
The values used to define the InputSpaceID and OutputSpaceID properties are typically the values intended for the InputSpaceID and OutputSpaceID parameters of the IsTransformationValid, TransformPoint, and TransformPoints methods.
When a LeastSquares object is used to transform between similar point types across different reference spaces -- as might typically occur with raster or digitizer board registration where one transforms from storage coordinates of the raster or digitizer board to storage coordinates of the application workspace -- then the two space IDs are different. When a LeastSquares object is used to transform between different point types -- as might occur if registration were used to simulate projection mapping equations -- then the two space IDs are identical.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.LeastSquares.Is3d
member.summary: Identifies whether or not the chosen LeastSquares model type is three-dimensional.
member.remarks:
An attempt to access this property when the LeastSquares model type is undefined produces an error.
All LeastSquares model types that are not three-dimensional are two-dimensional.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.LeastSquares.IsLinear
member.summary: Identifies whether or not the chosen LeastSquares model type is linear. This linear versus nonlinear status is important in selecting other objects and properties such as the type of residuals associated with the observations.
member.remarks: An attempt to access this property when the LeastSquares model type is undefined produces an error.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.LeastSquares.LeastSquaresModelTypeStrings
member.summary: Returns a collection of strings that enumerates the list of LeastSquares model types.
member.remarks: The collection returned by this property enumerates the list of valid model type name strings which may be used to set the ModelTypeStr property.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.LeastSquares.ModelTypeStr
member.summary: Defines the model type which the LeastSquares object uses to calculate its transformation. The model type is defined using a character string from a standard list of LeastSquares model type strings. The LeastSquares.LeastSquaresModelTypeStrings property can be used to obtain an object that enumerates the standard list.
member.remarks:
The model type of a LeastSquares object may be defined using either a constant value from the LeastSquaresModelConstants enumeration or a string from the LeastSquares.LeastSquaresModelTypeStrings collection.
Changing the value of the ModelTypeStr property causes the LeastSquares object to mark itself as needing to recalculate the transformation. When the LeastSquares object is in this need-to-calculate state, users cannot obtain statistics, such as residual data, or transform points until the situation has been rectified in this case by calling the LeastSquares.CalculateTransformation method.
Changing the model type may have other effects, such as changing the minimum number of control points needed or introducing the need to set the Degree property.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.LeastSquares.ModelTypeVal
member.summary: Defines the model type which the LeastSquares object uses to calculate its transformation.
member.remarks:
The model type of a LeastSquares object may be defined using either a constant value from the LeastSquaresModelConstants enumeration or a string from the LeastSquares.LeastSquaresModelTypeStrings collection.
Changing the value of the ModelTypeVal property causes the LeastSquares object to mark itself as needing to recalculate the transformation. When the LeastSquares object is in this need-to-calculate state, users cannot obtain statistics, such as residual data, or transform points until the situation has been rectified -- in this case by calling the LeastSquares.CalculateTransformation method.
Changing the model type may also have other effects, such as changing the minimum number of control points needed or introducing the need to set the Degree property.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.LeastSquares.Name
member.summary: The Name property defines a name string for the LeastSquares transformation.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.LeastSquares.NumberControlPointsNeeded
member.summary: The NumberControlPointsNeeded property returns the minimum number of control points which must be defined in order to calculate the transformation, given current property settings.
member.remarks:
The value of the NumberControlPointsNeeded property is determined by the model type (either the ModelTypeStr or ModelTypeVal property) and, for polynomial models, the Degree property.
An attempt to access this property when the LeastSquares model type is undefined produces an error.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.LeastSquares.NumberTransformationParameters
member.summary: The NumberTransformationParameters property returns the number of parameters in the transformation, given current property settings. This number is provided regardless of whether or not the transformation has actually been calculated.
member.remarks:
The value of the NumberTransformationParameters property is determined by the model type, either the ModelTypeStr or ModelTypeVal property, and, for polynomial models, the Degree property.
An attempt to access this property when the LeastSquares model type is undefined produces an error.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.LeastSquares.ObservationMatrixSize
member.summary: The ObservationMatrixSize property returns the number which is both the row and column size for the covariance statistics matrices which are related to observation data. This number is based upon current property settings and is provided regardless of whether or not the transformation has actually been calculated.
member.remarks: The value of the ObservationMatrixSize property is determined by the dimension and linearity of the model (Is3d and IsLinear properties, based upon model type) and by the number of control point type observations (Observations.ControlPointCount).

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.LeastSquares.Observations
member.summary: The Observations property returns the Observations collection object contained within the LeastSquares object. The member Observation objects contain the control or check point pairs and statistics which are kept per-observation.
member.remarks: Although the LeastSquares.Observations property is read-only (a particular Observations collection cannot be assigned by means of a property set), the Observations collection itself is modifiable, using its methods such as Add or Delete.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.LeastSquares.OutputPointType
member.summary: The OutputPointType property defines the point type of points on output when they are being transformed from the reference space of System 1 to the reference space of System 2.
member.remarks: The InputPointType, InputSpaceID, OutputPointType, and OutputSpaceID properties all must be defined before you can use the IsTransformationValid, TransformPoint, and TransformPoints methods.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.LeastSquares.OutputSpaceID
member.summary: The OutputSpaceID property defines the reference space identifier of points on output when they are being transformed from the reference space of System 1 to the reference space of System 2.
member.remarks:
The InputPointType, InputSpaceID, OutputPointType, and OutputSpaceID properties all must be defined before you can use the IsTransformationValid, TransformPoint, and TransformPoints methods.
The OutputSpaceID property value must be greater than zero.
The values used to define the InputSpaceID and OutputSpaceID properties typically are the values intended for the InputSpaceID and OutputSpaceID parameters of the IsTransformationValid, TransformPoint, and TransformPoints methods.
When a LeastSquares object is being used to transform between similar point types across different reference spaces (as might typically occur with raster or digitizer board registration, where one transforms from storage coordinates of the raster or digitizer board to storage coordinates of the application workspace), then the two space IDs are different. When a LeastSquares object is being used to transform between different point types as might occur if registration was being used to simulate projection mapping equations, then the two space IDs are identical.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.LeastSquares.ParameterCovarianceMatrix
member.summary: The ParameterCovarianceMatrix property returns a covariance matrix of the transformation parameters. This is a square matrix of dimension LeastSquares.NumberTransformationParameters by LeastSquares.NumberTransformationParameters. The matrix is returned as a one-dimensional array of doubles, where the matrix is laid out in row-major order.
member.remarks: This property cannot be accessed when the LeastSquares object has been put into a state that necessitates recalculation of the transformation.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.LeastSquares.ResidualCovarianceMatrix
member.summary: The ResidualCovarianceMatrix property returns a covariance matrix of the residuals for control-point observations. This is a square matrix of dimension LeastSquares.ObservationMatrixSize by LeastSquares.ObservationMatrixSize. The matrix is returned as a one-dimensional array of doubles, where the matrix is laid out in row-major order.
member.remarks: This property cannot be accessed when the LeastSquares object has been put into a state that necessitates recalculation of the transformation.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.LeastSquares.ResidualSmoothingExponent
member.summary:
The ResidualSmoothingExponent property defines the exponent used in the residual smoothing algorithm which can optionally be applied during the transformation of points during calls to the TransformPoint and TransformPoints methods.
The effect of the exponent in this algorithm is to control the rate of decrease of influence of a control point on a transformed point, as the transformed point moves away from the control point. The larger the exponent, the greater the decrease of influence as the point moves away. Stated differently, as the exponent increases, the effect of a nearby control point (as opposed to a further-away control point) upon a transformed point increases. The nearby point exerts a stronger pull on the transformed point.
member.remarks: Residual smoothing is applied to a point after it has been transformed by the transformation derived by the CalculateTransformation method. The algorithm involves interpolation of the residual field. For a given point following transformation by the least-squares-derived transformation, an interpolated residual is then added to the point, in effect adjusting for the discrepancies between the original control points and the least squares adjusted control points. More descriptively, points close to least squares adjusted control points are pulled towards the corresponding original control points, with adjusted control points being transformed onto the corresponding original control points exactly.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.LeastSquares.RootMeanSquareOfResiduals
member.summary: The RootMeanSquareOfResiduals property returns the root mean square of the residuals for the control points used to calculate the transformation. This is the square root of the sum of the residuals squared divided by the number of control points. For two-dimensional models, residuals in X and Y are used. For three-dimensional models, residuals in X, Y, and Z are used. For linear models, residuals only exist for system 2. For nonlinear models, residuals from both system 1 and system 2 are used.
member.remarks: This property cannot be accessed when the LeastSquares object has been put into a state that necessitates recalculation of the transformation.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.LeastSquares.SingleParameterConstraints
member.summary: The SingleParameterConstraints property returns the SingleParameterConstraints collection object contained within the LeastSquares object. The member SingleParameterConstraint objects define constraints upon individual parameters of the transformation.
member.remarks: Although the LeastSquares.SingleParameterConstraints property is read-only (a particular SingleParameterConstraints collection cannot be assigned through a property set), the SingleParameterConstraints collection itself is modifiable, using its methods such as Add or Delete.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.LeastSquares.TransformationParameters
member.summary: The TransformationParameters property returns the parameters of the calculated transformation. The parameters are returned as a one-dimensional array of doubles of size LeastSquares.NumberTransformationParameters.
member.remarks: This property cannot be accessed when the LeastSquares object has been put into a state that necessitates recalculation of the transformation.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.LeastSquares.VarianceFactor
member.summary: The VarianceFactor property returns the variance factor statistic, which is a single number giving a measure of the overall accuracy of the adjusted data. The variance factor is the sum of the weighted residuals squared for all control points divided by the degrees of freedom. For under- or fully determined systems where the degrees of freedom is negative or zero, the variance factor is defined to be zero. The variance factor is inversely proportional to the weighting of control points, which may reflect observed errors in specific locations. It is directly proportional to overall systemic errors, such as an inappropriate choice of model, and gross blunders, such as a poorly specified control point value.
member.remarks: This property cannot be accessed when the LeastSquares object has been put into a state that necessitates recalculation of the transformation.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.LeastSquares.WeightsUsage
member.summary: The WeightsUsage property controls how the standard deviation values for control point observations is used as weights in the calculation of the transformation. For nonlinear models, standard deviations may be used to weight both system 1 and system 2 observations. For linear models, only system 2 observations may be weighted. When used, weights are calculated as the reciprocals of the squares of standard deviation values.
member.remarks:
Changing the value of the WeightsUsage property causes the LeastSquares object to mark itself as needing to recalculate the transformation. When the LeastSquares object is in this need-to-calculate state, users cannot obtain statistics, such as residual data, or transform points until the situation has been rectified -- in this case by calling the LeastSquares.CalculateTransformation method.
Standard deviation values for system 1 cannot be used to weight system 1 observations when the model type is linear. An attempt to specify weighting of system 1 observations with a linear model type produces an error.
If the model type is undefined, any weights usage option may be selected. However, the option is validated at the time the LeastSquares.CalculateTransformation method is called. The model type must be defined then.
