member.summary: Method to initialize a new instance of the Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTSymbology class.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTSymbology.Color
member.summary: Property to return/set the RGB color value to be used as an override. It defaults to Null, which indicates that this property should not be used as an override. GTStyleColorConstants can be used instead of a specific RGB value.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTSymbology.FillColor
member.summary: Property to return/set the RGB fillcolor value to be used as an override. It defaults to Null, which indicates that this property should not be used as an override. GTStyleColorConstants can be used instead of a specific RGB value.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTSymbology.Size
member.summary: Property to return/set the symbol/text size to be used as an override. Size units are in Points (1 pt = 1/72 in) ranging from 1 to 500,000. It defaults to Null, which indicates that this property should not be used as an override.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTSymbology.Width
member.summary: Property to return/set the line/boundary width to be used as an override. Width units are in Points (1 pt = 1/72 in) ranging from 1 to 500,000. It defaults to Null, which indicates that this property should not be used as an override.

member.name: T:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTSegment
member.summary: GTSegment represents a line or line segment formed by 2 points. If the segment is "extended", then the line segment is extended infinitely in both directions. Otherwise, the segment is just the line segment between the two points.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTSegment.#ctor(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPoint,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPoint)
member.summary: Construct a line segment formed by the two specified points. The line is not extended.
member.param: Beginning point of the segment.
Ending point of the segment.
member.remarks: The points used to specify the line segment are copied on input, so no subsequent modifications to those GTPoint objects will affect the constructed GTSegment.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTSegment.#ctor(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPoint,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPoint,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Construct a line segment formed by the two specified points. The line is extended if the parameter is true.
member.param: Beginning point of the segment.
Ending point of the segment.
Indicates whether the line should be extended infinitely in both directions.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTSegment.ProjectPoint(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPoint)
member.summary: The ProjectPoint function projects a given point on to this line segment.
member.remarks: The return is the perpendicular projection of the point onto the segment. If the projection is not on the segment, and the segment's IsExtended property is false, then the point returned is the nearest end point (with Type property equal to GTSegmentPointType.gtsptOnEndpoint). If the projection is not on the segment, and the segment's IsExtended property is true, then the point returned is the perpendicular projection of the point onto the extended segment (with Type property equal to GTSegmentPointType.gtsptOnExtendedSegment). If the projected point is on the segment, the Type property of the return value will be GTSegmentPointType.gtsptOnSegment.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTSegment.Includes(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPoint)
member.summary: Determines if the given point is on this segment. If the segment's IsExtended property is true, this function raises an exception.
member.param: GTPoint to be tested to find if it is on the segment.
member.returns: Boolean

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTSegment.Intersect(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTSegment)
member.summary: Computes the intersection of this segment with the given segment. If no intersection exists, an empty array is returned. If the two segments overlap, a single GTSegmentPoint is returned with a Type property of gtsptOverlap. If either segment's IsExtended property is true, then that segment is considered to be extended infinitely in both directions for the purposes of computing the intersection.
member.param: GTSegment given for intersection computation.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTSegment.Intersect(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTArcGeometry)
member.summary: Computes the intersection(s) between this segment and the given arc. If this segment's IsExtended property is true, then the intersections include any intersections with the extension of the segment. The returned array may contain zero, one, or two elements. If any intersections are returned, their Type property will either be gtsptOnSegment or gtsptOnExtendedSegment.
member.param: GTArcGeometry given for intersection computation.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTSegment.ProjectPointAtAngle(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPoint,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPoint,System.Double)
member.summary: Returns a projected point by deriving the lines that pass through the anchor point at the specified angle increment from the original line segment and then projecting the reference point onto the closest derived line.
member.remarks:
Uses positional tolerance.
The angle increment must be greater than 0 and less than or equal to 180 degrees.
The extendability of the input segment is ignored.
member.param: Point used to define the location of the orthogonal line.
Point to be projected onto the orthognal line.
Angle increment used to derive the lines to which the reference point will be projected. For example, an angle increment of 90 would be used to calculate a point orthogonal to the input line segment.

member.summary: Sets or returns the beginning point of the segment.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTSegment.End
member.summary: Sets or returns the ending point of the segment.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTSegment.IsExtended
member.summary: Gets or sets the indication of whether this line segment is extended infinitely in both directions.

member.name: T:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.SingleParameterConstraints
member.summary:
The SingleParameterConstraints object holds all of the constraints which have been defined on the owning LeastSquares object’s transformation parameters.
The SingleParameterConstraints collection may not have a Count greater than or equal to the NumberTransformationParameters of the owning LeastSquares object.

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.SingleParameterConstraints.Add
member.summary: The Add method creates a new SingleParameterConstraint object, adds it to the SingleParameterConstraints collection, and returns it to the caller. This new SingleParameterConstraint is essentially empty, with its Transformation Parameter Index and Value both set to zero.
member.remarks:
Adding a new SingleParameterConstraint to the SingleParameterConstraints collection causes the owning LeastSquares object to mark itself as needing to recalculate the transformation if the ConstraintsUsage property of the LeastSquares object is set to True. When the LeastSquares object is in this need-to-calculate state, users cannot obtain statistics, such as residual data, or transform points until the situation has been rectified by (in this case) filling out the properties of the new SingleParameterConstraint and calling the LeastSquares.CalculateTransformation method.
The SingleParameterConstraints collection may not have a Count greater than or equal to the NumberTransformationParameters of the owning LeastSquares object.

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.SingleParameterConstraints.Delete(System.Int32)
member.summary: The Delete method removes a specified SingleParameterConstraint object from the collection and obliterates its internal data storage.
member.remarks:
Indexes in the SingleParameterConstraints collection begin with the value 0. These indexes are different from and should not be confused with the indices into the transformation parameters array which are held by individual SingleParameterConstraint objects.
An attempt to delete with an invalid (out-of-range) index produces an error.
Deleting a SingleParameterConstraint from the SingleParameterConstraints collection causes the owning LeastSquares object to mark itself as needing to recalculate the transformation if the ConstraintsUsage property of the LeastSquares object is set to True. When the LeastSquares object is in this need-to-calculate state, users cannot obtain statistics (such as residual data) or transform points until the situation has been rectified by (in this case) calling the LeastSquares.CalculateTransformation method.
Although it is possible to hold a reference on a SingleParameterConstraint object after its deletion, any attempt to usefully access the deleted object results in an error. At that point, release of the reference is the only allowable operation.
member.param: The index in the collection of the SingleParameterConstraint object to delete.

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.SingleParameterConstraints.DeleteAll
member.summary: The DeleteAll method removes all objects from the collection and obliterates any internal data storage formerly used by those objects.
member.remarks:
Deleting all SingleParameterConstraint objects from the SingleParameterConstraints collection causes the owning LeastSquares object to mark itself as needing to recalculate the transformation if the ConstraintsUsage property of the LeastSquares object is set to True. When the LeastSquares object is in this need-to-calculate state, users cannot obtain statistics (such as residual data) or transform points until the situation has been rectified. In the case of deleting all SingleParameterConstraint objects with LeastSquares.ConstraintsUsage set to True, either the LeastSquares.ConstraintsUsage property must be set to False or a valid set of SingleParameterConstraints must be populated. In either case, the LeastSquares.CalculateTransformation method must then be called.
Although it is possible to hold a reference on a SingleParameterConstraint object after its deletion, any attempt to usefully access the deleted object results in an error. At that point, release of the reference is the only allowable operation.
Calling DeleteAll on a collection which already has a Count of zero produces no error and does nothing.

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.SingleParameterConstraints.GetEnumerator
member.summary: Returns a type-safe enumerator for the collection.
member.returns: Collection type-safe enumerator

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.SingleParameterConstraints.System#Collections#IEnumerable#GetEnumerator
member.summary: Returns an enumerator for the collection.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.SingleParameterConstraints.Count
member.summary: The Count property returns the number of objects in the collection.

member.summary: The indexer property returns the SingleParameterConstraint object specified by the index within the SingleParameterConstraints collection.
member.remarks: The SingleParameterConstraint object specified by the index. Note that index values start at 0.

member.name: T:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.Observation
member.summary: The Observation object contains information about one pair of coordinate points used by the owning LeastSquares object to calculate or validate a transformation using a collection of such point pairs.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.Observation.AdjustedSystem1X
member.summary: The AdjustedSystem1X property returns the X coordinate of the system 1 observation point, as adjusted by the calculation of the transformation.
member.remarks:
This property can be accessed only if the model type of the owning LeastSquares object is nonlinear. Linear models hold system 1 points fixed and therefore do not adjust them. Attempts to reference this property when the model type of the owning LeastSquares object is linear produces an error.
This property cannot be accessed when the LeastSquares object has been put into a state that necessitates recalculation of the transformation.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.Observation.AdjustedSystem1Y
member.summary: The AdjustedSystem1Y property returns the Y coordinate of the system 1 observation point, as adjusted by the calculation of the transformation.
member.remarks:
This property can be accessed only if the model type of the owning LeastSquares object is nonlinear. Linear models hold system 1 points fixed and therefore do not adjust them. Attempts to reference this property when the model type of the owning LeastSquares object is linear produces an error.
This property cannot be accessed when the LeastSquares object has been put into a state that necessitates recalculation of the transformation.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.Observation.AdjustedSystem1Z
member.summary: The AdjustedSystem1Z property returns the Z coordinate of the system 1 observation point, as adjusted by the calculation of the transformation.
member.remarks:
This property can be accessed only if the model type of the owning LeastSquares object is nonlinear. Linear models hold system 1 points fixed and therefore do not adjust them. Attempts to reference this property when the model type of the owning LeastSquares object is linear produces an error.
This property cannot be accessed when the LeastSquares object has been put into a state that necessitates recalculation of the transformation.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.Observation.AdjustedSystem2X
member.summary: The AdjustedSystem2X property returns the X coordinate of the system 2 observation point, as adjusted by the calculation of the transformation.
member.remarks: This property cannot be accessed when the LeastSquares object has been put into a state that necessitates recalculation of the transformation.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.Observation.AdjustedSystem2Y
member.summary: The AdjustedSystem2Y property returns the Y coordinate of the system 2 observation point, as adjusted by the calculation of the transformation.
member.remarks: This property cannot be accessed when the LeastSquares object has been put into a state that necessitates recalculation of the transformation.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.Observation.AdjustedSystem2Z
member.summary: The AdjustedSystem2Z property returns the Z coordinate of the system 2 observation point, as adjusted by the calculation of the transformation.
member.remarks: This property cannot be accessed when the LeastSquares object has been put into a state that necessitates recalculation of the transformation.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.Observation.Description
member.summary: The Description property defines a string which may be used to describe the observation for informational purposes.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.Observation.LinearModelResidual
member.summary: The X property returns the X coordinate residual. Residuals for linear models are computed as the differences between the coordinates of the original observation in system 2 and the transformed observation from system 1.
member.remarks: This property cannot be accessed when the LeastSquares object has been put into a state that necessitates recalculation of the transformation.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.Observation.Name
member.summary: The Name property defines a name string for the Observation object.
member.remarks: The Name string can be used to identify the Observation within the Observations collection.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.Observation.NonlinearModelResidual
member.summary: The NonlinearModelResidual property returns the NonlinearModelResidual object which contains residual information for the Observation if the model type of the owning LeastSquares object is nonlinear.
member.remarks:
An attempt to access this property when the LeastSquares model type is undefined or linear produces an error.
The IsLinear property of the owning LeastSquares object may be used to determine if it is linear.
This property cannot be accessed when the LeastSquares object has been put into a state that necessitates recalculation of the transformation.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.Observation.System1StdDeviationX
member.summary: The System1StdDeviationX property defines a standard deviation value for the observation’s system 1 X coordinate. This value may be used to weight the system 1 observation for the purpose of calculating the least squares transformation. Setting a standard deviation for a system 1 X coordinate and using it to weight the system 1 observation is only allowed for nonlinear transformation models. Linear models hold all system 1 observations fixed, assuming no variances for them and making no adjustments on them.
member.remarks:
An attempt to set this property with a linear model type produces an error. The property may be set when the model type is undefined, but if the model type is subsequently set to a linear model, the value is ignored.
Changing the value of the System1StdDeviationX property causes the LeastSquares object to mark itself as needing to recalculate the transformation. When the LeastSquares object is in this need-to-calculate state, users cannot obtain statistics, such as residual data, or transform points until the situation has been rectified -- in this case by calling the LeastSquares.CalculateTransformation method.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.Observation.System1StdDeviationY
member.summary: The System1StdDeviationY property defines a standard deviation value for the observation’s system 1 Y coordinate. This value may be used to weight the system 1 observation for the purpose of calculating the least squares transformation. Setting a standard deviation for a system 1 Y coordinate and using it to weight the system 1 observation is only allowed for nonlinear transformation models. Linear models hold all system 1 observations fixed, assuming no variances for them and making no adjustments on them.
member.remarks:
An attempt to set this property with a linear model type produces an error. The property may be set when the model type is undefined, but if the model type is subsequently set to a linear model, the value is ignored.
Changing the value of the System1StdDeviationY property causes the LeastSquares object to mark itself as needing to recalculate the transformation. When the LeastSquares object is in this need-to-calculate state, users cannot obtain statistics, such as residual data, or transform points until the situation has been rectified -- in this case by calling the LeastSquares.CalculateTransformation method.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.Observation.System1StdDeviationZ
member.summary:
The System1StdDeviationZ property defines a standard deviation value for the observation’s system 1 Z coordinate. This value may be used to weight the system 1 observation for the purpose of calculating the least squares transformation.
Setting a standard deviation for a system 1 Z coordinate and using it to weight the system 1 observation is allowed only for nonlinear transformation models. Linear models hold all system 1 observations fixed, assuming no variances for them and making no adjustments on them. A standard deviation value for the observation’s system 1 Z coordinate is only used for three-dimensional transformation models. For two-dimensional models, this property is not used.
member.remarks:
An attempt to set this property with a linear model type produces an error. The property may be set when the model type is undefined, but if the model type is subsequently set to a linear model, the value is ignored.
Changing the value of the System1StdDeviationX property causes the LeastSquares object to mark itself as needing to recalculate the transformation. When the LeastSquares object is in this need-to-calculate state, users cannot obtain statistics, such as residual data, or transform points until the situation has been rectified -- in this case by calling the LeastSquares.CalculateTransformation method.

member.remarks: Changing the value of the System1X property causes the LeastSquares object to mark itself as needing to recalculate the transformation. When the LeastSquares object is in this need-to-calculate state, users cannot obtain statistics, such as residual data, or transform points until the situation has been rectified -- in this case by calling the LeastSquares.CalculateTransformation method.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.Observation.System1Z
member.summary: The System1Z property defines the Z coordinate for the system 1 component of the observation point pair. The system 1 Z coordinate is only used for three-dimensional transformation models. For two-dimensional models, this property will not be used.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.Observation.Type
member.summary: The Type property defines whether the observation point pair represents a control point pair, which is used by the owning LeastSquares object to calculate the transformation, or a check point pair, which may be used to validate the transformation by the statistics regarding the point pair.
member.remarks:
Changing the value of the Type property causes the LeastSquares object to mark itself as needing to recalculate the transformation. When the LeastSquares object is in this need-to-calculate state, users cannot obtain statistics, such as residual data, or transform points until the situation has been rectified -- in this case by calling the LeastSquares.CalculateTransformation method.
Changing the observation from cslsoControlPoint to cslsoCheckPoint type reduces the number of control points available for calculation of the transformation, possibly requiring the addition of one or more control points to have the number required by the given transformation model.

member.name: T:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.Links
member.summary:
A Links object is a collection of Link objects.
An AltCoordSystemPath object creates and deletes Link objects and manages their persistence through its Links collection. An AltCoordSystemPath object manages its transformation path using its TransLinks collection. Link objects appended to an AltCoordSystemPath’s TransLinks collection must belong to its Links collection.

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.Links.Add(System.String,Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSTransformLinkConstants)
member.summary: The Links.Add method creates a new Link object of a specified type and adds it to the Links collection.
member.remarks: Typically, the last link added is the definition of the alternate coordinate system.
member.param: Name of the Link object to add. This name must be 255 characters or less and can include embedded spaces.
The type of link object being added to the collection.

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.Links.Delete(System.String)
member.summary: The Delete method deletes a named Link object from the Links collection.
member.param: The name of the object to delete. This name must be 255 characters or less and can include embedded spaces.

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.Links.DeleteAll
member.summary: Delete all links in the collection.

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.Links.GetEnumerator
member.summary: Returns a type-safe enumerator for the collection.
member.returns: Collection type-safe enumerator

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.Links.System#Collections#IEnumerable#GetEnumerator
member.summary: Returns an enumerator for the collection.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.Links.Count
member.summary: The Count property returns the number of objects in the collection.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.Links.Item(System.String)
member.summary: The indexer returns an object from its Links collection object by specifying the object's name.
member.remarks: Note that Link object names are case-sensitive. For example, two links named "TestLink" and "Testlink" can exist as separate links within the Links collection.

member.name: T:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CoordSystemsMgr
member.summary: GTCoordSystemsMgr manages all coordinate system (CSS) data for a database connect. It also manages the transformations between the primary coordinate system and any alternate coordinate systems.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CoordSystemsMgr.CoordSystem
member.summary: Returns the primary coordinate system for the associated geoworkspace. This coordinate system is the central coordinate system to which all of the alternate coordinate system paths within the coordinate systems manager connect, thus allowing point transformations from the central coordinate system’s reference spaces to alternate reference spaces and vice versa.
member.remarks: It is not possible to change the CoordSystemsMgr.CoordSystem through a direct assignment, since the property is read-only. To accomplish this, use the CopyTo method on the new CoordSystem and specify the CoordSystemsMgr.CoordSystem as the destination argument.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CoordSystemsMgr.AltCoordSystemPaths
member.summary: Returns an object representing any alternate coordinate systems associated with the geoworkspace.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTVector.ScaleVector(System.Double)
member.summary:
Returns a vector pointing in the same direction as the input vector but with a magnitude times the magnitude of the input vector. In other words,
x.ScaleVector(v).Magnitude == v*x.Magnitude
and
x.ScaleVector(v).Normalize == x.Normalize.

member.name: T:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.GeogSpace
member.summary:
The GeogSpace object specifies and retrieves the ellipsoid and geodetic datum used to define the geographic reference space within the RefSpaceMgr object.
Setting the geodetic datum to csgdUserDefined enables selecting and assigning of an ellipsoid to the GeogSpace object. Otherwise, the ellipsoid and its parameters (such as polar radius) are preset according to the currently assigned geodetic datum. With the geodetic datum set to csgdUserDefined, setting the ellipsoid to cseUserDefined enables setting of ellipsoid parameter values. Ellipsoid parameters are preset according to the currently-assigned ellipsoid if the geodetic datum is set to csgdUserDefined but the ellipsoid is not set to cseUserDefined.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.GeogSpace.EccentricityStr
member.summary: Sets or returns the eccentricity of the reference ellipsoid using a formatted string. The eccentricity of the reference ellipsoid is a unitless parameter.
member.remarks:
This property can be set only if the ellipsoid is set to user-defined. The ellipsoid can be set to user-defined by setting the EllipsoidVal property to cseUserDefined or by setting the EllipsoidStr property to user-defined (non-standard).
The string assigned to the EccentricityStr property must be a positive numeric string that is equal or greater than 0.0 and less than 1.0. Setting this property to less than 0.0, to 1.0 or greater, or including one or more non-numeric characters produces an error.
When this property is returned, the string is formatted using the maximum amount of precision possible for the current eccentricity value.
Setting the reference ellipsoid to any value other than user-defined automatically sets the eccentricity ellipsoid parameter.
Modifying the EccentricityStr property automatically recalculates other ellipsoid parameters (flattening, flattening inverse, and polar radius).
Modifying this property after coordinate data has been collected for persistent storage invalidates subsequent coordinate system operations and many operations such as measurement dependent on the coordinate system.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.GeogSpace.EccentricityVal
member.summary: Sets or returns the eccentricity of the reference ellipsoid using a double precision value. The eccentricity of the reference ellipsoid is a unitless parameter.
member.remarks:
This property can be set only if the ellipsoid is set to user-defined. The ellipsoid can be set to user-defined by setting the EllipsoidVal property to cseUserDefined or by setting the EllipsoidStr property to User-defined (Non-standard).
The EccentricityVal property accepts a value equal or greater than 0.0 and less than 1.0.
Setting this property to less than 0.0 or to 1.0 or greater produces an error. Setting the reference ellipsoid to any value other than user-defined automatically sets the eccentricity ellipsoid parameter.
Modifying the EccentricityVal property automatically recalculates other ellipsoid parameters (flattening, flattening inverse, and polar radius).
Modifying this property after coordinate data has been collected for persistent storage invalidates subsequent coordinate system operations and many operations such as measurement dependent on the coordinate system.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.GeogSpace.EllipsoidStr
member.summary: Sets the reference ellipsoid used by the RefSpaceMgr object by specifying a character string from a standard list of ellipsoid character string names. This property also returns the character string for the currently assigned ellipsoid. The reference ellipsoid is used by many projection algorithms for transforming points between the geographic and projected reference spaces.
member.remarks:
The EllipsoidStr property can be set only if the geodetic datum is set to user defined. If the geodetic datum is set to any other value, the ellipsoid is preset, and cannot be changed without first changing the geodetic datum. The geodetic datum can be set to user defined by setting the GeodeticDatumVal property to csgdUserDefined or the GeodeticDatumStr property to User-defined (Non-standard).
Ifthe EllipsoidStr property is used to set the ellipsoid, the string assigned to this property must be an alphanumeric character string that matches an internal designation. The GeogSpace.EllipsoidStrings.Item method returns the character string for any item in the ellipsoid strings collection.
Setting the reference ellipsoid to any value other than user-defined automatically sets the equatorial radius, polar radius, eccentricity, flattening, and flattening inverse ellipsoid parameters.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.GeogSpace.EllipsoidStrings
member.summary: Returns a string collection that enumerates the list of available ellipsoids. This is a snapshot of the names of all the ellipsoids supported at the time of the object's creation.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.GeogSpace.EllipsoidVal
member.summary: Sets the reference ellipsoid used by the RefSpaceMgr object by assigning a predefined ellipsoid constant to the property. This property also returns the constant value for the currently assigned ellipsoid.
member.remarks:
The EllipsoidVal property can be set only if the geodetic datum is set to user-defined. If the geodetic datum is set to any other value, the ellipsoid is preset and cannot be changed without first changing the geodetic datum. The geodetic datum can be set to user-defined by setting the GeodeticDatumVal property to csgdUserDefined or the GeodeticDatumStr property to User-defined (Non-standard).
Setting the ellipsoid automatically sets the equatorial radius, polar radius, eccentricity, flattening, and flattening inverse ellipsoid parameters.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.GeogSpace.EquatorialRad
member.summary:
Sets or returns the equatorial radius of the reference ellipsoid using a double precision value in meters.
The EquatorialRad property value must be greater than 0.0.
member.remarks:
This property can be set only if the ellipsoid is set to user-defined. The ellipsoid can be set to user-defined by setting the EllipsoidVal property to cseUserDefined or by setting the EllipsoidStr property to User-defined (Non-standard).
Setting the reference ellipsoid to any value other than user-defined automatically sets the equatorial radius parameter.
Modifying the EquatorialRad property automatically recalculates the polar radius parameter.
Modifying this property after coordinate data has been collected for persistent storage invalidates subsequent coordinate system operations and many operations such as measurement dependent on the coordinate system.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.GeogSpace.FlatteningInverseStr
member.summary: Sets or returns the flattening inverse of the reference ellipsoid using a formatted string. The flattening inverse of the reference ellipsoid is a unitless parameter.
member.remarks:
This property can be set only if the ellipsoid is set to user-defined. The ellipsoid can be set to user-defined by setting the EllipsoidVal property to cseUserDefined or by setting the EllipsoidStr property to User-defined (Non-standard).
When the ellipsoid’s flattening inverse is set, the string assigned to the FlatteningInverseStr property must be a numeric string greater than 1.0. Setting this property to less than or equal to 1.0 or including one or more non-numeric characters produces an error.
When this property is returned, the string is formatted using the maximum amount of precision possible for the current flattening inverse value.
Setting the reference ellipsoid to any value other than user-defined automatically sets the flattening inverse ellipsoid parameter.
Setting the flattening inverse automatically causes a recalculation of the polar radius, flattening, and eccentricity ellipsoid parameter values.
Modifying this property after coordinate data has been collected for persistent storage invalidates subsequent coordinate system operations and many operations such as measurement that are dependent on the coordinate system.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.GeogSpace.FlatteningInverseVal
member.summary: Sets or returns the flattening inverse of the reference ellipsoid using a double precision value. The flattening inverse of the reference ellipsoid is a unitless parameter.
member.remarks:
This property can be set only if the ellipsoid is set to user-defined. The ellipsoid can be set to user-defined by setting the EllipsoidVal property to cseUserDefined or by setting the EllipsoidStr property to user-defined (non-standard).
The FlatteningInverseVal property accepts a value greater than 1.0.
Setting this property to less than or equal to 1.0 produces an error.
Setting the reference ellipsoid to any value other than user-defined automatically sets the flattening inverse ellipsoid parameter.
Setting the flattening inverse automatically causes a recalculation of the polar radius, flattening, and eccentricity ellipsoid parameter values.
Modifying this property after coordinate data has been collected for persistent storage invalidates subsequent coordinate system operations and many operations dependent on the coordinate system (such as measurement).

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.GeogSpace.FlatteningStr
member.summary: Sets or returns the flattening of the reference ellipsoid using a formatted string. The flattening of the reference ellipsoid is a unitless parameter.
member.remarks:
This property can be set only if the ellipsoid is set to User-defined. The ellipsoid can be set to user-defined by setting the EllipsoidVal property to cseUserDefined or by setting the EllipsoidStr property to User-defined (Non-standard).
When the ellipsoid’s flattening is set, the string assigned to the FlatteningStr property must be a positive numeric string that is equal or greater than 0.0 and less than 1.0. Setting this property to less than 0.0, to 1.0 or greater, or including one or more non-numeric characters produces an error.
Setting the reference ellipsoid to any value other than user-defined automatically sets the flattening ellipsoid parameter.
Setting the flattening automatically causes a recalculation of the polar radius, flattening inverse, and eccentricity ellipsoid parameter values.
When this property is returned, the string is formatted using the maximum amount of precision possible for the current flattening value.
Modifying this property after coordinate data has been collected for persistent storage invalidates subsequent coordinate system operations and many operations dependent on the coordinate system (such as measurement).
In the special case of an ellipsoid that is a sphere, eccentricity and flattening are both zero and the flattening inverse parameter value becomes infinite. In that case, this property returns the (localized) string "infinite - sphere". Code that needs to set or detect this case should use the eccentricity or flattening parameter and the value zero.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.GeogSpace.FlatteningVal
member.summary: Sets or returns the flattening of the reference ellipsoid using a double precision value. The flattening of the reference ellipsoid is a unitless parameter.
member.remarks:
This property can be set only if the ellipsoid is set to user-defined. The ellipsoid can be set to user-defined by setting the EllipsoidVal property to cseUserDefined or by setting the EllipsoidStr property to User-defined (Non-standard).
The FlatteningVal property accepts a value equal or greater than 0.0 and less than 1.0.
Setting this property to less than 0.0 or to 1.0 or greater produces an error.
Setting the reference ellipsoid to any value other than User-defined automatically sets the flattening ellipsoid parameter.
Setting the flattening automatically causes a recalculation of the polar radius, flattening inverse, and eccentricity ellipsoid parameter values.
Modifying this property after coordinate data has been collected for persistent storage invalidates subsequent coordinate system operations and many operations dependent on the coordinate system (such as measurement).

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.GeogSpace.GeodeticDatumStr
member.summary:
Sets the horizontal geodetic datum used by the RefSpaceMgr object by specifying a character string from a standard list of geodetic datum character string names. This property also returns the character string for the currently assigned geodetic datum.
Note: The geodetic datum defines the reference ellipsoid. This ellipsoid is used by many projection algorithms for transforming points between the geographic and projected reference spaces.
member.remarks:
The list of standard (predefined) or named (configurable) geodetic datum character string names can be obtained using the GeodeticDatumStrings collection object returned from the GeogSpace.GeodeticDatumStrings property.
If the geodetic datum is set to user-defined, the ellipsoid can be set using the EllipsoidStr or EllipsoidVal property. If the geodetic datum is not user-defined, the ellipsoid is preset and cannot be changed.
Named horizontal geodetic datums are defined in the NamedHDatum.ini configuration file.
Setting the projection algorithm (of the ProjSpace object contained within the same RefSpaceMgr that contains the GeogSpace object in question) to certain values causes the geodetic datum to be preset and unchangeable. These preset systems include:
British National Grid New Zealand Map Grid Both Swiss LV systems State Plane Coordinate System 1927
Setting the projection algorithm to State Plane Coordinate System 1983 presets the datum to North American 1983 from which it may be changed only to North American 1983 - HARN. An exception for these preset systems is that a named datum may be used with them provided that its base standard datum is the appropriate preset datum.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.GeogSpace.GeodeticDatumStrings
member.summary: Returns a collection of strings that enumerates the list of available geodetic datums.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.GeogSpace.GeodeticDatumVal
member.summary:
Specifies the horizontal geodetic datum referenced by all of the reference spaces of the RefSpaceMgr object. The horizontal geodetic datum is specified using a constant value from an enumeration.
Note: The geodetic datum defines the reference ellipsoid. This ellipsoid is used by many projection algorithms for transforming points between the geographic and projected reference spaces.
member.remarks:
If the GeodeticDatumVal property is used to set the geodetic datum, a constant is assigned to the property. The constant is assigned by its Long value or name.
If the geodetic datum is set to user defined, the ellipsoid can be set using the EllipsoidStr or EllipsoidVal property. If the geodetic datum is not user-defined, the ellipsoid is preset and cannot be changed.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.GeogSpace.PolarRad
member.summary: Sets the polar radius value using a precision double value or returns the current polar radius value as a precision double value. The value is expressed in meters.
member.remarks:
This property can be set only if the ellipsoid is set to user-defined. The ellipsoid can be set to user-defined by setting the EllipsoidVal property to cseUserDefined (Long value 22) or by setting the EllipsoidStr property to User-defined (Non-standard).
The PolarRad property accepts a value greater than 0.0 and less than or equal to the value of the EquatorialRad property.
Modifying the PolarRad property automatically recalculates the flattening, inverse flattening, and eccentricity ellipsoid parameters while holding the equatorial radius to its existing value.

member.name: T:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.UnitAndFormatSpec
member.summary:
The UnitAndFormatSpec object stores units and formatting information. This object formats and parses value and point strings. A value string is a string representing a single quantity like distance, area, or longitude. A point string is a string representing a set of two or more coordinates representing a single point.
The UnitAndFormatSpec object fires a Change event to notify listeners of changes to its properties.
The methods for the UnitAndFormatSpec object that format or parse strings use values without an appended-units alias.
Example: If a projected point string value contains X, Y, and height, it is presented as "10, 20, 5". However, the default units -- m, m, ft -- are not included in the string presentation. Instead, a separate property contains the default-units aliases.
Point and value strings use a specific unit type and its associated precision for parsing and formatting. Precision is the number of digits displayed to the right of the decimal point. Additionally, other parameters can affect the formatting and parsing of certain point and value strings.
Example: Geographic coordinates use the geographic unit type’s unit and precision for formatting and parsing operations. This functionality is used to support various units and formatting needs, such as the specification of parameters for a projection algorithm, or a coordinate readout in a particular reference space.

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.UnitAndFormatSpec.CopyTo(Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.UnitAndFormatSpec)
member.summary: The CopyTo method copies all of the properties of one object to another. The object receiving the copied characteristics must exist before calling the CopyTo method.
member.param: The destination object receiving the copied characteristics

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.UnitAndFormatSpec.FormatPointString(Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSPointStringConstants,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary:
The FormatPointString method formats a specified point to produce a point string. This point string is expressed in the correct unit type for the given point type.
Note: Unit strings are not appended to or embedded within the point string.
member.param: Type of point string to format. Range includes all valid CSPointStringConstants values.
X coordinate of point expressed in the appropriate computation base unit for the given point type to format.
Y coordinate of point expressed in the appropriate computation base unit for the given point type to format.
Z coordinate of point expressed in the appropriate computation base unit for the given point type to format.

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.UnitAndFormatSpec.FormatValueString(Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSValueStringConstants,System.Double)
member.summary: The FormatValueString method formats the given value to produce a value string. This value string is expressed in the correct unit type for the given value type. Unit strings are not appended to the produced value string.
member.param: Type of value string to format.
Value expressed in the appropriate computation base unit for the given value type to format.

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.UnitAndFormatSpec.GetPointDescription(Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSPointStringConstants,Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSDescriptionConstants)
member.summary: The GetPointDescription method builds a point description string describing the units and format specification of a particular point type. It combines the results of other options, such as the HeightDisplayOpt, GeogCoordOrd, and properties for default units, into one description of the specified point type. For example, the description string for a geographic point string might be "Lat, Lon (d:m:s), Hgt (m)".
member.param: Type of point string for which an overall description string is being returned.
Specifies whether to describe a point as it is accepted as input or as it displays on output.

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.UnitAndFormatSpec.ParsePointString(Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSPointStringConstants,System.String,System.Double@,System.Double@,System.Double@)
member.summary:
The ParsePointString method parses the given point string to produce a point in computational base units. This function assumes that the point string is expressed in the correct unit type for the given point type.
Note: Units should not be appended to or embedded in the input point string.
member.remarks:
Possible point strings include strings representing geographic, projection, geocentric, paper, and local space rectangular coordinates. Parsing a given character string representing a point includes the following:
Accounting for coordinate ordering for geographic point strings.
Accounting for geographic hemisphere option for geographic point strings.
Accounting for projection quadrant option for projection point strings.
Converting the character string to a set of double precision values.
Performing a unit conversion between input/output unit and computational base unit.
member.param: Type of point string to format. Range includes all valid CSPointStringConstants values.
Point string returned by the method. The point string is formatted and expressed in the correct I/O unit(s) for the type of point. Unit strings are not appended to or embedded in the point string.
X coordinate of point expressed in the appropriate computation base unit for the given point type to format.
Y coordinate of point expressed in the appropriate computation base unit for the given point type to format.
Z coordinate of point expressed in the appropriate computation base unit for the given point type to format.

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.UnitAndFormatSpec.ParseValueString(Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSValueStringConstants,System.String,System.Double@)
member.summary:
The ParseValueString method parses the given value string to produce a computational base value. This method assumes that the value string is expressed in the correct unit type for the type returned.
Note: Do not append units to the input value string.
member.remarks:
Possible value strings include the following:
Angle
Area
Azimuth
Bearing
Distance
Geocentric X, Y, and Z
Height
Latitude
Longitude
Paper height
Paper X and Y
Projection X and Y
Paper area
Paper distance
Paper volume
Volume
Time
Z height (local space rectangular system)
Parsing a given character string representing a value includes the following:
Accounting for projection quadrant option for projection X and Y values.
Accounting for geographic hemisphere option for longitude and latitude values.
Accounting for azimuth start and direction for azimuth values.
Accounting for special formatting for bearing values.
Converting the character string to a double precision value.
Performing a unit conversion between input/output unit and computational base unit.
member.param: Type of value string to parse.
Value string to parse. Express the value string to parse in the correct unit for the type of return value. Do not append units to the value string.
Value expressed in the appropriate computation base unit for the given value type parsed.

member.summary:

member.summary: The MeasurementReferenceSpace property sets or gets the active reference space used for performing measurements. This is accomplished by giving the value of this property to the MeasurementService object being used to perform measurements. This UnitFormatSpec property exists as a convenient and logical place to store the setting because MeasurementService objects are not persisted.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.UnitAndFormatSpec.ProjQuadrantOpt
member.summary:
The ProjQuadrantOpt property specifies the directions and signs of the projection’s X and Y axes used in the coordinate calculation of the projected reference space.
A typical option is X positive east and Y positive north. Both right-handed and left-handed systems are possible. The order of coordinates is always X,Y. No coordinate ordering options are necessary, since, for example, the quadrant options allow for X to point south and Y to point west.

member.summary: Represents a mechanism for client software to customize the data used in a schematic layout.

member.summary: Processes the collection of schematic elements.
member.remarks: After Execute returns, the GTSchematicGeneratorService uses the Elements collection to generate the schematic layout for that feature class.
member.param: The collection of schematic elements to be processed.

member.summary: Gets the feature number of the schematic elements being processed.
member.remarks: This property is provided to the filter object so that it can easily decide whether any filtering or custom processing is appropriate.

member.name: T:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.PaperSpace
member.summary: The PaperSpace object controls the nominal paper map scale and returns and adjusts the projection-to-paper matrix. This matrix is used internally by the RefSpaceMgr object to transform points between projection and paper space.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.PaperSpace.NominalMapScaleDenominator
member.summary: The NominalMapScaleDenominator property sets or gets a nominal map scale for readouts and measurements. The nominal map scale allows the placement of text or symbology with specific reference to the output map scale.
member.remarks:
The default value for the NominalMapScaleDenominator property is 50,000.
Changing the NominalMapScaleDenominator property changes the projection-to-paper matrix. The ProjectionToPaperMatrix property returns the current values for this matrix. Changing the ProjectionToPaperMatrix property may change the NominalMapScaleDenominator property.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.PaperSpace.ProjectionToPaperMatrix
member.summary: The ProjectionToPaperMatrix property sets or gets the transformation matrix between the projection and paper reference spaces. The 4 x 4 matrix consists of an array of 16 Double values arranged in column-major order.
member.remarks:
The nominal map scale is contained within the ProjectionToPaperMatrix as its scaling.
The values can be changed to adjust the matrix for rotation, offset, and so forth. This adjustment is accomplished by passing a new array of 16 Doubles to the ProjectionToPaperMatrix property.

member.name: T:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSBaseStorageConstants
member.summary: Intergraph Coordinate Systems Base Storage Constants.

member.name: F:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSBaseStorageConstants.csbsProjected
member.summary: A system referencing a chosen 2-D projection plane plus heights. The X direction increases in magnitude towards the East, Y direction increases in magnitude towards the North, and height or elevation increases in magnitude towards Up. Height is measured with respect to either the surface of the reference ellipsoid or an established mean sea level, depending upon the HeightStorageType.

member.name: F:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSBaseStorageConstants.csbsGeographic
member.summary: The system of longitude, latitude, height. Longitude is the angular measure with respect to the chosen prime meridian; it increases in magnitude towards the East. Latitude is the angular measure with respect to the equator; it increases in magnitude towards the North. Height or elevation is measured with respect to either the surface of the reference ellipsoid or an established mean sea level, depending upon the HeightStorageType. Elevation increases in magnitude towards Up.

member.name: F:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSBaseStorageConstants.csbsGeocentric
member.summary: The cartesian system with origin at the earth’s center. The X axis increases in magnitude going through the intersection of the Greenwich prime meridian and equator. The Y axis increases in magnitude going through the intersection of the 90 degrees East meridian and equator. The Z axis coincides with the earth’s rotational axis and increases in magnitude towards the North Pole.

member.summary: List of options available for specifying the longitude normalization used with storage coordinates which are tied to the geographic reference space.

member.name: F:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSLongitudeNormalizationConstants.cslnZeroTo360LeftInclude
member.summary: Longitude values are normalized to fall within the range 0 degrees to +360 degrees. The value 0 degrees is included in the acceptable interval and requires no normalization. The value +360 degrees is excluded from the acceptable interval and is normalized, resulting in the value 0 degrees.

member.name: F:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSLongitudeNormalizationConstants.cslnZeroTo360BothInclude
member.summary: Longitude values are normalized to fall within the range 0 degrees to +360 degrees. The values 0 degrees and +360 degrees are both included in the acceptable interval and require no normalization.

member.name: F:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSLongitudeNormalizationConstants.cslnMinus180ToPlus180LeftInclude
member.summary: Longitude values are normalized to fall within the range -180 degrees to +180 degrees. The value -180 degrees is included in the acceptable interval and requires no normalization. The value +180 degrees is excluded from the acceptable interval and is normalized, resulting in the value -180 degrees.

member.name: F:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSLongitudeNormalizationConstants.cslnMinus180ToPlus180BothInclude
member.summary: Longitude values are normalized to fall within the range -180 degrees to +180 degrees. The values -180 degrees and +180 degrees are both included in the acceptable interval and require no normalization.

member.name: F:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSLongitudeNormalizationConstants.cslnMinus360To0RightInclude
member.summary: Longitude values are normalized to fall within the range -360 degrees to 0 degrees. The value 0 degrees is included in the acceptable interval and requires no normalization. The value -360 degrees is excluded from the acceptable interval and is normalized, resulting in the value 0 degrees.

member.name: F:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSLongitudeNormalizationConstants.cslnMinus360To0BothInclude
member.summary: Longitude values are normalized to fall within the range -360 degrees to 0 degrees. The values -360 degrees and 0 degrees are both included in the acceptable interval and require no normalization.

member.name: F:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSLongitudeNormalizationConstants.cslnNoLongitudeNormalization
member.summary: No normalization of longitude values occurs.

member.name: T:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSGeodeticDatumConstants
member.summary:
The list of available horizontal geodetic datums. The definitions of these datums come primarily from two sources: NIMA Technical Report 8350.2, Third Edition (July 1997) and the EPSG Geodesy Parameters database, version 4.0 (March 1998). Where conflicts between these two sources exist, both definitions are provided and the names indicate the source.
Each constant having a positive value corresponds to a single standard (predefined) geodetic datum. The two constants having negative values have special meaning:
csgdNamed indicates that the geodetic datum is defined by one of the entries in the NamedHDatum.ini configuration file. This value cannot be used to set the GeogSpace and DatumTransformation properties referenced above, but may be reported as the value when the properties are retrieved.
csgdUndefined indicates the undefined condition and hence does not correspond to any standard (predefined) or named (configurable) datum. This value cannot be used with the GeogSpace.GeodeticDatumVal property but can be used with the two DatumTransformation properties.

member.name: T:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.LeastSquaresHomogeneousMatrixConstants
member.summary:
The LeastSquaresHomogeneousMatrixConstants enumeration is used with the LeastSquares.HomogeneousParamMatrixType property as the list of options available for specifying the orientation type of the homogeneous matrix returned by the LeastSquares.HomogeneousParameterMatrix property.
A left-handed matrix is often used when one of the systems references a raster space, where the y axis increases in magnitude in the down direction.

member.name: F:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.LeastSquaresHomogeneousMatrixConstants.cslshmRightHanded
member.summary: The matrix has right-handed orientation.

member.name: F:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.LeastSquaresHomogeneousMatrixConstants.cslshmLeftHanded
member.summary: The matrix has left-handed orientation.

member.name: T:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.LeastSquaresWeightsUsageConstants
member.summary:
The LeastSquaresWeightsUsageConstants enumeration is used with the LeastSquares.WeightsUsage property as the list of options available for specifying the weighting of control point type observations for the calculation of the least squares transformation.
Weights are computed internally as the reciprocal squares of an observation’s standard deviations. Thus, if a specific point is to be heavily weighted, then small numerical values should be given for its standard deviations.

member.name: F:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.LeastSquaresWeightsUsageConstants.cslswNone
member.summary: The standard deviations for both System 1 and System 2 for all observations is ignored. Internally, weights for all observations are uniformly set to 1.0 to achieve the effect of not giving special weighting to any particular observation.

member.name: F:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.LeastSquaresWeightsUsageConstants.cslswSystem1Only
member.summary: The System 1 standard deviations is used to weight the System 1 portion of the observations. The System 2 standard deviations is ignored. This option is only valid for nonlinear least squares models.

member.name: F:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.LeastSquaresWeightsUsageConstants.cslswSystem2Only
member.summary: The System 2 standard deviations are used to weight the System 2 portion of the observations. The System 1 standard deviations are ignored.

member.name: F:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.LeastSquaresWeightsUsageConstants.cslswSystem1AndSystem2
member.summary: Both the System 1 and System 2 standard deviations are used to weight the observations. This option is only valid for non-linear least squares models.

member.name: T:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.LeastSquaresObservationConstants
member.summary: The LeastSquaresObservationConstants enumeration is used with the Observation.Type property as the list of options available for specifying the observation type.

member.name: F:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.LeastSquaresObservationConstants.cslsoCheckPoint
member.summary: The observation is not used to calculate the least squares transformation. However, statistics such as residuals may still be obtained regarding the observation, which may prove useful in checking that the transformation performs as desired.

member.name: F:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.LeastSquaresObservationConstants.cslsoControlPoint
member.summary: The observation is used to calculate the least squares transformation. Statistics such as residuals are also available.

member.name: T:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSAzimuthDefinitionModeConstants
member.summary: The CSAzimuthDefinitionModeConstants enumeration is used with the ProjSpace.AzimuthDefinitionMode property as the list of options available for specifying how the azimuth angle projection parameter is defined.

member.name: F:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSAzimuthDefinitionModeConstants.csadmDirect
member.summary: Azimuth value at specified location for projection may be set or retrieved directly.

member.name: F:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSAzimuthDefinitionModeConstants.csadmByTwoPoints
member.summary:
Azimuth value at specified location for projection is defined by providing the coordinates of two points.
For Oblique Mercator the longitude and latitude of two points along the central line are used. For Local Space Rectangular the longitude, latitude, and geometric height of two points are used. For both projections neither point is required to coincide with the location at which the azimuth angle is measured.

member.name: T:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSGeographicHemisphereSelectionConstants
member.summary: The CSGeographicHemisphereSelectionConstants enumeration is used with the ProjSpace.HemisphereVal property as the list of options available for the hemisphere projection parameter.

member.name: F:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSGeographicHemisphereSelectionConstants.csghsNorthern
member.summary: Northern hemisphere

member.name: F:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSGeographicHemisphereSelectionConstants.csghsSouthern
member.summary: Southern hemisphere

member.name: T:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSProjectionAlgorithmConstants
member.summary: The CSProjectionAlgorithmConstants enumeration is used with the ProjSpace.ProjAlgorithmVal property as the list of options available for defining the algorithm used to transform points between the geographic and projection reference spaces.

member.name: F:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSProjectionAlgorithmConstants.cspaUndefined
member.summary: No algorithm is defined for transforming coordinates between geographic and projection reference spaces. Sometimes referenced as Rectangular Grid.

member.name: F:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSProjectionAlgorithmConstants.cspaMercator
member.summary: Mercator. Conformal and cylindrical; meridians are equally spaced, straight, parallel lines; parallels are unequally spaced, straight, parallel lines which are closest near the Equator; used for navigation and conformal mapping of regions near Equator.

member.name: F:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSProjectionAlgorithmConstants.cspaLambert
member.summary: Lambert Conformal Conic. Area and shape are distorted away from standard parallels; conformal except at the poles.

member.name: F:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSProjectionAlgorithmConstants.cspaNorthPolar
member.summary: North Polar Stereographic.

member.name: F:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSProjectionAlgorithmConstants.cspaSouthPolar
member.summary: South Polar Stereographic.

member.name: F:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSProjectionAlgorithmConstants.cspaSimpleCylindrical
member.summary: Simple Cylindrical (Plate Carree).

member.name: F:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSProjectionAlgorithmConstants.cspaTransverseMercator
member.summary: Transverse Mercator. Cconformal and cylindrical; used for conformal mapping of regions having predominantly north-south extent.

member.name: F:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSProjectionAlgorithmConstants.cspaUniversalTransverseMercator
member.summary: Universal Transverse Mercator. World-wide system which divides the surface of the Earth into 60 zones, each 6 degrees wide and mapped by the Transverse Mercator projection with a central meridian in the center of the zone. Other parameters are also preset.

member.name: F:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSProjectionAlgorithmConstants.cspaIndonesianPoly
member.summary: Indonesian Polyhedric.

member.name: F:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSProjectionAlgorithmConstants.cspaSPCS27
member.summary: State Plane Coordinate System 1927.

member.name: F:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSProjectionAlgorithmConstants.cspaPolyconic
member.summary: Polyconic. Based on multiple cones, each tangent to a parallel; central meridian is straight; other meridians are complex curves; parallels are non-concentric circular arcs; scale is true along each parallel and along the central meridian.

member.name: F:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSProjectionAlgorithmConstants.cspaAlbers
member.summary: Albers Equal Area. Conic; distorts scale and distance except along standard parallels; area measurements are not distorted; used for maps of the United States and equal area mapping of regions having predominantly east-west extent.

member.name: F:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSProjectionAlgorithmConstants.cspaObliqueMercator
member.summary: Oblique Mercator.

member.name: F:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSProjectionAlgorithmConstants.cspaNewZealand
member.summary: New Zealand Map Grid.

member.name: F:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSProjectionAlgorithmConstants.cspaVanDerGrinten
member.summary: Van der Grinten.

member.name: F:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSProjectionAlgorithmConstants.cspaAzimuthalEquidistant
member.summary: Azimuthal Equidistant. Equidistant - the distance between any two points on a straight line passing through the center of the projection is shown at true scale; can view the entire Earth; used in the polar aspect for maps of polar regions, and the Northern and Southern Hemispheres; sometimes used to show air route distances.

member.name: F:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSProjectionAlgorithmConstants.cspaOrthographic
member.summary: Orthographic. Neither conformal nor equal area; scale is true at the center and along any circle centered on the projection center, but only in the direction of the circumference of the circle; a perspective projection of the globe onto a tangent plane from an infinite distance - it has the look of a globe; all great or small circles are shown as elliptical arcs or straight lines; frequently used for views of the Earth as would be seen from space; can cover no more than one hemisphere at a time.

member.name: F:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSProjectionAlgorithmConstants.cspaSPCS83
member.summary: State Plane Coordinate System 1983.

member.name: F:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSProjectionAlgorithmConstants.cspaStereographic
member.summary: Stereographic. Conformal; scale is true only where the central parallel and latitude cross; all great and small circles are shown as circular arcs or straight lines; a perspective projection of the globe onto a tangent (or secant) plane from a point on the surface just opposite the point of tangency or the projection center; used in the polar aspect for topographic maps of polar regions.

member.name: F:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSProjectionAlgorithmConstants.cspaGnomonic
member.summary: Gnomonic. Neither conformal nor equal area; a perspective projection from the center of the globe onto a tangent plane at the central point of the projection; used by navigators and aviators because great-circle paths (shortest distances) are shown as straight lines; scale is true only where the central parallel and meridian cross.

member.name: F:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSProjectionAlgorithmConstants.cspaRobinson
member.summary: Robinson. Based on tables of coordinates, not mathematical formulas; distorts shape, area, scale, and distance in an attempt to balance the errors of projections and look right.

member.name: F:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSProjectionAlgorithmConstants.cspaCassini
member.summary: Cassini-Soldner. Cylindrical and equidistant; scale true along central meridian and along any straight line perpendicular to central meridian.

member.name: F:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSProjectionAlgorithmConstants.cspaSinusoidal
member.summary: Sinusoidal. Equal area; has straight parallels at right angles to a straight central meridian; other meridians are sinusoidal curves; scale is true only along the central meridian and the parallels.

member.name: F:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSProjectionAlgorithmConstants.cspaLambertAzimuthalEqArea
member.summary: Lambert Azimuthal Equal Area. Equal area; can view the entire Earth; scale is true only at the center but in all directions; frequently used in the polar aspect in atlases for maps of polar regions and of the Northern and Southern Hemispheres; the equatorial aspect is used for atlas maps of the Eastern and Western Hemispheres; the oblique aspect is used for atlas maps of continents and oceans; recommended for equal area maps of regions that are nearly circular.

member.name: F:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSProjectionAlgorithmConstants.cspaMillerCyl
member.summary: Miller Cylindrical. Neither conformal nor equal area; straight meridians and parallels that meet at right angles; shapes and areas are distorted, except at the Equator; directions are true only along the Equator.

member.name: F:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSProjectionAlgorithmConstants.cspaBonne
member.summary: Bonne. Pseudoconic and equal area; free of distortion along the central meridian and the central parallel.

member.name: F:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSProjectionAlgorithmConstants.cspaBritNGrid
member.summary: British National Grid.

member.name: F:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSProjectionAlgorithmConstants.cspaMollweide
F:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSProjectionAlgorithmConstants.cspaLocalSpaceRect
member.summary: Local Space Rectangular.

member.name: F:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSProjectionAlgorithmConstants.cspaUniversalPolarStereo
member.summary: Universal Polar Stereographic.

member.name: F:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSProjectionAlgorithmConstants.cspaRectifiedSkewOrthomorphic
member.summary: Rectified Skew Orthomorphic.

member.name: F:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSProjectionAlgorithmConstants.cspaIMWModPolycon
member.summary: Modified Polyconic (IMW Series). Used for quadrangle maps in the International Map of the World series; neither conformal nor equal area.

member.name: F:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSProjectionAlgorithmConstants.cspaObliqueLambert
member.summary: Oblique Lambert Conformal Conic.

member.name: F:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSProjectionAlgorithmConstants.cspaChamberlinTrimetric
member.summary: Chamberlin Trimetric.

member.name: F:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSProjectionAlgorithmConstants.cspaCylEquirect
member.summary: Cylindrical Equirectangular. Meridians are equally spaced; parallels are equally spaced, perpendicular to and with wider spacing than the meridians; often used for siimple outline or index maps.

member.name: F:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSProjectionAlgorithmConstants.cspaGeneralPerspective
member.summary: General Perspective.

member.name: F:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSProjectionAlgorithmConstants.cspaConic
member.summary: Equidistant Conic (Simple Conic). Neither conformal nor equal area; equally spaced parallels; direction, area, and shape are distorted away from the standard parallels.

member.name: F:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSProjectionAlgorithmConstants.cspaStereo3Step
member.summary: Three-Step Stereographic.

member.name: F:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSProjectionAlgorithmConstants.cspaGaussKruger
member.summary: Gauss-Kruger.

member.name: F:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSProjectionAlgorithmConstants.cspaBIPOCC
member.summary: Bipolar Oblique Conic Conformal. Conic and conformal; designed specifically for a map of North and South America.

member.name: F:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSProjectionAlgorithmConstants.cspaLaborde
member.summary: Laborde.

member.name: F:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSProjectionAlgorithmConstants.cspaEckertIV
member.summary: Eckert IV. Used for world maps; pseudocylindrical and equal area; central meridian is straight; the 180th meridians are semi-circles; other meridians are elliptical; scale is true at the central meridian at 40:30 North and South.

member.name: F:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSProjectionAlgorithmConstants.cspaSpaceObliqueMercator
member.summary: Space Oblique Mercator.

member.name: F:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSProjectionAlgorithmConstants.cspaSpaceObliqueMercatorPS
member.summary: Space Oblique Mercator. Preset Satellites.

member.name: F:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSProjectionAlgorithmConstants.cspaKrovak
member.summary: Krovak.

member.name: F:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSProjectionAlgorithmConstants.cspaSwitzerlandLV03
member.summary: Switzerland LV03 - Oblique projection with preset parameters; uses CH1903 datum.

member.name: F:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSProjectionAlgorithmConstants.cspaSwitzerlandLV95
member.summary: Switzerland LV95 - Oblique projection with preset parameters; uses CH1903+ datum.

member.name: T:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.UnitConstants
member.summary: The UnitConstants enumeration is used with many methods of the UnitsOfMeasure object for specifying a unit identification number (UnitID) from the set of numbers which correspond to the set of unit aliases defined by the delivered system.
member.remarks: If you have added a user-defined unit of measure ID, you may cast the integer value to this enumeration to pass it to a function that accepts a UnitConstants value.

member.name: T:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSTransDirectionConstants
member.summary:
The CSTransDirectionConstants enumeration is used with the TransLinks.Append method as the list of options available for specifying the transformation direction which the Append method should use in determining its ability to strengthen the transformation chain, when the option to so strengthen has been specified.
Currently the only strengthening performed by the TransLinks.Append method is the addition of a datum transformation link between two coordinate system links. Because all such datum transformations currently available are bidirectional and transformation between two coordinate systems is also bidirectional, the TransLinks.Append method currently ignores its direction parameter. Users should specify cstdForward for the required parameter.

member.name: T:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.ComplexPolynomial
member.summary: The ComplexPolynomial object defines parameters for the Complex Polynomial datum transformation model. The Complex Polynomial model defines a combined grid/datum transformation between grid coordinates of specific local coordinate systems and projection coordinates of specific mapping coordinate systems.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.ComplexPolynomial.ComplexPolyModelTypeStrings
member.summary: Returns a collection that enumerates the list of available complex polynomial models. This enumeration is the set of possible values for the ModelTypeStr property.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.ComplexPolynomial.ModelTypeStr
member.summary:
Sets the local coordinate system transformation model used by the ComplexPolynomial object by specifying a character string from a standard list of local coordinate system transformation model character string names. This property also returns the character string for the currently assigned local coordinate system transformation model.
If you use the ModelTypeStr property to set the local coordinate system transformation model, the string you assign to this property must be an alphanumeric character string that matches one of those within the ComplexPolyModelTypeStrings collection.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.ComplexPolynomial.ModelTypeVal
member.summary: Sets the local coordinate system transformation model used by the ComplexPolynomial object by assigning a predefined model constant to the property. This property also returns the constant value for the currently assigned local coordinate system transformation model.

member.name: T:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTComputeMarkerLocation
member.summary: The Intergraph G/Technology IGTComputeMarkerLocation Interface calculates the projected geographic point for the given detail marker location point.

member.summary: Method to compute the marker location for each input candidate feature.

The input stop criteria value

member.name: T:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTComputeGeoPoint
member.summary: The Intergraph G/Technology IGTComputeGeoPoint Interface calculates the projected geographic point for the given detail marker location point.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTComputeGeoPoint.Compute(ADODB.Recordset)
member.summary: Method to compute the projected geo point for the marker location.
member.remarks:
This method is used if the point calculated exists in the detail window and needs to be projected back to the geographic.
The input recordset structure is similar to the output recordset of the IGTComputeMarkerLocation interface.
The output recordset is a clone of the input recordset with the detail points appended to it.
member.param: Contains all the information necessary to determine the alternate geo point for a given detail component of a feature

member.summary: Property to return/set the metadata-defined arguments for this interface.
