member.remarks: Since the interface can be launched by the Net or desktop application, this property indicates the appropriate database.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTLoopMakeup.PostProcess(ADODB.Recordset,System.String@)
member.summary: Method called after a successful loop makeup has been performed.
member.remarks:
This method allows you to output the results of a loop makeup to a post process and embellish the report as you see fit.
Additional analytics can be performed on a loop makeup result to provide feedback about potential issues in a network. The loop-makeup-result recordset is provided to the method so that you can provide a string containing an error or warning message pertinent to the loop. The string will be included in the output recordset and may be displayed in a report.
member.param: The loop makeup output recordset containing the results of the loop.
Returns a string containing failures that will be reported to the user at the bottom of the loop makeup report. Use newline string ("\r\n") as separator string between faliure strings.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTLoopMakeup.ProcessFeature(ADODB.Recordset,ADODB.Recordset,System.String@,System.Double@,System.Double@,System.Double@,System.Double@,System.Double@,System.Double@,System.Double@,System.Double@,System.Double@)
member.summary: Method called when any feature defined in the G3E_LMUFeature metadata table is encountered in the network.
member.remarks:
The Loop Makeup command continues to process all the features it supports, but you can override the default calculations with your own calculations or add new features to Loop Makeup.
As Loop Makeup walks the traced network from the starting point to the ending point, feature by feature, the processor is called. The feature processor can specify the following:
Any change to the total length, total resistance, or total loss.
Any length, resistance, or loss that will be added to the totals and included as part of the output recordset.
Any length, resistance, or loss that will be added to the build out totals and included as part of the output recordset.
Any custom annotation for the feature on the report.
member.param: The recordset of input parameters to the command. See LMUInput Recordset structure below.
The feature recordset currently being processed and on the correct row.
The description to annotate in the output recordset. This is set by the command but may be overwritten by the interface.
Returns the calculated resistance the current feature applies to the total buildout loss.
Returns the calculated resistance the current feature applies to the total buildout resistance.
Returns the calculated resistance the current feature applies to the total buildout length.
Returns the calculated loss the current feature applies to the total network loss. This value is automatically added to the total loss by the loop makeup command.
Returns the calculated resistance the current feature applies to the total network resistance. This value is automatically added to the total resistance by the loop makeup command.
Returns the calculated length the current feature applies to the total network length. This value is automatically added to the total length by the loop makeup command.
The current total accumulated loss which may be reset by the interface.
The current total accumulated resistance which may be reset by the interface.
The current total accumulated length which may be reset by the interface.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.Interfaces.IGTLoopMakeup.ReportTitle(ADODB.Recordset,System.String@)
member.summary: Method called after a successful loop makeup and before the post process has been performed. This method provides a mechanism to override the Loop Makeup report title.
member.remarks: This method could be used, for example, to retrieve the address of the starting feature.
member.param: The loop makeup output recordset containing the results of the loop.
Specifies and returns the title for the loop makeup report.

member.name: T:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.UnitsOfMeasure
member.summary:
The UnitsOfMeasure object performs conversions between units of measure and manages user-defined measurement units.
The UnitsOfMeasure object contains predefined measurement units, such as meter and square miles. Measurement units are grouped by unit categories (distance, volume, mass, and so forth), which are also predefined. Each unit category has a base unit such as meters for distance. All other units in the category are defined by their relationships to this base unit.
Unit categories and measurement units have a name and an identification number. The name describes the unit category or measurement unit.
Example: Distance is a category name, and ft (for feet) is a measurement unit name.
The identification number is an integer value which may correspond to a predefined constant. Constants exist for unit categories and for measurement units.
Example: IgUnitAngle (integer value = 2) is the identification number for the angle unit category; igAngleRadian (integer value = 77) is the identification number for the radian unit of measure.
The UnitsOfMeasure object also contains methods for creating measurement units but not unit categories. These are called user-defined units. The purpose of user-defined units is to create units of measure that are not included in the predefined units.
Example If a distance unit is needed for half meters, a user-defined unit could be created.
User-defined units must be created for existing unit categories. They also must have a linear relationship (conversion factor) with the unit category's base unit.
Example With the distance type, the half meter unit would have a conversion factor of 0.5, which is the number of base units (meters) in a half meter.
User-defined units also allow offsets.
Example With the temperature type, the relationship between Celsius and the base Kelvin units is defined by an offset of 273.15.
User-defined measurement units are saved in the system registry and may be loaded from the registry during subsequent invocations of an application. Loading brings into the run-time system the unit identification numbers which are used to return the unit name, perform conversion, and allow deletions of user-defined units only.
The identification numbers for user-defined units are unique integer values which are generated when the units are first created. These numbers are in a different range from the predefined constants for the predefined units.

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.UnitsOfMeasure.AddUserDefinedUnit(Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.UnitTypeConstants,System.String,System.Double,System.Double,System.String,System.String)
member.summary:
The AddUserDefinedUnit method defines a unit of measure that is not available in the set of predefined units. This method adds the new unit to a specified unit category (type).
Besides the unit category, the AddUserDefinedUnit method requires a conversion factor. The conversion factor is the ratio between the unit being defined and the unit category's base unit of measure (such as meters). Furthermore, an offset can be specified. The return value of this method is the unit ID of the new unit.
The last requirement for defining a new unit is the application name and version number. These values help define the registry path where the information is stored, which allows the LoadUserDefinedUnits method to locate the new unit information through the registry during subsequent invocations of the application.
member.param: The measurement category (type). Values for this parameter are Unit TypeConstants.
The name for the unit being added

A conversion factor between the unit being added and the base unit of the measurement category. The base unit is multiplied by the value supplied in this parameter. For example, if the measurement category is linear (base units are meters), a value of 1.5 defines the new unit as 1.5 times the length of a meter.
Note: The GetCompBaseUnit method returns the base unit.
Provides an offset to the conversion. For example, converting between Celsius and Fahrenheit requires an offset of 32. Most units do not require an offset. Therefore, set this parameter to zero.
The application name string. This parameter helps determine the registry path for measurement unit information.
The application version string. This parameter helps determine the registry path for measurement unit information.

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.UnitsOfMeasure.ConvertUnitToUnit(Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.UnitTypeConstants,System.Double,Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.UnitConstants,Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.UnitConstants)
member.summary:
The ConvertUnitToUnit method converts a value from one unit of measure to another unit of measure such as feet to meters. This method requires the unit category (distance, area, volume, and so forth), the value to convert, and the input and output units for input.
Input and output units are specified by constants. Acceptable constants depend on the specified unit category. Refer to the Remarks section for information on determining acceptable units.
member.remarks:
The From and To units must both belong to the specified unit category. For example, feet and meters are both acceptable units for the distance unit category, but not for the mass unit category.
The GetUnitIDs method returns a list of acceptable units for a specified unit category. This method creates a UnitIDs collection object. The UnitIDs.Count property returns the total number of units applicable to the unit category. The UnitIDs.Item method returns individual unit identification numbers (unit names can be returned by supplying a unit identification number as a parameter to the GetUnitName method).
member.param: The measurement category (type).
The value to convert.

The unit identification number corresponding to the unit (meters, feet, radians, and so forth) of the input value. This value must be for a unit that is applicable for the unit category specified by the UnitType parameter. This value may be either a member of the UnitConstants predefined list or the integer value returned from a previous call to the AddUserDefinedUnit method.

The unit identification number corresponding to the unit (meters, feet, radians, and so forth) of the output (converted) value. This value must be for a unit that is applicable for the unit category specified by the UnitType parameter. This value may be either a member of the UnitConstants predefined list or the integer value returned from a previous call to the AddUserDefinedUnit method.
member.returns: The converted value.

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.UnitsOfMeasure.DeleteUserDefinedUnit(Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.UnitTypeConstants,System.Int32,System.String,System.String)
member.summary:
The DeleteUserDefinedUnit method deletes a user-specified unit. A user-specified unit is a measurement unit created by the AddUserDefinedUnit method.
The DeleteUserDefinedUnit method requires the unit category (type), unit identification number, and the application name and version information as input parameters. The unit category and unit identification number specify the measurement unit to delete. The application name and version allow the method to locate the information to delete in the registry.
member.remarks: Only units previously created with the AddUserDefinedUnit method can be deleted. An attempt to delete using a UnitID of a predefined unit produces an error.
member.param: The measurement category (type).
The unit identification number of the user-defined unit to delete.
The application name string. This parameter helps determine the registry path for measurement unit information.
The application version string. This parameter helps determine the registry path for measurement unit information.

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.UnitsOfMeasure.GetCompBaseUnit(Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.UnitTypeConstants)
member.summary:
The GetCompBaseUnit method returns the value of the unit constant corresponding to a specified unit category's base unit.
Example:
The base unit for the distance unit category is meters. Therefore, the GetCompBaseUnit method returns a value of igDistanceMeter (59) for a unit type of igUnitDistance (1).
member.param: The measurement category (type).

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.UnitsOfMeasure.GetUnitID(Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.UnitTypeConstants,System.String,System.Object)
member.summary:
The GetUnitID method returns the unit identification number of a specified unit. This method requires the unit type (time, distance, and so forth) and the unit name (rad, m, and so forth) as input. This method can also be made case-sensitive.
The value returned from the GetUnitID method is a value which either corresponds to a UnitConstants entry (in the case of predefined units) or was previously returned from a call to the AddUserDefinedUnit method.
member.param: The measurement category (type).
The name (ft, in, and so forth) of the measurement unit whose identification number is being returned. If CaseFlag is true, this string must match the standard unit name's case exactly.
Specifes if the method is to be case sensitive. If this parameter is True, then the UnitName must match in case.
member.returns: Unit identification number

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.UnitsOfMeasure.GetUnitIDs(Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.UnitTypeConstants)
member.summary: The GetUnitIDs method returns a collection of all unit identification numbers that are applicable for a specified unit category. The collection is returned as a UnitIDs object.
member.remarks: The UnitIDs.Count property returns the total number of units applicable to the unit category. The UnitIDs indexer property can return individual unit identification numbers (unit names can be obtained by supplying a unit identification as a parameter to the GetUnitName method).
member.param: The measurement category (type).
member.returns: The set of units belonging to the specified category.

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.UnitsOfMeasure.GetUnitIDs(Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.UnitTypeConstants,Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSUnitConstants)
member.summary: The GetUnitIDs method returns a collection of all unit identification numbers that are applicable for a specified unit category. The collection is returned as a UnitIDs object.
member.remarks: The UnitIDs.Count property returns the total number of units applicable to the unit category. The UnitIDs indexer property can return individual unit identification numbers (unit names can be obtained by supplying a unit identification as a parameter to the GetUnitName method).
member.param: The measurement category (type).
The kind of units desired within the specified category.
member.returns: The set of units belonging to the specified category matching the specified filter.

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.UnitsOfMeasure.GetUnitName(Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.UnitConstants)
member.summary:
The GetUnitName method returns the unit name for a specified unit identification number.
Example:
The GetUnitName method returns the name "mm" for a unit identification number of 61.
member.remarks: A typical use of the GetUnitName method is within a loop to create a list of measurement unit names for a selected unit category.
member.param: The unit identification number for the unit whose name is to be returned. This value may be either a member of the UnitConstants predefined list or the value returned from a previous call to the AddUserDefinedUnit method.

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.UnitsOfMeasure.LoadUserDefinedUnits(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: The LoadUserDefinedUnits method reads the user-defined measurement units from the registry and adds them to the applicable unit categories.
member.remarks: Typically the LoadUserDefinedUnits method is called once during application startup, so that any user-defined units previously added to the application are available during the current session.
member.param: The application name string. This parameter helps determine the registry path for measurement unit information.
The application version string. This parameter helps determine the registry path for measurement unit information.

member.name: T:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.StandardMolodensky
member.summary: The StandardMolodensky object defines parameters for the Standard Molodensky datum transformation model. The Standard Molodensky model defines the transformation between geodetic coordinates of different datums. The model involves three translations between respective geocentric systems. This model is an approximation of the Three-parameter Shift model.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.StandardMolodensky.DeltaEquatorialRad
member.summary: The DeltaEquatorialRad property defines the difference between the equatorial radius of the forward output reference ellipsoid and the equatorial radius of the forward input reference ellipsoid for the StandardMolodensky object.
member.remarks: This property is always in meters.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.StandardMolodensky.DeltaFlattening
member.summary: The DeltaFlattening property defines the difference between the flattening of the forward output reference ellipsoid and the flattening of the forward input reference ellipsoid for the StandardMolodensky object.
member.remarks: This property is unitless.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.StandardMolodensky.DeltaX
member.summary: The DeltaX property defines the geocentric X shift between the centers of the forward input reference ellipsoid and the forward output reference ellipsoid for the StandardMolodensky object.
member.remarks: This property is always in meters.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.StandardMolodensky.DeltaY
member.summary: The DeltaY property defines the geocentric Y shift between the centers of the forward input reference ellipsoid and the forward output reference ellipsoid for the StandardMolodensky object.
member.remarks: This property is always in meters.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.StandardMolodensky.DeltaZ
member.summary: The DeltaZ property defines the geocentric Z shift between the centers of the forward input reference ellipsoid and the forward output reference ellipsoid for the StandardMolodensky object.
member.remarks: This property is always in meters.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.StandardMolodensky.EllipsoidStrings
member.summary: The EllipsoidStrings property returns the EllipsoidStrings collection object for a GeogSpace or StandardMolodensky object. This is a snapshot of the names of all the ellipsoids supported at the time of the object's creation.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.StandardMolodensky.ForwardInputSpaceEccentricity
member.summary: The ForwardInputSpaceEccentricity property defines the eccentricity for the forward input space reference ellipsoid for the StandardMolodensky object. This property is unitless.
member.remarks:
This property can be set only if the ForwardInputSpaceEllipsoidVal and ForwardInputSpaceEllipsoidStr are set to the user-defined reference ellipsoid.
The ForwardInputSpaceEccentricity property accepts a value equal or greater than 0.0 and less than 1.0. Setting this property to less than 0.0 or to 1.0 or greater produces an error
Setting the reference ellipsoid to any value other than User-defined automatically sets the eccentricity ellipsoid parameter.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.StandardMolodensky.ForwardInputSpaceEllipsoidStr
member.summary:
The ForwardInputSpaceEllipsoidStr property sets the forward input space reference ellipsoid used by the StandardMolodensky object by specifying a character string from a standard list of ellipsoid character string names. This property also returns the character string for the currently assigned forward input space reference ellipsoid.
If you use the ForwardInputSpaceEllipsoidStr property to set the forward input space reference ellipsoid, the string you assign to this property must be an alphanumeric character string that matches one of those within the EllipsoidStrings collection.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.StandardMolodensky.ForwardInputSpaceEllipsoidVal
member.summary: The ForwardInputSpaceEllipsoidVal property sets the forward input space reference ellipsoid used by the StandardMolodensky object by assigning a predefined reference ellipsoid constant to the property. This property also returns the constant value for the currently assigned forward input space reference ellipsoid.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.StandardMolodensky.ForwardInputSpaceEquatorialRad
member.summary: The ForwardInputSpaceEquatorialRad property defines the equatorial radius for the forward input space reference ellipsoid for the StandardMolodensky object. This property is always in meters.
member.remarks:
The ForwardInputSpaceEquatorialRad property value must be greater than 0.0.
This property can be set only if the ForwardInputSpaceEllipsoidVal and ForwardInputSpaceEllipsoidStr are set to the user-defined reference ellipsoid.

member.name: T:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTArcGeometry
member.summary: The GTArcGeometry object represents a circular arc. Arcs are defined by a starting point, an ending point, a radius, a normal vector, and a "greater than pi" flag. By defining the arc this way, we guarantee that the starting and ending points are exact, which provides accurate "meeting points" with other line and arc geometries in a linear feature.

Perpendicular bisector of the chord which connects the arc endpoints.

member.summary: Returns the length of half of the chord connecting the endpoints of the arc, the midpoint of that chord, and the perpendicular bisector of that chord. member.summary: Returns an arc with the specified origin (center point), normal vector, and radius, where the starting point of the arc is at the specified (measured relative to the x-axis) from the origin, and the ending point of the arc is at the specified (measured relative to the ) from the origin.
member.param: The center of the circle containing the arc.
The normal vector of the arc, which determines the plane containing the arc as well as the direction of sweep.
The radius of the cicle containing the arc.
The angle, in radians, formed by the line joining the origin to the starting point of the arc, measured relative to the positive x-axis.
The angle, in radians, formed by the two radii joining the origin to the starting and ending points of the arc.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTArcGeometry.ComputeArcByRadiusAndTangents(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPoint,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPoint,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPoint,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPoint,System.Double)
member.summary:
Returns an arc with the specified . The given tangent points determine two lines that are tangent to the arc at the arc's starting and ending points. Note that the lines are extended in either direction as far as necessary to be tangent to the arc.
If no arc can be determined from the given input values, the ArgumentOutOfRangeException is thrown. For example, if the given lines are parallel, a unique arc is not determinable.
member.remarks:
The start point of the arc is on extended line (Start1, End1) and its end point is on extended line (Start2, End2). The tangent of the arc at its start point is the same as the angle of (Start1, End1). The tangent of the arc at its end point is the same as the angle of (Start2, End2). The arc has the radius specified by the Radius input parameter.
If this function is used to compute a fillet arc, the caller may need to perform additional validation of the input parameters based on what is considered to be a fillet in the workflow being implemented.
If computing a fillet arc, the custom code may also need to validate whether the output arc is a valid fillet in the workflow being implemented.
Positional tolerance must be greater than zero for all calculations to complete successfully.
member.param: Starting point of the first tangent line.
Ending point of the first tangent line.
Starting point of the second tangent line.
Ending point of the second tangent line.
The radius of the cicle containing the arc.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTArcGeometry.ComputeArcByPointAndTangents(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPoint,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPoint,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPoint,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPoint)
member.summary:
This function is similar to ComputeArcByRadiusAndTangents, except that the second given point, , represents the endpoint of the first tangent line and the starting point of the arc.
If no arc can be determined from the given input values, the ArgumentOutOfRangeException is thrown.
member.remarks:
The start point of the arc is identical with End1 and the end point of the arc is on the extended line (Start2, End2). The tangent of arc at its start point is the same as the angle of the line (Start1, End1). The tangent of arc at its end point is the same as the angle of the line (Start2, End2).
When the lines (Start1, End1) and (Start2, End2) are parallel (but not collinear), the end point of the arc is calculated as an intersection of the extended line Start2, End2 and the line perpendicular to (Start1, End1) passing through End1.
If this function is used to compute a fillet arc, the caller may need to perform additional validation of the input parameters based on what is considered to be a fillet in the workflow being implemented.
If computing a fillet arc, the custom code may also need to validate whether the output arc is a valid fillet in the workflow being implemented.
Positional tolerance must be greater than zero for all calculations to complete successfully.
member.param: Starting point of the first tangent line.
Ending point of the first tangent line and starting point of the arc.
Starting point of the second tangent line.
Ending point of the second tangent line.
member.returns: Returns an arc

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTArcGeometry.ComputeArcsBy2PointsAndRadius(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPoint,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPoint,System.Double)
member.summary:
Returns an array of GTArcGeometry objects representing all possible arcs with the given starting point, ending point, and radius. The returned array may have 0, 2, or 4 elements, depending on the relationship between the given radius and the distance between the and points:
Number of arcsCondition
0 Given radius is greater than the distance between and .
2 Given radius is exactly equal to the distance between and . Each arc is a semicircle.
4 Given radius is less than the distance between and . The 4 arcs form two circles that intersect at the given points.
The length of the returned array can be used to determine how many arcs were computed.
member.remarks: Positional tolerance must be greater than zero for all calculations to complete successfully.
member.param: Starting point of the arc.
Ending point of the arc.
Radius of the circle containing the arc.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTArcGeometry.ComputeArcBy2PointsAndTangent(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPoint,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPoint,System.Double)
member.summary:
Returns an arc with the given starting and ending points, where the tangent line to the arc at the starting point forms an angle of radians with the positive x-axis.
Note that ComputeArcBy2PointsAndTangent(p1, p2, angle) and ComputeArcBy2PointsAndTangent(p1, p2, angle+pi) yield complementary arcs that form a complete circle.
If no arc can be determined from the given input values, the ArgumentOutOfRangeException is thrown. For example, if the angle formed by the line through and is equal to , no arc can be computed.
member.remarks: Positional tolerance must be greater than zero for all calculations to complete successfully.
member.param: Starting point of the arc.
Ending point of the arc.
Angle between the arc starting point tangent and positive x-axis.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTArcGeometry.Intersect(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTSegment)
member.summary: Computes the intersection(s) between this arc and the given segment. If the segment's IsExtended property is true, then the intersections include any intersections with the extension of the segment. The returned array may contain zero, one, or two elements. If any intersections are returned, their Type property will either be gtsptOnSegment or gtsptOnExtendedSegment.
member.param: GTSegment given for intersection computation.
member.returns: An array of Intersection points between the arc and a given segment

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTArcGeometry.Intersect(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTArcGeometry)
member.summary: Computes the intersection(s) between this arc and the given arc. The returned array may contain zero, one, or two elements. If the arcs overlap, then one element will be returned with a Type property of gtsptOverlap. Otherwise, the Type property of all returned elements (if any) will be gtsptOnSegment.
member.param: GTArcGeometry given for intersection computation.
member.returns: An array of Intersection points between the arc and a given arc

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTArcGeometry.Start
member.summary: Returns or sets the starting point of the arc.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTArcGeometry.End
member.summary: Returns or sets the ending point of the arc.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTArcGeometry.Radius
member.summary: Returns or sets the radius of the arc.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTArcGeometry.Normal
member.summary:
Returns or sets the normal vector for the arc. The normal vector determines the direction of the arc's sweep as well as the plane of the arc. The sweep direction follows the right-hand rule for vectors. For example, a normal of [0, 0, 1] (in the positive Z-direction) determines an arc in the XY-plane that sweeps counter-clockwise.
Given a starting point, and ending point, and a radius, there are an infinite number of possible arcs with those properties. When the arc is restricted to a particular plane by the Normal vector, there are 4 possible arcs -- two that sweep clockwise and two that sweep counter-clockwise. The Normal vector's direction (using the right-hand rule) further narrows these choices to two.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTArcGeometry.GreaterThanPi
member.summary: Returns or sets a Boolean flag determining whether the arc is greater than (true) or less than or equal (false) to a half circle. This flag chooses one of the two possible arcs that pass through the given starting and ending points with the given radius and Normal vector.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTArcGeometry.Origin
member.summary: Returns the center point of this arc. .

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTArcGeometry.MidPoint
member.summary: Returns the midpoint -- the point on the arc halfway between the Start and End points -- of this arc. .

member.name: T:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTSegmentPoint
member.summary: GTSegmentPoint is used by some geometry math functions to return a point with additional information about how the point was computed. GTSegmentPoint may represent the result of an intersection operation (e.g., ) or a projection operation (e.g., ).

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTSegmentPoint.#ctor(Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTPoint,Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTSegmentPoint.GTSegmentPointType)
member.summary: Constructions a GTSegmentPoint with the indicated point and type. The input point is copied, so changes made to the input point will not affect this GTSegmentPoint.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTSegmentPoint.Point
member.summary: Sets or returns the point designated by this object. The set accessor makes a copy of the input point.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTSegmentPoint.Type
member.summary: Sets or returns the type associated with the point.

member.name: T:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTSegmentPoint.GTSegmentPointType
member.summary: GTSegmentPointType conveys additional information about the associated point.

member.name: F:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTSegmentPoint.GTSegmentPointType.gtsptOnSegment
member.summary: For an intersection, indicates that the intersection lies on the two geometries intersected. For a projection, indicates that the projection lies on the target segment.

member.name: F:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTSegmentPoint.GTSegmentPointType.gtsptOnEndpoint
member.summary: Not used for intersections. For a projection, indicates that a perpendicular projection was not possible, so the result is an endpoint of the target segment.

member.name: F:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTSegmentPoint.GTSegmentPointType.gtsptOnExtendedSegment
member.summary: For an intersection, indicates that the intersection lies on the extension of one or both input segments. For a projection, indicates that the projection lies on an extension of the target segment.

member.name: F:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTSegmentPoint.GTSegmentPointType.gtsptOverlap
member.summary: Not used for projections. For an intersection, indicates that the input geometries overlap in an infinite number of points.

member.name: T:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CoordSystem
member.summary:
The CoordSystem object defines characteristics of a GIS coordinate system. These characteristics include the storage resolution, range and tie to the projection, geographic, geocentric and paper reference spaces.
The CoordSystem object also binds the storage to one of these reference spaces and specifies the characteristics of the bond. These characteristics also include how to handle heights (ellipsoidal versus Mean Sea Level, if applicable to the bound reference space).

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CoordSystem.Clone
member.summary: Creates a new CoordSystem object identical to this one.
member.returns: New CoordSystem object

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CoordSystem.ChangeGUID
member.summary: The ChangeGUID method assigns a new unique identifier to the CoordSystem object. The number is automatically generated and can be returned with the GUID property. .
member.remarks: The ChangeGUID method must be used to generate a new GUID for the coordinate system if the coordinate system is modified. This uniquely identifies this coordinate system and distinguishes it from the previous definition.

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CoordSystem.CopyTo(Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CoordSystem)
member.summary: Copies the properties of this CoordSystem object to another CoordSystem object. The CopyTo method is the proper way to modify the CoordSystem object referenced by a CoordSystemsMgr.
member.param: The destination object receiving the copied characteristics

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CoordSystem.FormatGCoordSystemTableRow(System.Object[])
member.summary:
Saves the coordinate system definition into an array of variants representing a row in a GDO coordinate system table.
Units and formatting information contained in the coordinate system’s sub-objects are not a part of this definition (they are not defined in the GDO specification for its coordinate system table).
member.param: An array of variants representing a row in a GDO coordinate system table. This array must be allocated by the caller and sized according to the definition of the GDO coordinate system table.

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CoordSystem.GetApproxHorizDataCenterAsGeocPntVal(System.Double@,System.Double@,System.Double@)
member.summary: Returns the approximate horizontal data center as a geocentric point. This point is returned as double values for the X, Y, and Z geocentric coordinates.
member.param: Geocentric X coordinate of approximate horizontal data center (in meters)
Geocentric Y coordinate of approximate horizontal data center (in meters)
Geocentric Z coordinate of approximate horizontal data center (in meters)
member.remarks: For more information on formatting and parsing geocentric X, Y, and Z values, see the UnitAndFormatSpec object.

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CoordSystem.GetApproxHorizDataCenterAsGeogPntVal(System.Double@,System.Double@)
member.summary: Returns the approximate horizontal data center as a geographic point. This point is returned as double values for the geographic point's longitude and latitude.
member.param: Longitude of approximate horizontal data center (in radians)
Latitude of approximate horizontal data center (in radians)
member.remarks: For more information on formatting and parsing geographic longitude and latitude values, see the UnitAndFormatSpec object.

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CoordSystem.GetApproxHorizDataCenterAsPaperPntVal(System.Double@,System.Double@)
member.summary: Returns the approximate horizontal data center as a paper point. This point is returned as double values for the paper point's X and Y coordinates.
member.param: Paper X coordinate of approximate horizontal data center (in meters)
Paper Y coordinate of approximate horizontal data center (in meters).
member.remarks: For more information on formatting and parsing paper point X and Y values, see the UnitAndFormatSpec object.

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CoordSystem.GetApproxHorizDataCenterAsProjPntVal(System.Double@,System.Double@)
member.summary: Returns the approximate horizontal data center as a projection point. This point is returned as double values for the projection point's X and Y coordinates.
member.param: Projection X coordinate of approximate horizontal data center (in meters)
Projection Y coordinate of approximate horizontal data center (in meters)
member.remarks: For more information on formatting and parsing paper point X and Y values, see the UnitAndFormatSpec object.

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CoordSystem.GetHorizResByAngAlongGroundVal(System.Double@,System.String@)
member.summary: Returns the horizontal resolution as an angle along the surface of the unscaled spherical model of the Earth (ground). The resolution is returned as two components: magnitude and unit. This form mimics the natural language describing data resolution (accuracy), such as the expression "a thousandth of an arc second resolution", where 0.001 would be the magnitude and "sec" would be the unit.

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CoordSystem.GetHorizResByGroundDistVal(System.Double@,System.String@)
member.summary: Returns the horizontal resolution as a distance on the surface of the unscaled spherical model of the Earth (ground distance). The resolution is returned as two components: magnitude and unit. This form mimics the natural language describing data resolution (accuracy), such as the expression "half a centimeter resolution", where 0.5 would be the magnitude and "cm" would be the unit.

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CoordSystem.GetHorizResByPaperDistVal(System.Double@,System.String@)
member.summary: Returns the horizontal resolution in reference to a distance on the paper map. The resolution is returned as two components: magnitude and unit. This form mimics the natural language describing data resolution (accuracy), such as the expression "a 100th of an inch resolution (resolution of my digitizer board)", where 0.01 would be the magnitude and "in" would be the unit.

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CoordSystem.GetStorageMeridianConvergence(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Returns the meridian convergence of the storage reference space at a specified geographic point. This meridian convergence is the angle from the positive Y storage space axis to geographic North.
member.param: In radians
In radians
In Meters
member.returns: Meridian convergence

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CoordSystem.GetVertResByHeightVal(System.Double@,System.String@)
member.summary: Returns the vertical resolution in reference to a height value. The resolution is returned as two components, magnitude and unit. This form mimics the natural language describing data resolution (accuracy), such as the expression "a tenth of a meter resolution for the storage of my heights", where 0.1 would be the magnitude and "m" would be the unit.
member.remarks: For coordinate systems with projected or geographic base storage types, the vertical resolution directly affects the scaling of the Z-storage dimension. For a coordinate system with a geocentric base storage type, the vertical resolution does not directly affect the scaling of the Z-storage dimension. Instead, it is an indicator of the accuracy and resolution of the heights generated from geocentric (X, Y, and Z) data locations.

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CoordSystem.GetVertResByPaperHeightVal(System.Double@,System.String@)
member.summary: Returns the vertical resolution in reference to a paper height. The resolution is returned as two components: magnitude and unit. This form mimics the natural language describing data resolution (accuracy), such as the expression "a thousandth of an inch resolution for the storage of my paper heights", where 0.001 would be the magnitude and "in" would be the unit.
member.remarks: For coordinate systems with projected or geographic base storage types, the vertical resolution directly affects the scaling of the Z-storage dimension. For a coordinate system with a geocentric base storage type, the vertical resolution does not directly affect the scaling of the Z-storage dimension. Instead, it is an indicator of the accuracy and resolution of the heights generated from geocentric (X, Y, and Z) data locations.

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CoordSystem.IsEssentiallyIdentical(Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CoordSystem)
member.summary: Returns true if storage coordinates based on the given coordinate system and this coordinate system would always reference the same location. Characteristics such as base storage type, storage resolution and data center, geodetic datum, paper scale, projection algorithm, and projection algorithm parameters are considered in this comparison, while other characteristics such as I/O units and formatting are not considered.
member.returns: Boolean True or False

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CoordSystem.IsExactlyIdentical(Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CoordSystem)
member.summary: Returns true if all properties of the given coordinate system are equal to this object's properties.
member.returns: Boolean True or False

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CoordSystem.Equals(System.Object)
member.summary: Equivalent to IsExactlyIdentical(obj as CoordSystem).
member.returns: Boolean True or False

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CoordSystem.op_Equality(Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CoordSystem,Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CoordSystem)
member.summary: Equivalent to cs1.IsExactlyIdentical(cs2).
member.returns: Boolean True or False

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CoordSystem.op_Inequality(Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CoordSystem,Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CoordSystem)

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CoordSystem.LoadFromFile(System.String)
member.summary: Loads the coordinate system definition from a file.
member.remarks:
The file from which the coordinate system definition is loaded may be one of two types:
An OLE Structured Storage file which contains a specific coordinate system substorage. These files typically have a .csf extension. Such a file is created by the SaveToFile method.
A MicroStation design file.

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CoordSystem.LoadFromGCoordSystemTableRowFormat(System.Object[])
member.summary: Loads the coordinate system definition from an array of variants representing a row in a GDO database’s Coordinate System table. The retrieved data defines the CoordSystem object accordingly and overwrites its current definition. Units and formatting information contained in the coordinate system’s sub-objects are not a part of this definition (they are not defined in the GDO specification for its coordinate system table).
member.param: A variant array representing a row in a GDO database table. This array consists of fields from a row in a recordset, where the recordset was extracted from the Coordinate System table of a GDO database.

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CoordSystem.LoadFromMGEFileSecondaryCoordSystem(System.String)
member.summary: Loads the coordinate system definition from an MGE design file using the secondary coordinate system of the MGE file.
member.remarks: Both the LoadFromMGEFileSecondaryCoordSystem and LoadFromFile methods extract a coordinate system definition from an MGE design file. The LoadFromFile method uses the MCSO Primary Coordinate System definition if it is present and establishes defaults if it is not. That is, it will accept a vanilla, non-MGE MicroStation design file. It includes design file working units and global origin in its definition. The LoadFromMGEFileSecondaryCoordSystem method uses the MCSO Secondary Coordinate System definition and raises an error if it is not found. It does not include design file working units and global origin in its definition because they do not apply to the MCSO Secondary Coordinate System.

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CoordSystem.LoadUsingPrimaryFromMGEfile(System.String)
member.summary: Equivalent to LoadFromFile when given an MGE file. .

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CoordSystem.SaveToFile(System.String)
member.summary: Writes the coordinate system definition to an OLE Structured Storage file.
member.remarks:
This method writes to an OLE Structured Storage file. If the file does not exist, it is created. If the file already exists, its contents are overwritten.
These coordinate system files typically have a .csf extension. These files are the same type as those created or edited by the DefCSF executable, and may be used as input to the CoordSystem.LoadFromFile method.

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CoordSystem.SetApproxHorizDataCenterAsGeocPntVal(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Defines the approximate horizontal data center using a geocentric point. This method requires values for the geocentric point's X, Y, and Z coordinates as inputs.
member.remarks:
One use of the SetApproxHorizDataCenterAsGeocPntVal method might be in the case of geometries constrained to integer storage, where this method could be used to perform a parallel (rigid) shift of the data, such that the approximate horizontal data center falls at the center of the integer storage range.
Changing the data center after coordinate data has been collected for persistent storage invalidates subsequent coordinate system operations and many operations dependent on the coordinate system, such as measurement.
For more information on formatting and parsing geocentric X, Y, and Z values, see the UnitAndFormatSpec object.
member.param: Geocentric X coordinate in meters of approximate horizontal data center(in meters)
Geocentric Y coordinate in meters of approximate horizontal data center(in meters)
Geocentric Z coordinate in meters of approximate horizontal data center(in meters)

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CoordSystem.SetApproxHorizDataCenterAsGeogPntVal(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Defines the approximate horizontal data center using a geographic point. This method requires values for the geographic point's longitude and latitude as inputs.
member.remarks:
One use of the SetApproxHorizDataCenterAsGeogPntVal method method might be in the case of geometries constrained to integer storage, where this method could be used to perform a parallel (rigid) shift of the data, such that the approximate horizontal data center falls at the center of the integer storage range.
Changing the data center after coordinate data has been collected for persistent storage invalidates subsequent coordinate system operations and many operations dependent on the coordinate system, such as measurement.
For more information on formatting and parsing geographic longitude and latitude values, see the UnitAndFormatSpec object.
member.param: Longitude of approximate horizontal data center (in radians)
Latitude of approximate horizontal data center (in radians)

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CoordSystem.SetApproxHorizDataCenterAsPaperPntVal(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Sets the approximate horizontal data center using a paper point. This method requires values for the paper point's X and Y coordinates as inputs.
member.remarks:
One use of the SetApproxHorizDataCenterAsPaperPntVal method might be in the case of geometries constrained to integer storage, where this method could be used to perform a parallel (rigid) shift of the data, such that the approximate horizontal data center falls at the center of the integer storage range.
Changing the data center after coordinate data has been collected for persistent storage invalidates subsequent coordinate system operations and many operations dependent on the coordinate system, such as measurement.
For more information on formatting and parsing paper X and Y values see the UnitAndFormatSpec object.
member.param: Paper X coordinate of approximate horizontal data center (in meters)
Paper Y coordinate of approximate horizontal data center (in meters)

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CoordSystem.SetApproxHorizDataCenterAsProjPntVal(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Sets the approximate horizontal data center using a projection point. This method requires values for the projection point's X and Y coordinates as inputs.
member.remarks:
One use of the SetApproxHorizDataCenterAsProjPntVal method might be in the case of geometries constrained to integer storage, where this method could be used to perform a parallel (rigid) shift of the data, such that the approximate horizontal data center falls at the center of the integer storage range.
Changing the data center after coordinate data has been collected for persistent storage invalidates subsequent coordinate system operations and many operations dependent on the coordinate system, such as measurement.
For more information on formatting and parsing projection X and Y values, see the UnitAndFormatSpec object.
member.param: Projection X coordinate of approximate horizontal data center (in meters)
Projection Y coordinate of approximate horizontal data center (in meters)

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CoordSystem.SetHorizResByAngAlongGroundVal(System.Double,System.String)
member.summary: Specifies the horizontal storage resolution as an angle along the surface of the unscaled spherical model of the Earth (ground). This method requires the magnitude of the angular distance and the unit name as inputs. This form mimics the natural language describing data resolution (accuracy), such as the expression "a thousandth of an arc second resolution", where 0.001 would be the magnitude and "sec" would be the unit.
member.remarks:
For projected and geographic storage types, horizontal resolution directly affects the uniform scaling of X, Y storage dimensions. For a geocentric storage type, horizontal resolution directly affects the uniform scaling of X, Y, and Z storage dimensions.
Changing the storage resolution after coordinate data has been collected for persistent storage invalidates subsequent coordinate system operations and many operations dependent on the coordinate system, such as measurement.
member.param: This value must be greater than 0.0.

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CoordSystem.SetHorizResByGroundDistVal(System.Double,System.String)
member.summary: Specifies the horizontal storage resolution as a distance on the surface of the unscaled spherical model of the Earth (ground distance). This method requires the magnitude of the linear distance and the linear unit of measure name as inputs. This form mimics the natural language describing data resolution (accuracy), such as the expression "half a centimeter resolution", where 0.5 would be the magnitude and "cm" would be the unit.
member.remarks:
For projected and geographic storage types, horizontal resolution directly affects the uniform scaling of X, Y storage dimensions. For a geocentric storage type, horizontal resolution directly affects the uniform scaling of X, Y, and Z storage dimensions.
Changing the storage resolution after coordinate data has been collected for persistent storage invalidates subsequent coordinate system operations and many operations dependent on the coordinate system, such as measurement.
member.param: This value must be greater than 0.0.

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CoordSystem.SetHorizResByPaperDistVal(System.Double,System.String)
member.summary: Specifies the horizontal storage resolution as a distance on the paper map. This method requires the magnitude of the linear distance and the linear unit of measure name as inputs. This form mimics the natural language describing data resolution (accuracy), such as the expression "a 100th of an inch resolution (resolution of my digitizer board)", where 0.01 would be the magnitude and "in" would be the unit.
member.remarks:
For projected and geographic storage types, horizontal resolution directly affects the (uniform) scaling of X, Y storage dimensions. For a geocentric storage type, horizontal resolution directly affects the (uniform) scaling of X, Y, and Z storage dimensions.
Changing the storage resolution after coordinate data has been collected for persistent storage invalidates subsequent coordinate system operations and many operations dependent on the coordinate system, such as measurement.
member.param: This value must be greater than 0.0.

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CoordSystem.SetVertResByHeightVal(System.Double,System.String)
member.summary: Specifies the vertical storage resolution in reference to a height value. This method requires the magnitude of the height value and the linear unit of measure name as inputs. This form mimics the natural language describing data resolution (accuracy), such as the expression "a tenth of a meter resolution for the storage of my heights", where 0.1 would be the magnitude and "m" would be the unit.
member.remarks:
For coordinate systems with projected or geographic base storage types, the vertical resolution directly affects the scaling of the Z-storage dimension. For a coordinate system with a geocentric base storage type, the vertical resolution does not directly affect the scaling of the Z-storage dimension. Instead, it indicates the accuracy/resolution of the heights generated from geocentric (X, Y, and Z) data locations.
Changing the storage resolution after coordinate data has been collected for persistent storage invalidates subsequent coordinate system operations and many operations dependent on the coordinate system, such as measurement.
member.param: This value must be greater than 0.0.

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CoordSystem.SetVertResByPaperHeightVal(System.Double,System.String)
member.summary: Specifies the vertical storage resolution in reference to a paper height value. This method requires the magnitude of the paper height value and the linear unit of measure name as inputs. This form mimics the natural language describing data resolution (accuracy), such as the expression "a thousandth of an inch resolution for the storage of my paper heights", where 0.001 would be the magnitude and "in" would be the unit.
member.remarks:
For coordinate systems with projected or geographic base storage types, the vertical resolution directly affects the scaling of the Z-storage dimension. For a coordinate system with a geocentric base storage type, the vertical resolution does not directly affect the scaling of the Z-storage dimension. Instead, it indicates the accuracy/resolution of the heights generated from geocentric (X, Y, and Z) data locations.
Changing the storage resolution after coordinate data has been collected for persistent storage invalidates subsequent coordinate system operations and many operations dependent on the coordinate system (such as measurement).

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CoordSystem.TransformPoint(Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSPointConstants,System.Int32,Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSPointConstants,System.Int32,System.Double@,System.Double@,System.Double@)
member.summary:
Transforms a single point between different reference spaces according to the capabilities of the object and the method parameters.
The TransformPoint method accepts a single point (specified as X, Y, and Z coordinate values) to transform, accepts the input and output point types, and accepts input and output reference space identifiers as input. The method returns the X, Y, and Z coordinate values of the transformed point, using the same parameters as used for the input coordinate values.
member.remarks: The X, Y, and Z parameters serve as both input and output (the transformation is done “in place”).
member.param: This parameter is ignored, but must be set to 1.
This parameter is ignored, but must be set to 1.

member.name: M:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CoordSystem.TransformPoints(Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSPointConstants,System.Int32,Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CSPointConstants,System.Int32,System.Double[])
member.summary:
Transforms coordinates between different reference spaces.
The TransformPoints method accepts an array of points to transform, accepts the input and output point types, and accepts input and output reference space identifiers as input. The method returns the transformed coordinates, using the same array of points as used for input.
member.param: This parameter is ignored.
This parameter is ignored.
A single-dimensional array containing the points to transform. Each point is stored as a set of 3 consecutive elements representing X, Y, and Z coordinates respectively.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CoordSystem.ApproxVertDataCenterAsHeightVal
member.summary: Sets or gets the approximate vertical data center defined as a height value in meters.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CoordSystem.BaseStorageType
member.summary: The BaseStorageType property sets or gets the base storage bond to a specified reference space.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CoordSystem.GUID
member.summary:
Sets or gets a unique identifier for the coordinate system. This identifier is a variant of type BSTR. It is a 38 byte ASCII representation of the GUID in the form {12340001-4980-1920-6788-123456789012}.
The string value returned by this property might contain hexadecimal characters. In that event, the caller should make no assumptions regarding the case. Either uppercase or lowercase may be used on input and neither should be assumed on output.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CoordSystem.GUIDType
member.summary: The GUIDType property sets or gets the GUID type. This type uses the GUIDTypeConstants to be transitory or persistent.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CoordSystem.HeightStorageType
member.summary: Returns or sets the storage of heights (sometimes called elevations) when the base storage bond has been defined to bind storage to either the projected or geographic reference space.
member.remarks:
Changing this property after coordinate data has been collected for persistent storage invalidates subsequent coordinate system operations and many operations, such as measurement, dependent on the coordinate system.
Setting the HeightStorageType property is not applicable to a CoordSystem object with a geocentric base storage type. In this case, an attempt to set the HeightStorageType property produces an error.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CoordSystem.LonNormStorageOpt
member.summary: Sets or gets the storage normalization of longitude when the base storage bond has been defined to bind storage to the geographic reference space. Options for specifying the longitude normalization are CSLongitudeNormalizationConstants.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CoordSystem.Name
member.summary: An information string that can be used to hold a name for this particular coordinate system object with its unique parameters.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CoordSystem.RefSpaceMgr
member.summary: Returns the RefSpaceMgr object for the given CoordSystem object. This property extends the methods and properties of the RefSpaceMgr object to the CoordSystem object.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CoordSystem.StorageToCompMatrix
member.summary: Gets or sets the transformation from storage coordinates to computational base coordinates. The 4 x 4 matrix consists of an array of 16 Double values arranged in column-major order.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CoordSystem.StorageToPaperScale
member.summary: Returns the current scale factor between storage and meters on the scaled paper plane.
member.remarks: When storage coordinates are defined to be geographic, this property emulates the default associated projection in its computation of the scale.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.CoordSystem.StorageToProjectionScale
member.summary: Returns the current scale factor between storage and projection values.
member.remarks: When storage coordinates are defined to be geographic, this property emulates the default associated projection in its computation of the scale.

member.name: M:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTDataContext.OpenFeature(System.Int16,System.Int32)
member.summary: Method to open a feature for editing.
member.remarks:
This routine is used for editing or reviewing a feature.
GTDataContext is responsible for caching the GTKeyObject for editing features until the transaction is committed or rolled back.
This method does not fail if no transaction is in progress, but it also does cache the GTKeyObject. That is, the feature is read-only and any changes to the feature are temporary. The returned GTKeyObject is cached if there is a transaction in progress when this method is called.
When caching is enabled (that is, a transaction is in progress), you should not call OpenFeature to open thousands or even hundreds of features at a time. If you must open many features, and you are calling this method in the context of a custom command, consider calling GTTransactionManager.Commit on sets of 100 or fewer features. If you are calling OpenFeature in the context of another interface (for example, the IGTPostProcess interface), you do not have control of the transaction, and therefore you cannot call GTTransactionManager.Commit on sets of 100 features. In this case, you should consider alternative means for updating many features. A database procedure is one choice. Converting your IGTPostProcess interface to a custom command is another choice. If you implement a database procedure, you must understand that Functional interfaces and Attribute edit Control interfaces are not executed.
If caching is not enabled (that is, a transaction is not in progress), you should still limit the number of GTKeyObject objects that are instantiated at any given time, although the number you can open is higher (in the hundreds). However, this still may not be the most efficient means of accessing the data. For read-only access to large quantities of data, especially from multiple component tables, consider using GTDataContext.OpenRecordset to query the precise data you need. This approach ensures that you get the data in one query to the database, instead of possibly many queries.
For the given FNO, FID, the returned GTKeyObject object has a GTComponents collection property that exposes access to each GTComponent object that makes up the returned feature. Each GTComponent has a Recordset property that exposes the records, fields, and values for a given component instance (CNO, CID). Calling Recordset.AddNew, Recordset.Delete, or making edits to existing Recordset field values causes IGTFunctional and IGTAttributeEditControl interfaces to execute.
Do not call Recordset.Update. It does not do anything because these Recordsets are disconnected from the underlying database connection. Instead, changes to the GTComponent's Recordset are saved to the database when you explicitly call GTTransactionManager.Commit from your custom command or when the governing product command commits its transaction. The "Update" IGTFunctional interfaces are executed as part of the commit operation.
You cannot use the same GTKeyObject in multiple transactions. Depending on the .Net code language that is used, you should set the GTKeyObject to Nothing(VB.Net) or null(C#) after calling GTTransactionManager.Commit because it is no longer in the underlying cache. You must call OpenFeature again to make subsequent edits to the same feature.
member.param: Feature number of the feature to be opened.
Feature ID of the feature to be opened.

member.name: T:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.Link
member.summary:
A Link object is an individual link in the transformation path. The link object can be a coordinate system, datum transformation, or least-squares transformation.
A Link object is created through the Links.Add method. This method also specifies the link type. Use TransLinks.Append to include the Link object in the transformation path.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.Link.LinkObject
member.summary:
A Link object is an individual link in the transformation path. The link object can be a coordinate system, datum transformation, or least-squares transformation.
A Link object is created through the Links.Add method. This method also specifies the link type. Use TransLinks.Append to include the Link object in the transformation path.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.Link.Type
member.summary:
The Type property returns the type of the transformation object that comprises the Link object. The link can be one of four types: coordinate system, datum transformation, least-squares, and reference space manager.
The Type property returns a constant value that was assigned to the Link object when it was created.
member.remarks: A Link object's type is specified as a parameter of the Links.Add method during creation of the link.

member.name: P:Intergraph.CoordinateSystems.Link.COMLink
member.summary: Provides the underlying COM object for other .NET wrappers.

member.summary: Creates a new empty raster geometry.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTRasterGeometry.RasterPolygon
member.summary: Retrieves the polygon border of the raster image. This will always be a polygon with 4 distinct vertices, but will not always be a rectangle or even a parallelogram. The shape of the polygon is determined by the raster image's transformation matrix. If the image is skewed, the returned polygon reflects the skewing.

member.name: P:Intergraph.GTechnology.API.GTRasterGeometry.DisplayMatrix
member.summary: Sets or returns the transformation matrix applied to the raster image. This matrix transforms coordinates in the image's "pixel space" (that is, pixels within the image file) to the world coordinates of the map window where the image is displayed.
